Puno, ella tiene 52 años D. edad, D. estado civil casada, es madre D. 02 hijos y tiene estudios D. primaria completa,  vive en el Barrio Revolución.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 02 años,  su primer préstamo fue D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles el cual utilizó para la compra D. ropa. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo D. S/. 500.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra D. ropas D. adultos y D. todas las tallas.

Su deseo es seguir trabajando y así solventar los gastos familiares.

A ella le gustan los ahorros, los encuentros del Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
Bernardina is a member of the Community Bank "Las Poderosas D. Santa Rosa", located in the district and province of Azangaro, in Puno. She is 52 years old, she is married, and she is mother of 2 children. She completed primary school. She lives in Barrio Revolucion.

She has been with Manuela Ramos (Kiva Field Partner) for the past 2 years. Her first loan of S/.500 nuevos soles was invested in the purchase of items of clothing.

She requires a loan of S/.500 nuevos soles. The funds will be used to purchase clothing for adults in various sizes.

Her wish is to keep working and to cover the family's expenses.

She loves being able to save money, and she enjoys the Community Bank meetings.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothing for adults in various sizes.

loans.name: Juana Teresa

texts.es:
La señorita Juana tiene 31 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.  Ella es socia del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”
La empresaria presenta estudio superiores completos.
Juana se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza de Unique, Avon y Esika
Este es el primer crédito que solicita, ella requiere 300 soles para invertir en su negocio, comprará mas productos de belleza para tener en stock y poder vender con mas rapidez y facilidad.
También ha empezado a comprar vitrinas y  mostradores para colocar sus productos en su casa y posteriormente alquilar un stand en una tienda comercial en trujillo.
Juana tiene como sueño incrementar su negocio, ganar mas clientes y obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Juana, 31, lives in the Salaverry district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She is a member of the Las Emprendedoras II Community Bank. She has a college degree. Juana sells Unique, Avon, and Esika beauty products. This is her first loan. She needs 300 PEN to buy more beauty products to have in stock. Then she will be able to sell faster and easier. She has also started to buy display cases and counters for her products in her house. Later, she will rent a stand in a store in Trujillo. Juana’s dream is to expand her business, gain more customers, and get greater income.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more products to stock her inventory

loans.name: Silvia Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Silvia, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 51 años de edad, estado civil conviviente, es madre de 01 hijo y tiene estudios superiores (Docente de Ciencias Sociales),  vive en el Barrio Pedro Vilcapaza.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles con el cual compró abarrotes.

En este momento ella solicito un préstamo de S/.  1300.00 nuevos soles. Para la compra de arroz, azúcar, leche, fideos, y también combustible.

Su deseo es continuar trabajando para solventar los gastos familiares. A ella le gusta la forma de trabajo del Movimiento Manuela Ramos.
texts.en:
Silvia belongs to the Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa Community Bank, which is located in the Azangaro district, Azangaro province, Puno department. She is 51, in a common law marriage, and has a son. She has a college degree (Social Studies teacher). She lives in the Pedro Vilcapaza neighborhood. She works with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos. With her first loan for 300 PEN, she bought groceries. She is now asking for a loan for 1,300 PEN to buy rice, sugar, milk, noodles, and fuel. Her wish is to keep working to pay the family expenses. She likes the way the Movimiento Manuela Ramos works.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, milk, noodles, and fuel

loans.name: Ma. Anna

texts.en:
Ma. Anna A., 41, a mother of four and the wife of a shoemaker, lives and manages their home business in Balubad Settlement, a poor community in Marikina City, Philippines. 

Anna sells and delivers the shoes and sandals made by her husband, who formerly worked as a shoemaker in a prominent shoe manufacturing company in Marikina. They have been in the business for almost fifteen years. Their products are noted for their good quality. They are now distributed through their dealers to private and government offices,  which earns them a minimum P500 per day. In addition, Anna cooks and sells snacks to some small offices in Marikina and San Mateo.

This loan will be used to purchase some raw materials directly from the manufacturers. They can save as much as 70 percent of the total cost of what they would have paid to retailers.

Anna prays that they will be blessed with enough capital that they will be able to produce more shoes and sandals. This will enable them to sell their products in the provinces at prices that are much higher than in Metro Manila.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for their shoemaking business

loans.name: Gloria Maria

texts.es:
La señora Gloria Maria tiene 54 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry , provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios secundarios completos, tiene 2 hijos pero son mayores y ninguno depende económicamente de ella.
Gloria se dedica a hacer manualidades de todo tipo, especialmente almohadones y tejidos.
Ella requiere un primer préstamo de S/. 300 soles para comprar materiales para sus manualidades como: telas,hilos,Algodón, Lentejuelas, etc

Ella desea seguir creciendo en su negocio, para ello piensa solicitar más prestamos que le permitan incrementar su capital.
texts.en:
Gloria Maria is 54. She lives in the Salaverry district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She has a high school education. She has two children, but they are grown and independent. Gloria makes handicrafts of all kinds. Her specialties are cushions and weavings. She needs a loan for 300 PEN to buy materials like fabric, thread, cotton, sequins, etc. for her handicrafts. She wants her business to keep growing. To do that she thinks she will ask for more loans that will allow her to increase her capital.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials like fabric, thread, wire, and sequins for her handicrafts

loans.name: María Lourdes

texts.es:
Con mucho entusiasmo en su negocio, la señora María Lourdes R. se dedica a elaborar diferentes platillos de comida los cuales son ofrecidos en el mercado Mayoreo que es donde tiene el negocio.

A pesar de las difíciles circunstancias económicas que ella ha atravesado, ha logrado salir adelante en su negocio y ha acudido a Ceprodel esperando ser beneficiada con un crédito para la compra de la materia prima y así continuar elaborando sus deliciosos platillos en su localidad.
texts.en:
With much enthusiasm for her work, Mrs. María Lourdes R. prepares different dishes of food and sells them from the wholesale market where her business is located.

Despite going through economic difficulties, she has managed to succeed in her business. She has come to Ceprodel requesting a loan to purchase ingredients so that she can continue preparing delicious dishes from her vending location.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for preparing meals

loans.name: Sonia María

texts.es:
En el Mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua, la señora Sonia L. desde hace nueve años se dedica a atender su negocio de venta de plátanos siendo este negocio el que le permite el sustento para su hogar.

Con mucho esfuerzo ha buscado la manera de salir adelante y para ello espera en que Ceprodel le brinde un crédito para la compra de los plátanos y de esta manera comercializarlos en su localidad que tanto es visitada por los clientes.
texts.en:
From the Mercardo Mayoreo in the city of Managua, Mrs. Sonia L. has been selling bananas for nine years. Being in business has allowed her to maintain her standard of living.

With great effort, she has looked for ways to move forward. We expect that Ceprodel will approve her loan, which will be used to purchase of bananas. She then can sell them from her vending location, which is frequented by her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bananas

loans.name: Catalina

texts.es:
La señora Catalina, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Flor Azangarina II”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 41 años de edad, de estado civil casada, es madre de 04 hijos y tiene estudios de secundaria completa,  vive en el Barrio Alianza.

Inicia su trabajo con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos con un préstamo inicial de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, el cual utilizó para aumentar el capital de su negocio, ella se dedica a la venta de ropas, para niños y adultos, también vende mantas bien surtidas.  Nos comenta que lleva también su negocio a las ferias de Desaguadero. 

Su mayor sueño es poder seguir trabajando. A ella le gustan las facilidades de pago  y los préstamos que da el Movimiento Manuela Ramos.
texts.en:
Sra. Catalina is a member of the Communal Bank group "Flor Azangarina II", which is located in the Azangaro district of Azangaro Province, Puno Department. She is 41 years old, married, and the mother of 4 children who have completed high school. She lives in the town of Alianza.

She just started working with Manuela Ramos and has received her initial loan of 500 soles, which will be used as capital for her business. She sells clothing for children and adults, as well as blankets. Sra. Catalina told us that she sells her merchandise at the open markets in Desaguadero.

Her biggest dream is to continue working. She likes the ease of payments for the loans given by Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing for children and adults

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria  A. , 36, is a mother of 4 girls  ages 13, 11, 10,5 and a wife to a sewer. She runs a small sewing business and a sari-sari store.  They live in a small indigent community at Panganiban St., Concepcion 2, Marikina City.
Gloria and Walter were both skilled sewers making shirts, pants and bags in a big sewing company when they met. This has been their source of income  until Gloria gave birth to their youngest daughter. They decided  to resign from their work and accept sewing jobs at home instead so they could still earn a living while attending to the needs of their growing children.  For two years now, they are working as  sub- contractors to Natasha, a big name local manufacturer.
The need to have an everyday income drives  Gloria to put up a small sari-sari store where she used her previous loan in CCT.  Utilizing her new loan, Gloria plans to add more goods to her fast growing store.  
In the future, Gloria plans to acquire 3 more sewing machines and hire a few seamstresses to help  them with the business because with only 2 sewing machines at the present, their capability to accept bigger job orders is limited

loans.use: more goods for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Roxana Luz

texts.es:
La señora Roxana R. C.   tiene 28  años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry , provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios superiores completos, tiene 2 hijos que dependen económicamente de ella.
Roxana  se dedica a la venta de productos de nutrición y adelgazamiento Herbalife (medicina natural), los cuales los vende a sus familiares, amistades y los promociona a través de volantes.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles ella empezó con la compra de productos de belleza de Unique, Yanbal. Avon.
Con este crédito de S/ 1,200, lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra de mas productos de Herbalife para aumentar su stock y generar mayores ganancias.
Roxana  tiene como sueño incrementar sus ventas para generar mas dinero.
texts.en:
Mrs. Roxana R. C. is 28 years old. She lives in the Salaverry district of Trujillo province, department of La Libertad, Peru. This businesswoman completed her high school education. She has 2 dependent children.

Roxana sells Herbalife nutritional and weight loss products (natural medicines) to relatives and friends, and advertises through promotional flyers. With her first loan of 300 soles she purchased beauty products from Unique, Yanbal, and Avon. With this loan of 1200 soles, she will buy more Herbalife products to expand her inventory and generate more profits. Roxana dreams of increasing her sales so that she can generate more income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more Herbalife products

loans.name: Alfredo Antonio

texts.es:
En el Mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua, el señor Alfredo Antonio A. se dedica a laborar arduamente en su negocio de pulpería vendiendo diferentes tipos de productos los cuales comercializa muy alegremente en su localidad donde es visitado por sus clientes.

Es de importancia destacar que a pesar de las difíciles situaciones económicas que ha atravesado, ha logrado salir adelante y es por esta razón que hoy en día tiene muchas más ganas de mejorar su pulpería y para ello ha solicitado un crédito en Ceprodel para dar lugar a la compra de los productos para surtir el negocio y así percibir mejores ingresos en su negocio.
texts.en:
In the wholesale market in Managua, Mr. Alfredo Antonio works hard in the grocery business selling different types of products that are gladly sold to customers that visit there. It is important to note that in spite of the setbacks of the difficult economic situation, he has continued to move forward. For this reason today he has much desire to improve his grocery business. He is asking for a loan from Ceprodel to buy more products for his business. In this way he will provide revenue for his business.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase products for his grocery business.

loans.name: María Genara

texts.es:
Con mucho entusiasmo y con muchas ganas de salir adelante, la señora María J. se dedica a su negocio de elaboración y venta de alimentos los cuales son  comercializados por ella misma en su localidad.

Es de mucha importancia destacar que ella se dedica a este negocio desde hace 20 largos años y por esto es que ha adquirido mucha experiencia en la elaboración de los alimentos por lo que es muy visitada por las personas que a diario compran los deliciosos alimentos que ella prepara.
texts.en:
María J. works with much enthusiasm and the desire to get ahead. She makes and sells food. She sells the food herself at her site. She has been in this business for 20 long years, and she has gained a lot of experience making food. Therefore, she has a lot of people come to her site daily to buy the delicious food that she prepares.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make food

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es:
La señora Lidia C. es una dama muy alegre que desde muy jovencita aprendió a elaborar tortillas y hoy en día es el negocio propio que ella tiene y es su fuente de ingresos para mantener a su familia.

Como todo negocio en desarrollo, su negocio requiere de la compra del maíz para elaborar las tortillas y por esta razón es que espera en Ceprodel para que le brinde un crédito y así comprar el maíz para elaborar las deliciosas tortillas que ella sabe preparar en su localidad en el mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua.
texts.en:
Lidia C. is a very happy woman. When she was a very young girl she learned to make tortillas. She now has her own business, and it is her source of income to support her family. As with all developing businesses, her business needs to buy corn to make the tortillas. That is why she hopes that Ceprodel will give her a loan. Then she will buy the corn to make the delicious tortillas that she knows how to prepare. She will do this at her site in the Mayoreo market in the city of Managua.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn

loans.name: Dora Josefa

texts.es:
Gracias a los grandes esfuerzos llevados a cabo por la señora Dora A., ha logrado salir adelante en su negocio de venta de ropa habiendo mejorado su negocio adquiriendo mercadería la cual la ofrece a diario en su establecimiento. 

Ella actualmente ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para la compra de la ropa y así mantener sus estantes listos para cuando llegan sus clientes puedan llevar el producto y lograr su satisfacción. Su negocio está ubicado en el mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua y se dedica a este negocio desde hace siete años.
texts.en:
Thanks to the blessings of a greater power, Mrs. Dora has achieved success in her clothing business. She has improved her business by acquiring merchandise that she offers daily to her customers in her establishment. She is looking to Ceprodel for a loan to buy clothes and stock her shelves so that when her customers arrive they can buy her products and be satisfied. Her business is located in the wholesale market in Managua. She has been in business for seven years.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothes

loans.name: Vidal

texts.es:
En el Mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua, el señor Vidal A. se dedica a su negocio de venta de productos lácteos como lo son el queso y la cuajada siendo este negocio el que le genera ingresos para sustentar su amada familia.

Con el propósito de mejorar y ampliar sus ventas, ha solicitado en Ceprodel un crédito para la compra del queso para ofrecerlo en su establecimiento y así continuar mejorando poco a poco su nivel de ingresos y logrando la satisfacción de todos y cada uno de los clientes por medio del negocio.
texts.en:
Mr. Vidal A. sells dairy products like cheese and cuajada (milk curd, a typical Nicaraguan food) in Managua's Mayoreo Market. This business provides him with enough of an income to support his beloved family. With the aim of improving and increasing his sales, he has requested a loan from Ceprodel that he will use to buy cheese to sell in his establishment, and so continue gradually to improve his income level and satisfy each and every one of his customers with his business.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cheese

loans.name: God Is Love And My Guide Group

texts.es:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL
DIOS ES AMOR Y MI GUIA

“Dios es amor y mi guía” es una Alcom muy responsable y puntal en sus pagos, la presidenta  Sra. Edid A. S. D. G. se siente muy satisfecha D. trabajar con personas responsables, unidas y Colaboradoras.

La señora Edid tiene un negocio D. buffet donD. trabaja toda su familia. Ella empezó estudiando cursos D. pastelería, desD. entonces comenzó a hacer pasteles y tortas en casa y venderlos, lo cual agradó a sus vecinos y empezaron a hacerles pedidos; pero eso no fue suficiente para ella ya que incremento su negocio haciendo comidas y cócteles para reuniones D. su familia y a su vez D. su vecindario. Ahora después D. 18 años logro tener su negocio familiar ya que sus hijas también colaboran con ella cuando tienen pedidos al por mayor.

Los mas D. 18 años D. trabajo satisface mucho a la socia pero ella se preocupa en el bienestar D. sus compañeras, porque les enseña lo que aprenD. para que ellas también puedan incrementar sus ingresos familiares.

El crédito  otorgado a la Sra. lo invertirá en comprar insumos para su buffet y comprar algunos utensilios que le hacen falta.

Ella nos comenta que desea que la socias no solo tengan un crédito, sino también crezcan como personas con valores y principios. Cada vez que realizan sus reuniones hacen sus oraciones pidiendo al ser supremo que los guié y los oriente.
texts.en:
Community Savings God is Love and my GuiD. “God is Love and my GuiD.” is a very responsible group and is punctual in its repayments. The president, Mrs. Edid A. S. D. GranD. is very satisfied in working with responsible, united, and collaborative people. Mrs. Edid has a buffet business, where her whole family works. She began studying pastry-making, and since then, she began to make pastries and cakes in her house and then sell them. Her neighbors liked this and began to place orders. This, however, wasn’t enough for her, so she began to grow her business by making food and cocktails for family and neighborhood get-togethers. Now, after 18 years, she has succeeded in having a family-run business; her daughters also work with her when they have many orders. Those more than 18 years of work satisfy her a great deal, but she worries about the well-being of her friends, so she teaches them what they need to know so that they can also increase their incomes. The loan granted to Mrs. Edid will be invested to buy supplies for her buffet and to buy some utensils that she lacks. She told us that she wants the other members to not only have a loan, but also to grow as people with values and principles. Each time that the group members meet, they make speeches asking the supreme bring to guiD. them and to direct them.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica D. F. is 33 years old and is married with six children, all of school age. She lives in Camanga Village, Tukuran, Zambonaga Del Sur.

Jessica has been in agriculture for almost four years. She joined Paglaum MPC last year with a previous loan of PHP 5,000. She is now in her 3rd loan with a loan amount of PHP 5,000 which will be used as additional capital to buy garden fertilizer. She deeply wishes to have a good harvest and hopes to live a good life ahead.

loans.use: To buy garden fertilizer

loans.name: Elma Marie

texts.en: Elma Marie R. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 28 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. Elma Marie owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Elma Marie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. Elma Marie is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 7th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita M. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 55 years old, married, and has seven adult children. Nenita owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily selling snacks known as "suman" (glutinous rice cooked in coconut milk, and often steamed in banana leaves) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Nenita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Ermetania

texts.en:
Ermetania M., 52 years old, lives with her six children in Camanga Village, Zamboanga Del Sur.

Ermetania earns PHP 8,000 from her garden. She joined Paglaum MPC microfinance program in November 2007. She has religiously paid her previous loan and has now applied for her 5th loan of PHP 7,000 which she will use to buy garden fertilizer. The profit she earns from her garden she will use to expand their livelihood and support her family expenses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her garden

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena M. is from the town of Katipunan. She is 48 years old. Helena is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Helena owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector, operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling ready-to-wear clothes in the local community. Helena has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Helena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Helena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Helena from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Bernardita

texts.en:
Bernardita S. is from the town of Katipunan. She is 39 years old. Bernardita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Bernardita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Bernardita has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Bernardita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernardita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Bernardita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Bernardita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
Laila F. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 21 years old. Laila is married and has an infant. To make a living, Laila owns & operates a business venture in the services sector, operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing a motor cab for hire to local community members. Laila has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Laila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. Laila is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Laila from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en: Marcelina Y. is from the town of Polanco. She is 57 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. Marcelina owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale and also operates a sari-sari (variety) store at home. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Marcelina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. Marcelina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies, as well as stock for her sari-sari store. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies as well as stock for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa R. makes a living primarily from selling peanuts in the local community. She is 53 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the city of Dapitan. Felisa has been in this business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Felisa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living condition and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. Felisa is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in a new business selling gasoline in bottles. This will be her fifth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in a business selling gasoline

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie H. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 28 years old. Melanie is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Melanie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Melanie is just starting this business.

In 2004, Melanie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Melanie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Melanie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Leonarda

texts.en:
Leonarda G. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 54 years old and married with 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Leonarda prepares and sells a variety of food products in the local community. Leonarda has been in this business for over 22 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

Leonarda joined PMPC in 2000 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonarda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC, which she had used to purchase additional products to sell.  Leonarda is now requesting her 20th loan from PMPC in the amount of of 30,000 PHP.  She will use it for working capital and to purchase additional inventory, and plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
H. Nguyễn Thị is a 45 year-old married mother of 5 grown children living in the town of Vĩnh Phúc in the Phuc Yen province.  To making a living, H. raises water buffalo.  H. has been in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month.

H. joined TYM Fund in 1999 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  H. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000,000 VND from TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell.  H. is now requesting her 5th loan from TYM Fund in the amount of 10,000,000 VND in order to purchase breeding livestock.  H. believes this will help to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen S. is from the village of Polo Pitogo. She is 34 years old. Helen is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Helen owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Helen has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Helen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Helen is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 14th loan taken out by Helen from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna, or Lhor to her friends, is 48 and has been in the rice-distribution business for six years. She lives, together with her family, a couple of blocks away from the city's garbage dump area, popularly known as Payatas. Under and around the foot of the gigantic mountain of garbage live Philippines' poorest urban residents, the scavengers. Lorna has four kids, two of whom are in college. Her eldest already graduated from college, all thanks to her rice business. 

Lhor owns one of the only three government rice-distribution stores in Payatas. She regularly receives two rice deliveries per week. Each delivery gives her 20 sacks (50 kilos each) of government rice, which she pays for upon delivery. She then repacks the rice and sells it to the community for PHP18.00 per kilo, half the price of other commercial rice. The delivery, repacking and selling all lasts but a day after delivery. The business earns an income of PHP20,000.00 per month.

Lhor considers the business not only as a blessing to her family, but most importantly to her community. More than 300 residents, some of them scavengers from around Payatas, line up every week to get their weekly ration of rice. The line can go as far as 100 meters from the front of Lhor's store. She says she wants to upgrade her order of 40 sacks a week to 70, because more and more families are not able to buy their ration because Lhor's supply runs out every time for them. Dealers like Lorna are chosen by the Social Welfare Department as authorized distributors to poor communities.

Lhor has never missed a savings or loan payment for all her six years of borrowing. Her previous loan was for PHP30,000. She is now borrowing her 13th loan from the Center for Community Transformation (CCT).

CCT is a Filipino family-oriented and Bible-centered development organization that provides and creates equal business opportunities for small-scale Filipino entrepreneurs through loans and social interventions.

loans.use: Expand her government rice-distribution business

loans.name: Motee'

texts.en:
Motee' is a young man, 21 years old. He is living with his family: father, mother and six brothers and sisters. He contributes 30% of his business income to cover his family’s expenses.

Motee' finished high school but didn't continue his education. After finishing school he started to help his father in his shop and, after one year of gaining business experience, he decided to start his own business. 

Motee' started to sell clothes as a vendor. Then, from the income, he established his own shop in one of Jenin’s small shopping malls.

This is Motee’s first loan with FATEN, but he has been in this activity for four years and he is a very hardworking young man. In the photo, Motee' appears at his shop.

loans.use: To buy new inventory for the summer season

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is 27 years old, married, and has two children aged 3 years and 3 months. He is living in the same house as his father, mother and four of his brothers.

Mohammad’s business is the only source of income for the family since his mother is suffering problems with her heart while the cost for such things is very expensive. He started his business four years ago and his mother’s sickness was the main drive for him to work harder, especially since he lives in Qalqilia, which is surrounded by the wall (Israel established this wall for security reasons and a huge amount land was confiscated for it. Qalqilia was much affected since it is a border town and very famous for its agriculture).

This is Mohammad’s first loan with FATEN. He has asked for $1,500 to buy clothes for the summer season. Mohammad’s shop sells clothes for children, not expensive clothes, to suit the economic status of the poor people. 
 
Mohammad appears in the photo at his shop.

loans.use: To purchase new stuff for the summer season

loans.name: Kareema

texts.en:
Kareema is 54 years old. She has ten children, six of whom are married and financially independent from the family. Her other four children still live at home: two of them are under 18 years old and still at school, while the other two are working at the family barber shop.

The barber shop is the only source of income for the family since Kareema's husband does not work. Kareema started the business three years ago in order to give her children a career. They were already trained to do haircutting and had worked for a while at other barber shops.

Kareema helps her two children by buying all the merchandise and cleaning the shop. The new loan will be used to pay for the shop rent since they decided to move to a new, bigger shop that has a better location.

This is Kareema's second loan. Her first loan was for $700 and was fully repaid on time.
 
Kareema's son appears in the photo at his saloon after they moved to the new location and did some renovation. Kareema doesn't appear in the photo for social reasons.

loans.use: To pay rent for the new barber shop

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en:
Nadia is 38 years old and is married with four children: two boys aged 9 and 11 years old and two girls aged 6 and 5 years old.

Nadia started her kindergarten a few years ago. She thought of having a small kindergarten for children below 4 years old since her husband is not working on a permanent basis. The kindergarten started with only one room and a small kitchenette and reception and only four infants. Currently she has a good apartment with twenty-two children. The kindergarten is under the supervision of the Ministry of Health and is officially registered. The kindergarten is the main source of income for the family.

Nadia needs $3,000 to buy new beds for the children, new toys, and to renovate the kindergarten during summer since during summer she closes it for one month for renovation.

Nadia’s husband helps her in the kindergarten. He buys groceries and other stuff in addition to taking some children home to  their families. 

In the photo, Nadia appears in the kindergarten with her husband.

loans.use: To purchase toys and equipment for the kindergarten

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Roshan Liqa Group

texts.en: This is the Roshan Liqa group. It is made up of five members. All of them would like to increase their businesses. Saher wants to take a loan for her beauty salon to buy new and good quality cosmetics. Naqibullah wants to take a loan for his house repairing. Habibullah would like to take a loan for his burger shop to buy the essential materials for his shop. Wahida would like to take a loan for a tailoring business to buy a new machine and other supplies. S. Bebe wants to take a loan for a carpet weaving business. They all have requested a loan of 50000 Afghani to complete their necessities. Besides, they would like to improve their business and bring changes in life.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics

loans.name: Shikeba Pari Gul Group

texts.en: This is the Shikeba Pari Gul group, which is made up of four members. Each of them wants to take a loan of 14000 Afghani. Shikeba wants to take a loan for carpet weaving to buy good quality materials. Zakia wants to take a loan for his brother who has got a mobile shop. Parwin and Pari Gul want to take a loan for the tailoring business. All the members would like to be successful in their businesses and progress well. The total amount they have requested is 56000 Afgani. They admire this process so much and mention that Kiva is a really effective program.

loans.use: To buy good quality materials

loans.name: Khsang's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is being requested by three borrowers, all of whom live in Rolosh Commune in Siem Reap Province. The group leader, Khsang H., 53, is a widowed mother caring for four children who are students. She currently earns a living planting vegetable crops. All of her children also work by growing crops when they are not studying.

Since the crop business is a main source of family income, Khsang H. has requested a loan to grow different kinds of crops during this farming season.

The other two borrowers are N., who will be using part of the loan to buy a bicycle for her family and the rest to buy more fertilizer to improve her crop yield, and L., who is an internal staff member for a hotel and is asking for a loan to buy a bicycle to ride to work.

loans.use: To grow different kinds of crops during this farming season

loans.name: Samar Qand Group

texts.en:
Samar Qand group is made up of four members. They would like to increase their business and complete all their necessities.

Ajmal has got a general store, so he wants to take a loan to complete his stock. M. Yousef has a fruit shop and he desires to have an increased one and buy more fruits. Eid M. and A. A. are farmers and they want to take a loan for purchasing more seeds and tools for farming to have more cultivated land.

loans.use: To increase their businesses and help their families better in future

loans.name: Night

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 31-year-old Night M. from Mwanza. She is married with three children between the ages of 2 and 11 years old. Night has been running a shop since 2001. She sells soda, breads, soap and cooking oil. She works at the business 16 hours per day, 7 days per week, and is assisted by two employees. Night currently earns about 180USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase cooking oil, soda and breads. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Night thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro credit in Tanzania through micro leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil, soda and breads.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tomatoes, bananas and soap

loans.name: Chhim's Group

texts.en:
Chhim S., 55, has been chosen to be leader by other members of this group loan. Chhim S. currently owns a bicycle, which she uses for riding to buy used goods at the cheapest price door-to-door and then sells them out to gain a profit. She is a married woman blessed with two children, one of whom is married and lives separately, whilst the other one is still living in the family home. Another source of income is from her husband who works in construction. Chhim S. is applying for a loan to purchase an old motor for her family’s traveling needs. This will help the family reduce paying tax costs. The other three borrowers who are jointly taking this loan are:
M., a farmer, who is asking for a loan to buy piglets to raise.
M. who will be using the loan to decorate her house.
L. who will take out this loan to buy a used motor to make the family's transportation easier.

loans.use: To purchase an old motor for family’s traveling needs

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Anna K. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, who are 9 and 17 years old. Anna has been running a tailoring business since 2005. Her business is to make clothes for women. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Anna currently earns about $300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD in order to purchase threads and a sewing machine. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Anna thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase threads and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy T., age 45, of San Mateo, Rizal, Philippines, is the mother of two grade-school-aged girls and the wife of a businessman.

Mercy runs an apparel-sewing business that caters mostly to schools and offices in Metro Manila. For seven years, her shop has produced custom-made clothes, school and office uniforms, tote bags, and caps. She plans to use her loan to purchase additional cloth and other sewing materials.

During lean months (January to March and July to August), Mercy accepts sub-contract sewing jobs from bigger companies to be able to pay for the salary of her six seamstresses and to pay for other expenses. The business now earns an average net income of 25,000 PHP per month.

In the near future, Mercy plans to create her own line of t-shirts, bags, and caps with Christian themes, and to acquire a store space in a mall where she prefers to market her products.

loans.use: Cloth and sewing materials

loans.name: Lelane

texts.en:
Ma. Lelane O., age 39, is the mother of three children ages 8, 11, and 17, and the wife of Juny, a jeepney driver. She is a tricycle operator who lives in a poverty-stricken community in San Mateo, Rizal, Philippines.

Lelane converted her husband’s motorcycle into a tricycle (a motorcycle with a sidecar) with the help of her first loan from CCT. She uses it to transport five children to school, for which she earns 1,750 PHP per month, in addition to 200 PHP per month she earns from its everyday use as a passenger vehicle. She also uses the tricycle to purchase bananas and other food products from the market and deliver them to the neighborhoods where she sells them.

Lelane plans to use her loan to re-open her sari-sari (general) store, which was closed for months due to lack of capital. She hopes that, with improved finances, she will be able to send her eldest daughter to school again to continue her college education.

loans.use: Inventory and other expenses to re-open a general store

loans.name: Mzaituni Group

texts.en:
Joyce M., age 25, is married with two children, ages 7 and 4. Joyce has a food business, which she started in 2005. She works daily from 9am until 6.30pm and is able to earn a monthly profit of around $323.

This will be Joyce’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to open a salon and buy a sack of powdered soap (which she sells door to door), and repaid the loan successfully. She wants a new loan to improve her salon.

Joyce will share this loan with her loan group, Mzaituni, which totals 18 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Joyce is first from the left in the front row.

loans.use: To improve a salon

loans.name: Sophronia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Sophronia M. from Mwanza. She is single with three children, between the ages of 14 and 22. Sophronia has been running a café business since 2007. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), and plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by one employee. Sophronia currently earns about 300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase rice, cooking oil, and wheat flour. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Sophronia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase rice, cooking oil, and wheat flour

loans.name: Ben Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Ben est composé de six femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygamiques avec en  moyenne 45 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Banankoro (4ème Région Administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage, d’amitié et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle.
Ce groupe de femmes fait l’achat vente d’articles divers et la petite restauration (beignet et arachide grillé).
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, elles ont décidés d’adhérer au programme de crédit  de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles  sont à leur 7ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les six précédents.
Ce prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 4 sacs d’arachide en gousse, 3 sacs de haricot et 80 litres de lait. Elles s’approvisionnent en arachide et haricot hebdomadairement à la foire du village; le lait est acheté à N’Dobougou Wèrè. Elles revendent leurs marchandises à domicile, en ambulant dans les quartiers et à la foire du village (chaque jeudi)  à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants. Une partie du haricot est transformée en  farine puis en beignets et les gousses d’arachide sont grillées avant la vente. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.000FCFA qui servira à l’achat de fournitures scolaires des enfants et aider les époux à subvenir aux charges de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent faire de l’élevage des petits ruminants et avoir une charrette et un âne pour les travaux champêtres et le transport des marchandises.
texts.en:
The Ben Group is made up of six women, mostly married in polygamous families, on average 45 years old with four children. They all live in the village of Banankoro (in Mali's Fourth Administrative Region), and know one another through the bonds of marriage, neighborhood, friendship and membership in the same traditional organization. This group of women buys and sells assorted wares, and also vends doughnuts and roast peanuts. To increase their business, they have decided to join a credit plan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their seventh loan, after having fully repaid the previous six. This loan will be used to buy four sacks of unshelled peanuts, three sacks of beans, and eighty liters of milk. They buy their supplies of peanuts and beans weekly at the village fair; they buy the milk at N'Dobougou Wère. They resell their wares out of the home, around the neighborhood and at the village fair (every Thursday) to a clientele of men, women and children. They make some of the beans into flour which they use to make doughnuts, and they roast the peanuts in their shells before selling them. They hope to earn an average monthly profit of 18,000 FCFA, which will serve to buy school supplies for their children and help their husbands with the expenses of their families. They hope to begin raising small ruminants, and to have a cart and donkey for working in the fields and transporting merchandise.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of assorted wares

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Benkadi de l’association Danaya sont mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles polygamiques dans le village de Banankoro  (4ème  Région administrative du Mali). Âgées en moyenne de 45 ans avec 4 enfants, elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et d’amitié.
Les membres du groupe Benkadi font le commerce d’articles divers et de la friandise dans lesquels  ils sont très sollicités et appréciés.
Dans le but d’augmenter le volume de leurs activités, elles décidèrent de faire recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursés les six prêts précédents, elles sont à leur 7ème prêt solidaire qui  sera utilisé pour acheter,  4sacs de haricot, 2 sacs de mil, 400 kg d’oignon et un chargement de charrette en mangue. Elles s’approvisionnent en mangue dans les vergers du village, en haricot, mil et en oignon hebdomadairement à la foire du village avec les forains venant de Niono et de Ségou. Une bonne partie du haricot est transformée en beignets pour la vente. Elles revendent toutes leurs marchandises en détail au comptant et à crédit  à domicile, en ambulant dans le village, au camp militaire et à la foire hebdomadaire de Banankoro à une clientèle constituée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants. 
Elles  envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt  et pour l’épargne. 
Elles souhaitent épargner afin d’acheter des équipements pour les travaux champêtres.
texts.en:
The five women of the Group Benkadi in the Association Danaya are mostly married in traditional, large, polygamous families in the town of Banankoro (4th Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali). On average they are 45 years old with 4 children. They know each other through of the links of marriage, neighborhood and friendship.

The members of Group Benkadi sell various items and delicacies which are very wanted and popular. With the goal of increasing the volume of their business, they decided to turn to the micro-finance group Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly re-paid their 6 previous loans, they are on their 7th loan together. They will use the loan to buy 4 sacks of beans, 2 sacks of millet (grain), 400 kilograms of onions and a cart-load of mangoes. They will supply themselves with mangoes from the local orchard; they will buy beans, millet and onions from the weekly market from the vendors from Niono and Ségou. A good part of the beans is turned into donuts to sell.

They sell all of their merchandise at retail for cash and credit from their houses, walking around the town, at the military base and in the weekly market in Banankoro. Their clientele consists of men, women and children.

They anticipate earning an average monthly profit of 17.500FCFA which they will use to pay the maturity dates of the loan and for savings. They want to save to buy farming equipment.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various supplies for their business.

loans.name: Zubeda

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Zubeza B. from Mwanza, single with five children between the ages of 7 and 16. Zubeda has been running a business since 2006 selling charcoal, small black pieces of dry earth that are used by many Tanzanians as a fuel to cook their daily meals. Women cook food in small coal pots in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal) and add paper, dry grass, old plastic bags or kerosene in order to light them.

Because there is such a high demand for charcoal across the country, being a charcoal seller is quite lucrative. Working at the business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week and assisted by two employees, Zubeda currently earns about $100 per month. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase more stock in bulk and in the future plans to expand her business. Zubeda thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA! SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more stock in bulk.

loans.name: Lean's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan for three women who live in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, led by Mrs. Lean R., who is 29 and divorced. She normally generates income of $4 per day selling different kinds of vegetables in the local busy market, having attracted many clients because she is killed in communication. To achieve even greater success, Lean would like a loan from Kiva to order extra vegetables to better meet customer demand.

The other borrowers in this group are: Lean R., a vegetable-seller requesting a loan to buy more vegetables to sell; Sok S., a vegetable-seller seeking to add to her working capital.

loans.use: To order extra vegetables.

loans.name: Timinandi Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Timinandi sont mariés majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en  moyenne 46 ans et 3 enfants par femme. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Banankoro (4ème Région Administrative du Mali).
Timinandi est un groupe qui fait le commerce d’articles divers tels les céréales, les condiments alimentaires etc.
Dans le but de renforcer leur fonds de commerce, elles ont décidées d’intégrer  Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er prêt solidaire.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 6 sacs d’arachide en gousse, 3 sacs de riz et 300 kg d’oignon. L’oignon est frit et les gousses d’arachide grillées d’abord avant d’être vendus. Elles s’approvisionnent en arachide et oignon hebdomadairement à la foire du village, en riz dans les foires de Siribala, Dougabougou et Ségou. Les produits sont revendus à domicile et à la foire du village (chaque jeudi) à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour acheter du pétrole pour la lampe, du savon et pour aider les époux à subvenir aux charges familiales.

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers.

loans.name: Mario Silvio

texts.pt:
Mario Silvio O. nasceu na província do Niassa a 3.000km da capital do pais (maputo), tem 31 anos de idade, masculino, casado e pai de dois filhas com idades compreendidas entre dois e oito anos.
Freqüentou a escola ate 10 classe e interrompeu por razoes sociais e espera retomar logo que estabilizar a sua situação social e financeira.

 Vive na casa própria em boane desde o ano de 1982. Saiu de Niassa ao distrito de Boane juntamente com a sua mãe que se encontra já sob sua responsabilidade. Ele é a única pessoa com ingresso na família.

Trabalha numa empresa há dois anos como motorista por tempo indeterminado e tem um salário mensal no valor de 7.000,00MT. Aprendeu a conduzir a nove anos na escola de condução de Maputo-cidade.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos e diz ter obtido informações sobre a existência da Hluvuku-Adsema através de amigos e decidiu aproximar e submeter o primeiro pedido.

Este é o seu segundo empréstimo no valor de 20.000,00MT com o qual pretende comprar material de construção para melhorar a sua moradia.
O primeiro credito foi, também, do mesmo tamanho e com a mesma finalidade tendo reembolsado sem problemas. Compromete se a pagar o presente empréstimo em harmonia com o plano de prestações.

Mario sonha terminar a construção da sua casa para depois mobiliar e tomar mais empréstimos para negócios, com objectivo de incrementar a receita familiar.
texts.en:
Mario Silvio O. was born in the province of Niassa, which is 3Km from the capital of the country (Maputo). He is 31 years old, male, married, and the father of two daughters with ages 2 and 8. He attended school until the 10th grade and stopped for social reasons. He hopes to begin again as soon as his social and financial situations stabilize. He has lived in his own home in Boane since the year 1982. He left Niassa for the district of Boane together with his mother who is currently his responsibility. He is the only person with acceptance in his family. He has worked for a company for 2 years as a driver and has a monthly salary of 7,000MT. He learned to drive nine years ago at a driving school in the city of Maputo. He has never had any loans with other banks and says he obtained information about the existence of Hluvuku-Adsema through his friends. He decided to approach to submit his first application. This is his second loan for 20,000MT with which he intends to purchase construction materials to improve his home. The first loan was also the same size and was used for the same ends. He paid it off without problems. He is committed to paying the present loan in accordance with the payment plan. Mario dreams of finishing the construction of his home so he can later furnish it and borrow more money for business with the objective of increasing his family income.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi de l’association Djantoyerela est composé de 2 polygames et 2 monogames ayant en moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans le quartier Bananissabakoro de  la ville de Ségou (4ème  Région administrative  de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues par des liens professionnel et social et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat et la vente des céréales, des pagnes, du bois de chauffe, des produits cosmétiques etc. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt solidaire. Le premier prêt fut correctement remboursé.
Ce deuxième  prêt servira à utiliser,  20 tissus pour pantalon, 10 complets de pagnes wax, 4 sacs d’arachide, 3 sacs de mil et 5 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe.
 Le mil est décortiqué, lavé, pilé en poudre, pétri et frit en galettes  pour être vendu, quand aux graines d’arachide, elles sont triées, lavées, grillées, décortiquées et broyées pour donner de la pâte destinée à la vente. 
Elles se ravitaillent en tissus et pagnes wax mensuellement au Burkina Faso et aux autres produits à la foire hebdomadaire du grand marché de Ségou.
Elles revendent toutes leurs marchandises en détail au comptant et à crédit à domicile et en ambulant dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 31.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, la tontine et faire face aux évènements sociaux sans l’apport d’autrui.
texts.en:
Group Benkadi of the Association Djantoyerela is composed of 2 polygamous women and 2 monogamous women. On average, they are 37 years old, with 4 children each. They all live in the neighborhood of Bananissabakoro in the city of Ségou (4th Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other through professional and social links.

In their business they sell various items, such as grains, “pagnes” (brightly printed cloth), firewood, cosmetics etc. With the goal of increasing their business, they decided to join the credit program Soro Yiriwaso – this is their second loan as a group with Soro Yiriwaso. The first loan was properly repaid.

This second loan will be used to buy 20 pieces of fabric for pants, 10 sets of wax “pagnes”, 4 sacks of peanuts, 3 sacks of millet and 5 carts of firewood. The millet will be hulled, washed, crushed into a powder, then kneaded and fried as tarts for the women to sell. The peanuts will be sorted, washed, roasted, peeled and crushed into a paste (i.e. peanut butter) to sell.

They will supply the cloth and wax “pagnes” monthly from Burkina Faso and the other products at the large weekly market in Ségou.

They sell their merchandise at retail for cash or credit, from their homes and walking around the neighborhood. Their clientele composed of men, women and children.

They anticipate an average monthly profit of 31,000 FCFA which they will use to repay the loan, the tontine (a traditional revolving credit association) and to pay for social events without contribution from others.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of items for their business.

loans.name: Rosa Maria Da Gloria

texts.pt:
Rosa Maria da Gloria U. de 41 anos de idade, natural da cidade da Matola, mulher, casada e mãe de 2 filhos com idades compreendidas entre 16 e 21 anos freqüentou escola ate 6 classe e terminou quando começou quando casou e passou a viver com o seu marido ate este momento.

Saiu da Matola (a 20 km de boane) em 1986 com seus pais e no ano de 1994 transferiu se de boane a cidade de Maputo, sozinha, onde reside ate data hoje.
É comerciante com bastante experiência (a mais de 15 anos) tendo aprendido em boane, trabalha sozinha e sem empregados. A sua principal actividade é de venda de frangos congelados. O seu rendimento diário é de 900,00MT com os quais consegue sustentar a família e poupar algum, no final de cada mês.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos e que conheceu a Hluvuku-Adsema através de amigas. Este é o seu quinto credito com a instituição no valor de 28.000,00MT para reforço do volume de mercadoria e satisfazer a demanda de produtos de primeira necessidade.

Primeiramente levantou créditos na seguinte ordem de (8.700,00MT; 11.000,00MT; 15.000,00MT e 10.000,00MT) respectivamente para o exercício da mesma actividade.
Espera reembolsar em harmonia com o plano de prestações para no futuro aceder a mais empréstimos para aquisição de um terreno.
texts.en:
Rosa Maria da Gloria U. is 41 years old. She is originally from the city of Matola. She is married and has two children, 16 and 21 years old. She attended school until 6th grade but had to stop when she got married and went to live with her husband. She left Matola, 20 km from Boane, with her parents in 1986. In 1994 she moved from Boane to Maputo by herself. She's lived in Maputo ever since. She is a shopkeeper with a fair bit of experience (more than 15 years). She started working in Boane, and still works on her own, without employees. Her main economic activity is selling frozen chickens. She earns 900 meticals a day, which she uses to support her family and save a little every month. She's never received loans from other banks, and learned about Hluvuku-Adsema through friends. This is her fifth loan with the institution. The loan is in the amount of 28,000 meticals, which will be used to increase stock and satisfy demand for staple goods. Her prior loans were for 8700, 11,000, 15,000, and 10,000 meticals respectively, and were used for the same purpose. She intends to repay her loan fully and on time, in order to be able to request more loans and buy a plot of land.

Translated from Portuguese by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase stock in her shop

loans.name: Lipa

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Lipa R. from Mwanza. She is single with two children between the ages of 9 and 20 years old. Lipa has been running a tailoring business since 2005. Her business is to make clothes for women. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Lipa currently earns about 240 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase thread and a sewing machine. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Lipa thanks you for her support!


ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase thread and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes  du  groupe Sabougnouman sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames dans le quartier Bananissabakoro de la ville de  Ségou (4ème  Région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans et 5 enfants par femme.
Elles font essentiellement le commerce d’articles divers tels les pagnes wax, les produits cosmétiques,  du savon, des chaussures, du bois de chauffe, des céréales (riz, mil et arachide), des fruits et légumes, pommes de terre, bananes, pommes, mangues, oranges, etc. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur  deuxième  prêt  solidaire. Le premier prêt fut correctement remboursé sans aucune difficulté.
Ce  nouveau prêt servira à  acheter, 5 complets de pagnes wax, 20 cartons de savon, 5 sacs d’arachide, 2 cartons de pommes, 3 sacs de mil, 250 kg de banane, un chargement de charrette en mangues, 8 chargements de charrette en  bois de chauffe. Elles se ravitaillent en fruits et légumes à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et aux autres produits à la foire hebdomadaire du grand marché de Ségou. Elles revendent toutes leurs marchandises en détail au comptant  et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant dans les quartiers et dans les différents marchés de Ségou à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 26.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et aider les époux à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
Elles ont pour ambition d’avoir une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The women of the Group Sabougnouman are married, mostly in monogamous families in the neighborhood Bananissabakoro in the city of Ségou (4th Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali). On average, they are 45 years old with 5 children per woman.

Their business is basically to sell various items, such as wax “pagnes” (brightly printed cloth), cosmetics, soap, shoes, firewood, grains (rice, millet and peanuts), fruits and vegetables (like potatoes, bananas, apples, mangoes, oranges) etc.

With the goal of increasing their business, they joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom this is their second loan together. The first loan was properly repaid without difficulty.

This new loan will be used to buy 5 sets of wax “pagnes”, 20 cartons of soap, 5 sacks of peanuts, 3 cartons of apples, 3 sacks of millet, 250 kilograms of bananas, one cartload of mangoes and 8 cartloads of firewood. They will supply themselves with fruits and vegetables in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and the other products in the weekly large market in Ségou.

They will resell all of their merchandise at retail for cash and credit from their homes, walking around the neighborhoods and the other markets in Ségou to a clientele composed of men and women.

They anticipate an average monthly profit of 26,000FCFA, which will be used to repay the loan and to help their spouses provide for their families. Their ambition is to buy a house to live in.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of items for their business.

loans.name: Lita

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 44-year-old Lita M. from Mwanza. She is married with five children between the ages of 10 and 20 years old. Lita has been running a clothes business since 2004.
