She sells clothes to her customers. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Lita currently earns about 200USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase clothes to sell to her customers. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Lita thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Badegnajuru Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badegnajuru est composé de cinq  femmes  (toutes mariées)  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans, 4 enfants et vivant  la plupart dans des  familles monogames dans le quartier Babemba, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali.)
 Elles mènent  diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  des condiments alimentaires, de chaussures, du bois de chauffe etc.  
Dans le but  d’augmenter la clientèle et le profit, elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur sixième  prêt solidaire, tous les prêts précédents  se sont  bien dénoués. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 50 colis de condiments, 100 paires de chaussures et 10 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et  à Bamako (la capitale du Mali ) Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Médine, dans les quartiers  ou de façon ambulante  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée dans l’éducation et  la santé des enfants et l’autre partie sera utilisée pour rembourser le prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Badegnajuru  ambitionnent devenir des grossistes  et  aider leur mari à construire une maison.
texts.en:
The group of Badegnajuru is composed of five women (all married); on average, they are 37 years old with 4 children per woman. They mostly live in monogamous families in the neighborhood of Babemba, one of the neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso (3rd Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali).

They run diverse businesses, which sell, amongst other things, condiments, shoes, firewood etc.

With the aim of increasing their clientele and their profits, they are working with the micro-finance group Soro Yiriwaso. This is their sixth loan; all previous loans have been properly repaid.

With this new loan, they intend to buy 50 packages of condiments, 100 pairs of shoes and 10 cartloads of firewood. They will supply themselves from the large market in the city of Sikasso and in Bamako (the capital of Mali). They will sell their merchandise in the market of Médine, in the neighborhoods or walking around, to a clientele composed mostly of men and women. They will sell their goods mostly for cash.

They anticipate each earning a profit of 18,000 FCFA, which they will use partly to for education and the health of their children and the other part will be used to repay the loan.

The goal of the women of Group Badenajuru ambition is to become wholesales and to help their husbands build a house.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of items for their business.

loans.name: Loh's Group

texts.en: This small loan is for only two borrowers. Its leader, Mr. Loh S., 38 years old, is a motorbike taxi driver. He uses his old motor to pick up his customers who need to go anywhere around his community. He is married with five teenage children; two of them are employed as security guards for an industry and provide income to meet their family’s expense, while his wife works sewing clothing to earn a living. Loh S. cannot attract as many clients as before because his motor breaks down frequently, so he hopes to replace this old one by using the Kiva loan to purchase a new one. One other borrower, Mrs. Meur P., is applying for a loan to use as additional capital in her fish-selling business.

loans.use: To replace an old motor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase materials for making clothes.

loans.name: Kaïra Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kaïra est composé de quatre femmes mariées vivant majoritairement dans des familles polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et  ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans le quartier Babemba, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  (3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali.) 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente des pagnes wax, d’habits  pour enfants et  des condiments alimentaires.
Dans le but  d’augmenter la clientèle et leur chiffre d’affaire, elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur sixième  prêt solidaire, tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 30 colis de  pagnes wax, 10 colis d’habits  pour enfants et 40 cartons de condiments alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Médine, dans les quartiers sur place ou de façon ambulante  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée dans l’éducation et  la santé des enfants et l’autre partie sera utilisée  pour rembourser le prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Kaïra ambitionnent devenir des grossistes  et d’entreprendre des voyages entre le Mali et les pays frontaliers.
texts.en:
The Group Kaïra is composed of four married women who mostly live in polygamous families; on average, they are 35 years old with 3 children per woman. They live in the neighborhood of Babemba, one of the neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso (3rd Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali).

They run diverse businesses, selling “pagnes” (brightly printed cloth), childrens clothes and condiments, amongst others.

With the goal of increasing their clientele and their business, they are working with the microfinance group Soro Yiriwaso and this will be their sixth loan. All of their previous loans were properly repaid.

With this new loan, they intend to buy 30 sets of wax “pagnes”, 10 sets of children’s clothes and 40 packages of condiments. They will supply themselves at the large market in the city of Sikasso. They will carry out their own sales in the market of Médine, in the neighborhoods, or door-to-door. They sell to a clientele composed of men and women, mostly in cash.

They anticipate each earning a monthly profit of 12,000 FCFA, which they will use partly for the education and health of their children and the other part will be used to repay the loan.

The ambition of the women of Group Kaïra is to become wholesalers and to take trips throughout Mali and bordering countries.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of items for their business.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 57-year-old Joyce T. from Mwanza. She is married with five children between the ages of 19 and 26 years old. Joyce has been running a clothes business since 2006. She sells clothes to different customers. She works at the business for 8 hours per day, 6 days per week. Joyce currently earns about 250USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Joyce thanks you for her support!
ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Margarida Jaime

texts.pt:
Margarida Jaime A. tem 41 anos de idade, nasceu na cidade de Maputo, casada e mãe de uma filha de 12 anos de idade e freqüenta escola. 
Margarida estudou ate sete classe e interrompeu devido a problemas de saúde.
Vive na cidade da Matola com seu marido e mais uma irmã que esta sob sua responsabilidade.

Saiu da cidade de Maputo no ano de 1986 com sua família (marido, filha e sua irmã).
Começou a fazer negocio no ano de 2000, é dona do negocio e ainda não tem empregado. Vende mais iogurte que compra em quantidades maiores e tem bastante aceitação no mercado.
Rende 10.000,00MT mensalmente com os quais consegue alimentar a família e poupar algum dinheiro par os momentos de crise.

Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo com a Hluvuku-Adsema e já teve outros num banco comercial concorrente na praça.
Margarida conheceu a Hluvuku-Adsema através de informações obtidas com suas colegas na zona.

Com o valor de 20.000,00mt pretende reforçar o volume do negocio e responder a demanda.
Espera pagar o credito de acordo com o plano de amortização para no futuro mais breve aceder a novos empréstimos com o mesmo fim.
texts.en:
Margarida Jaime A. is 41 years old. She was born in the city of Maputo. She is married and has a 12-year-old daughter who is in school. Margarida went to school through seventh grade, and dropped out because of health problems. She lives in the city of Matola with her husband and a sister for whom she is economically responsible. She left Maputo in 1986 with her family (husband, daughter, and sister). She started her business in 2000. She owns the business but still doesn't have an employee. She sells yogurt, which she buys in large quantities, and she has made inroads in the market. She earns 10,000 meticals a month, which she uses to feed her family and save some money for emergencies. This is her first loan from Hluvuku-Adsema, and she's received other loans from a commercial bank near the plaza. Margarida heard about Hluvuku-Adsema through information provided by colleagues in the area. She will use this loan of 20,000 meticals to expand her stock and increase her sales volume, and to respond to demand. She intends to pay off the loan in keeping with the payment plan, so in the near future she can request other loans to be used for the same purpose.

Translated from Portuguese by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase stock in her shop

loans.name: Bello

texts.en: O. is 44 years old and married with five children. She lives in Lagos State Nigeria. She is into laundry services and has been selling drinks for over 20 years. O. has been with LAPO Microfinance for one year. She is requesting a loan of N150,000 to purchase more drinks and a laundry machine. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a laundry machine & drinks

loans.name: Sao's Group

texts.en: This small loan is being requested by two borrowers. Its leader, Mr. Sao P., 49, has a job driving a motorcycle taxi for a profit. He is married with four children: two are married and have ready started new family homes, while the others are employed as garment workers. His wife is a fresh fish seller. Sao P. will be using this loan to improve his wife’s investment by buying additional fish to sell. The other borrower is Mrs. Heng N., 29, who works in the garment industry, and is asking for a loan to buy a motorbike for riding to work.

loans.use: To buy additional fish to sell

loans.name: Sayi

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Sayi S. from Mwanza.  She is married with three children between the ages of 3 and 16 years old. Sayi has been running a pharmacy business since 2007. Her business is to sell human medicine for treatment. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Sayi currently earns about 260USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase medicine in bulk. In the future, she plans to improve her business. Sayi thanks you for your support!

ABUOT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase medicine in bulk.

loans.name: Cufamune Gracieta

texts.pt:
Cufamune Gracieta F. nasceu em Bilene Macia (um dos distritos da província de Gaza que se localiza a 230 km a norte de Maputo) é uma mulher bastante trabalhadora, tem 62 anos de idade, viúva e avo de três netos com idades de 12 e 15 anos, todos estudando e sob sua responsabilidade.

 Cufamune estudou ate 4 classe e tendo parado por questões políticas na altura do colonialismo Português no pais.

Saiu da Macia no ano de 1966, sozinha, para boane aonde mais tarde veio a casar com o já falecido marido e vive na casa própria.

É comerciante há bastante tempo e vende, pessoalmente, roupas de segunda mão. Aprendeu a fazer negócios há 23 anos e o produto com mais saída é o fato completo para homens e que o custo por unidade é de 1.800,00MT. Adquire a mercadoria na cidade de Maputo a custos razoáveis. Com os rendimentos consegue custei ar as despesa familiares, incluindo a sua irmã que vive longe dela.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos e este é o seu segundo credito com a Hluvuku-Adsema, no valor de 25.000,00MT que pretende reforçar o volume do negocio e satisfazer a demanda de produtos neste momento de inverno.
O primeiro credito foi de 15.000,00MT para exercer a mesma actividade. Teve informações sobre as operações da hluvuku através de amigas e residentes no distrito de boane.
Propõe se a pagar em harmonia com o plano de prestações e pedir novos empréstimos para vender os produtos a grosso.
texts.en:
Cufamune Gracieta F. was born in Bilene Macia (one of districts in Gaza province located 230 km north of Maputo). She is a hardworking woman, 62 years old, a widow with three grandchilren between the ages of 12 and 15. All of them are in school, and she is their guardian. Cufamune went to school until 4th grade, when she had to stop because of political turmoil during Portuguese colonial rule of the country. She left Macia in 1966, going by herself to Boane, where she later married her late husband. She lives in her own house. She's been a shopkeeper for some time and sells secondhand clothing. She learned business 23 years ago and the most popular products are men's suits, which she sells for 1800 meticals each. She acquires her goods in the city of Maputo at affordable prices. She uses her earnings to cover family expenses, including supporting her sister, who lives far away. She's never received loans from other banks, and this is her second loan with Hluvuku-Adsema, in the amount of 25,000 meticals. She intends to use the loan to increase her sales and satisfy the demand for products during this winter season. She used her first loan of 15,000 meticals for the same purpose. She learned about Hluvuku through friends and residents of Boane. She intends to pay off her loan in full and on time, and to request new loans so she can begin selling products wholesale.

Translated from Portuguese by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase stock in her shop

loans.name: Anica

texts.pt:
Anica M. nasceu na cidade de Pemba (na província do norte do pais que faz fronteira com Tanzânia), mulher de 32 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 4 filhos com idades compreendidas entre 10 e 23 anos. Vive com o marido na casa própria e tem o nível médio concluído.

Saiu de Pemba no ano de 1986 com a sua primeira filha a maputo onde viveu e dois anos depois saiu para outra província a norte do Mpauto (inhambane) e tendo regressado a Boane no ano de 1990, juntamente com o seu marido.
Trabalha como secretaria do Instituto Pedagógico de Umbelauzi de Boane a mais de 19 anos onde recebe 4.600,00MT, valor que lhe ajuda a suportar os encargos familiares e pagamento do credito de Habitação.

Anica, nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos e este é o seu quarto credito no valor de 25.000,00MT que pretende usar na aquisição de material de construção da sua casa. Obteve informações sobre a Hluvuku-Adsema através de amigos e colegas do serviço.

Primeiramente levantou 17.000,00mt; 20.000,00; e 40.000,00mt para aplicar na compra de material de construção.

Propõe se a pagar o credito em de acordo com o plano de prestações para no futuro aceder a mais empréstimos comm o plano de terminar a construção da casa.
texts.en:
Anica M. was born in the city of Pemba, in a northern province that borders Tanzania. She is 32 years old, married, and has 4 children between the ages of 10 and 23. She lives with her husband in their own house and finished high school. She left Pemba for Maputo in 1986 with her eldest daughter, and lived there two years. She went to another province north of Maputo (Inhambane), and then returned to Boane in 1990 with her husband. She has worked as a secretary in Boane's Instituto Pedagógico de Umbelauzi for more than 18 years and earns 4600 meticals, which help her support her family and pay off her loans. Anica has never received loans from other banks, and this is her fourth loan, in the amount of 25,000 meticals, which she will use to purchase construction materials for her house. She learned about Hluvuku-Adsema through friends and colleagues. Her previous loans were for 17,000, 20,000, and 40,000 meticals and were also used to buy contrsutction materials. She intends to pay off this loan in full and on time so that she can apply for further loans and finish building her house.

Translated from Portuguese by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Adeyemi

texts.en: M. is a single lady of 26 years. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria where she sells provisions, shoes, ladies bags, cosmetics and drinks.  She has been in this business for the past nine years. M. has been in LAPO Microfinance for three years.  She is requesting a loan of N150,000 to purchase more provisions, ladies bags, shoes and cosmetics to enable her to meet her customer's demands. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, shoes, cosmetics and drinks to sell

loans.name: Inacio Dinis

texts.pt:
Inacio Dinis C. tem 44 anos de idade, natural de Maputo, masculino casado e pai de 3 filhos com idades compreendidos entre 12 e 19 anos, todos são estudantes.
Inácio estudou ate 8 classe.

Nunca mudou de local de residência, nasceu e vive em maputo com sua família.
É mecânico profissional e funcionário do estado afecto no Comando Distrital da Policia de Moçambique em boane há 29 anos. Recebe como salário mensal, 2.957,00MT que usa para sustente ar a sua família e amortizar o empréstimo.

Vive na casa própria no bairro Ndlavela (aredores da cidade de maputo).
Este o seu terceiro empréstimo com a Hluvuku-Adsema no valor de 12.000,00MT pretende comprar material de construção para aplicar na casa que esta fazendo em fases.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, obteve informações sobre a hluvuku a traves de amigos.

Primeiramente levantou 10.000,00MT; 10.300,00MT que também aplicou na mesma actividade.
Propõe se a pagar sem problemas e pretende aceder a mais empréstimos para terminar a obra e depois mobiliar
texts.en:
Inacio Dinis C. is 44 years old, natural of Maputo, married father of 3 children between the ages of 12 and 19, they are all students. Inácio studied until the 8th grade. He's never moved out of Maputo, where he was born and lives with his family. He is a professional mechanic and has been a civil servant of the District Police of Mozambique in Boane for 29 years. His monthly wages are 2.957,00 MT and he uses his income to support his family and pay for his loan. He lives in his own house in the Ndlavela neighborhood (outside the city of Maputo). This is his third loan with Hluvuku-Adsema, in the value of 12.000,00MT of which he intends to use to buy building supplies to continue building his house. He has never had loans from other banks and he learned about Hluvuku through his friends. At first, he borrowed 10.000,00MT and then 10.300,00MT which he also used for the same purpose. He proposes to pay for his loan without problems and intends to apply for more loans in the future in order to continue this project and also furnish his house afterward .

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Hungria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build his house

loans.name: Ivona

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36 year old Ivona P. from Mwanza. She is widowed with four children between the ages of 3 and 20 years old. Ivona has been running a clothes business since 1999. Her business is to make clothes and bed sheets and sell them to clients.

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Ivona currently earns about 165 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase cloth and a sewing machine. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Ivona thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cloth and sewing machine.

loans.name: Kazeem

texts.en:
D. is 30 years old and married with 2 children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells hair extensions and recharge cards; she has been in the business for 10 years. She has been with LAPO Microfinance for 3 years.

D. is requesting the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more hair extensions, recharge cards and hair cream. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions, hair cream and rechargable cards

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30 year old Sophia M. from Mwanza. She is married with two children between the ages of 1 and 7 years old. Sophia has been running a hardware business since 2008. Her business is to sell building construction materials such as nails. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week.

Sophia currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more building construction materials. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Sophia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future

loans.use: To purchase more building construction materials.

loans.name: Anar Gul

texts.en:
The man who is pictured is Anar Gul, the son of A.. He lives in Bagrami, Kabul Afghanistan. He is married and has four children. He is a farmer and an educated man as well. He is involved in this business since 1999, so he has the experience of 10 years in farming. He likes to work hard and earn money to bring changes in both business and life.

Anar Gul wants to take an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani to buy more seeds and the required tools for farming.

Finally, he would like to state that Kiva is a best process that supports the entrepreneurs.

loans.use: For buying more seeds and tools.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 26 year old Leticia N. from Mwanza. She is married with three children between the ages of 3 and 6 years old. Leticia has been running a tailoring business since 2008. Her business is to make womens clothes. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week.

Leticia currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase materials and a sewing machine. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Leticia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase materials and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Fanta

texts.fr:
Madame Fanta C.  est âgée de 48 ans et vit avec ses 7 enfants et son époux dans le quartier Darsalam, dans une famille monogame, dans la ville de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école en classe de 6ème (système scolaire Malien) elle commença le petit commerce de jus auprès de sa mère qui avait un réfrigérateur. Après plusieurs années dans ce commerce, elle a maîtrisé les rouages du commerce. Ayant vite compris que les femmes aiment les produits cosmétiques, elle s’est engagée dans cette activité au tout début en faisant le marchandage ambulant de marché en marché. Avec une dizaine année d’activité, elle a ouvert sa boutique  située une artère  très facile d’accès. Très sollicitée et appréciée par les femmes pour sa connaissance des produits et ses conseils dans le choix des articles, Fanta est d’une notoriété très enviable à Ségou.
Dans le souci d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire, elle fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation  depuis  54 mois. Après  4 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels tous correctement remboursés, elle est à son 3 ème prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 5 cartons de mèches pour les cheveux, 3 cartons de parfums et 2 cartons de cosmétique (skin light) en république  du Sénégal et effectue sa vente toujours au comptant à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes.
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 45.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour prendre en charge certaines dépenses de la famille. 
Son ambition est  d’avoir une maison.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fanta C. is 48 years old and lives with her 7 children and her husband in a monogamous family, in the neighborhood of Darsalam in the city of Ségou (4th Administrative Region of Mali).

She left school in the 6th grade (Malian school system) and started a small business selling juice with her mother, who had a refrigerator. After many years in that business, she mastered the ways of business. Understanding that women love cosmetics, she started this business by selling in the market. After ten years of this activity, she opened a shop in a main thoroughfare which is easy to access. She is very popular and appreciated by the women for her knowledge of the products and advises them about the items they choose; Fanta is wonderfully well-known in Ségou. With the intent of increasing her business, she is working with Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she has worked for the past 54 months. After 4 group loans and 2 individual loans which were all properly repaid, she is on her third individual loan. She will use this loan to buy 5 boxes of hair extensions, 3 boxes of perfumes and 2 boxes of cosmetics in the Republic of Senegal and will sell them for cash to a mostly female clientele. She hopes to earn a monthly profit of 45,000 FCFA, which she will use to pay for some family expenses. Her goal is to have a house.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of items for her business.

loans.name: Zahiriddin

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Захириддин Рахматуллаев - молодой человек 1973 года рождения, женат, имеет двоих детей. Занимается купля - продажей и откормом скота. Он покупает у пастухов молодых бычков и, откормив их 3 - 4  месяца, продаёт их на скотных рынках Джаббор - Расуловского района .   Таким образом, он зарабатывает деньги для своей семьи . Кроме того, он занимается производством сырых кирпичей на заказ у себя дома. Ему в этом помогают его младшие братья. Он рад сотрудничеству с нашей организацией и благодарит наших партнеров по КИВА.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. Zahiriddin R. is a young man born in 1973. He is married and has two children. He buys and sells and growth feeds cattle. He buys young calves from shepherds and after feeding them for three to four months resells them on the cattle markets of the Jabbar Rasulov region. This way he makes money for his family. Besides that he also takes orders to make raw bricks at his home. His younger brothers help him in this business. He is happy to be working with our organization and is thanking our partners at Kiva.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Madina

texts.fr:
Madame  Madina D. est âgée de 42 ans,  mariée et mère de 6 enfants, elle habite  dans un foyer monogame avec  son mari  et leurs enfants  dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou (4ème  région  administrative de la république du Mali). 
 Madina abandonne très tôt l’école depuis la  classe de 7ème année fondamentale (système scolaire Malien) au profit de la tresse. En plus de la tresse, elle  s’initia  également au  commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait du riz et du bois de chauffe. Avec son mariage à un mari qui possède un magasin de friperie, elle opta pour l’exercice de cette activité commerciale depuis maintenant une dizaine d’année au grand marché de Ségou et jouit d’une grande réputation.
Dans le but d’augmenter le volume de son activité, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 4 ans. Après avoir bien remboursés 4 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels; elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt  pour acheter, 5 balles de friperies au grand marché de Ségou auprès des grossistes et effectuent sa vente en détail et généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes sur place au grand marché de Ségou et à domicile à Hamdallaye.
Madame Madina D. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour prendre en charge certaines charges familiales, rembourser les intérêts du prêt  et faire un peu d’épargne. 
Son ambition est de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Madam Madina D., age 42, is married and the mother of 6 children. She lives in a monogamous home with her husband and their children in the Hamdallaye neighborhood of Ségou city (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Madina dropped out very early from school in the 7th basic year( Malian educational system) in favor of braiding. Besides braiding, she also learnt a business from her mother who sold rice and fire wood. Having married, her husband owns a second-hand clothes shop and she opted to practice this business about 12 years ago in the big market of Ségou where she enjoys a huge reputation. With the aim to increase the volume of her business, she turned to Soro Yiriwaso. She‘s been in contact with Soro Yiriwaso since 4 years. After having repaid correctly 4 group loans and 2 individual loans, she is on her 3rd individual loan. She intends to use this loan to buy 5 bails of second hand clothes from wholesalers in the big Ségou market and sells by retail and usually cash sale to her customers made of men and women in the premise of the big Ségou market and to households in Hamdallaye. Madam Madina D. intends to make a monthly profit of 50.000FCFA which will be used to take care of some family needs, to repay the interest of the loan and to make a bit of saving. Her ambition is to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bails of second hand clothes

loans.name: Anitha

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 27 year old Anitha R. from Mwanza. She is married with one child the age of one year old. Anitha has been running a poultry business since 2007. Her business is a Poultry/kuku business. Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients.

Kuku means "chickens" in Swahili and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein.

She works at the business for 8 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Anitha currently earns about 220 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more chickens. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Anitha thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens.

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou  Konaté est âgée de 45 ans, mère de 5 enfants, elle vit dans une famille monogame avec ses enfants et son époux dans le  quartier Sébénikoro -Pélengana de Ségou (4ème  région administrative de la république  du Mali). 
Ayant abandonnée l’école  en classe de 9ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour se marier, Oumou Konaté a appris le commerce de pâte d’arachide auprès de sa mère depuis son jeune âge et jouit aujourd’hui d’une très grande notoriété pour la propriété  et la qualité de sa pâte d’arachide surtout du côté des femmes fonctionnaires de Ségou. 
Pour avoir  de la pâte d’arachide, on procède au lavage des grains pour enlever l’ivraie (mauvaises graines) des bonnes graines puis les opérations suivantes se succèdent : séchage, triage, grillade, épluchure et broyage au moulin. La pâte ainsi obtenue est mise dans des seaux en plastique avec couvercles pour la vente.
Dans le but d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, elle a fait recours à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 42 mois, après avoir bien remboursés 3 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel.
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 5 sacs de graines d’arachide et 32 seaux en plastique. Elle s’approvisionne en ces matières premières au marché de Pélengana. La pâte d’arachide est vendue dans des seaux, à crédit payable mensuellement et au comptant majoritairement  aux femmes en ambulant et à domicile.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 37.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et prendre en charge certaines charges familiales (savon et compléments du prix des condiments).
texts.en:
Madam Oumou Konaté, aged 45, and the mother of 5 children lives in a monogamous family with her children and husband in the Sébénkoro-Pélengana neighborhood of Ségou( Fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having dropped out from school in the 9th basic year (Malian education system) to marry, she learnt to make groundnut paste as a business from her mother, at a tender age and enjoys today a huge reputation for her business and the quality of her groundnut paste especially from women civil servants from Ségou. To make groundnut paste, wash the grains first to remove the chaff (bad grains) from the good grains and the following processes come one after the other; drying, sorting, frying (without oil), removing the skin and grinding at the mill. The paste is thus collected and put in plastic buckets with lids for sale. With the goal of increasing her funds for this business, she turned to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She has been with this institution 42 months ago, and after having repaid correctly 3 group loans and 2 individual loans, she is on her 3rd individual loan. This new loan will be used to buy 5 bags of groundnuts and 32 plastic buckets. She gets her basic supplies at the Pélengana marketplace. The groundnut paste is sold in buckets on credit to be paid monthly and mainly on cash to women who sell from door -to- door and in their homes. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 37,000 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan and to pay for certain family expenses (soap and seasoning).

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of groundnuts and plastic buckets

loans.name: Wahidou

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Wahidou Traoré est âgé de 24 ans et vit dans une famille traditionnelle élargie avec ses 2 enfants et son épouse dans le quartier Secoura  de Ségou (4ème  région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Wahidou n’a pas fréquenté l’école et très tôt il commença les activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce auprès de son cousin qui tenait une boutique de pièces détachées. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage auprès de ce dernier, il jouit d’une grande expérience car il maîtrise à fond le commerce de détail. Alors  Wahidou opta pour le commerce d’articles divers de boutique depuis 3 ans. Sa boutique située aux abords d’une route nationale qui est très facile d’accès. Ses articles sont bien disposés sur des étagères attirant la clientèle. Il jouit d’une grande clientèle car il est le seul qui possède une boutique où on peut trouver beaucoup de marchandises sans avoir besoin du grand marché.
C’est dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle en augmentant le volume de son activité, qu’il a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est à son 1er prêt individuel.
 Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 5 sacs de sucre, 4 cartons de thé et 1 carton de pâtes alimentaires sur place à Ségou auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Avec ce prêt il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA, qui lui servira de fonds de roulement et de mener autres activités génératrices de revenus comme l’embouche bovine et ovine.
Son ambition est d’ouvrir une 2ème boutique dans la ville de Ségou.
texts.en:
Mr. Wahidou Traoré is 24 years old and lives in an extended traditional family, with his two children and his wife, in the Secoura neighborhood in Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Wahidou never attended school, and started working to earn an income at an early age, notably with his cousin who used to run a spare parts store. After several years of learning with him, he now has a good experience and masters retailing. Three years ago, Wahidou started selling various items. His store is located next to a national road and is easy to get to. His items are well presented on stalls, and attract customers. He has a large clientele, since he's the only one who has a store where many items can be found without having to travel to the grand market.

Eager to meet customer demand by expanding his business, he's seeking his first loan from Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan, he intends to buy from wholesalers in Ségou : 5 sacks of sugar, 4 boxes of tea, and 1 box of pasta. He resells for cash and on credit to a clientele comprising both men and women. With this loan, he hopes to turn a monthly profit of XOF 150'000 (ca US$ 320), to be used as working capital for other money-making activities, such as raising cattle and sheep. He ambitions to open a second store in Ségou.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 sacks of sugar, 4 boxes of tea, and 1 box of pasta

loans.name: Mamoutou

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Mamoutou   K. est âgé de 38 ans et vit avec ses 2 enfants, son épouse et d’autres ménages chez son oncle dans une famille traditionnelle élargie dans le quartier Médine de la ville de Ségou (4ème  région administrative de la république  du Mali). 
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école pour des raisons religieuses, il commença très tôt le commerce auprès de son grand frère qui vendait des pièces détachées au grand marché de la ville de Ségou. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage  auprès de ce dernier, il acquiert une solide expérience dans  le commerce de pièces pour moto. C’est ainsi qu’il  décida d’évoluer seul  dans ce créneau  il y a de cela  8 ans au marché  du quartier Médine de Ségou. Sa boutique située en plein centre du marché, est facile d’accès. Mamoutou est d’un commerce très agréable et sollicité de beaucoup de réparateurs et propriétaires de moto.  
Dans le but satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, il  fait recours à l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son 1er prêt individuel.
Il  compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 1 carton de cylindres, 30 pneus et 2 cartons de bougies pour moto sur place à Ségou auprès des grossistes. Mamoutou K. vend au comptant, en détail et à crédit payable mensuellement à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Avec ce prêt il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA, qui  sera réinjecté dans ses activités et  aider la famille élargie dans la prise en charge des dépenses (nourriture, habillements, santé, éducation).
Son ambition est d’avoir un chez soi (une maison à usage d’habitation)
texts.en:
Mr Mamoutou K. is 38 years old, and lives with his two children and his wife, together with other households, at his uncle's, in an extended traditional family in the Médine neighborhood in the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Having never attended school for religious reasons, he started working early on with his older brother, who used to sell spare parts at the grand market in Ségou. After several years of learning with him, he acquired a strong experience as a motorcycle spare parts reseller. This is why, eight years ago, he decided to go his separate way in this field in the Médine neighborhood in Ségou. His store is located at the market center, and is easy to get to. Mamoutou is kind, and many motorcycle repairmen and owners work with him.

In order to meet the demand of his steeply increasing clientele, he's seeking his first loan from Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso. He intends to use it to buy 1 box of cylinders, 30 tires, and 2 boxes of motorcycle spark plugs from wholesalers in Ségou. Mamoutou K. retails for cash and on one-month credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women.

With this loan, he hopes to turn a monthly profit of XOF 100'000 (ca US$ 215), that will in part be reinvested in his business, and in part used to provide for the daily expenses of his extended family (food, clothes, heath care, and education). He ambitions to have his own house.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 1 box of cylinders, 30 tires, and 2 boxes of motorcycle spark plugs

loans.name: Djeneba

texts.fr:
Djeneba C. est une  célibataire âgée  de 46 ans et mère d’un enfant qui vit  avec ses nièces et son enfant dans le quartier Médine de la ville de Ségou (4ème  région de la république du Mali) 
Contrôleur de douane de formation, elle a commencé le commerce en classe de 8ème (système éducatif Malien) avec la  vente des jus de fruits. En plus des jus de fruits, elle  vend  des sandwiches, des brochettes de viande de bœufs et des boissons gazeuses. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation dans la fabrication de jus et les femmes viennent chez elle pour apprendre les recettes.
Pour faire un cocktail de jus de fruits de 60 000 unités par exemple, elle a besoin de 100 kg d’orange, 20 kg d’ananas et 10 kg de mandarine. Ces fruits pressés à l’aide d’une machine à presser  et le jus obtenu  est mélangé dans 17 kg de sucre avec les arômes et essences, avant d’être mis dans les emballages et mis au frais.
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour développer   son activité, elle fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son 1er prêt individuel.
Elle compte l’utiliser pour acheter, 4 sacs de sucre, 1 sac de lait et 4 cartons d’aromes pour jus. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières sur place à Ségou.  Djeneba C. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui lui permettra de payer son loyer,  d’aider sa famille  et de payer son personnel.
Son ambition est d’abord de  se construire une maison.
texts.en:
Djeneba C., age 46, is unmarried and the mother of one child. She lives with her nieces and her child in the Médine neighborhood in the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). A trained customs controller, she started her business during 8th grade, selling fruit juice. In addition, she also sells sandwiches, beef brochettes, and soft drinks. Her reputation is this field is very high, and women come to her to learn recipes.

To make a fruit juice cocktail of 60'000 units for instance, she needs 100 kg of orange, 20 kg of pineapple, and 10 kg of mandarine. The fruits are processed with a squeezer, and the resulting juice is mixed with 17 kg of sugar, aromas and essences, before being conditioned and put in the fridge.

Eager to bolster her working capital in order to develop her business, she's seeking her first loan from Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso. She intends to use it to buy 4 sacks of sugar, 1 sack of milk, and 4 packs of juice aroma. She gets her raw materials in Ségou, and sells for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women. She hopes to turn a monthly profit of XOF 150'000 (ca US$ 325), to be used to pay the rent, to help her family, and to pay her employees. Her ambition is firstly to build herself a house.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 4 sacks of sugar, 1 sack of milk, and 4 packs of juice aromas

loans.name: Ajami

texts.en:
A., 27 years old, lives in Bint Jbeil. He has been working as a stone carving for four years. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools and electrical wires for his work. This is the first time that A. has requested a loan. 

A. is recognized for his work because of his experience and quality craftsmanship. His clients are people from his region. Initially he didn’t have the startup capital to begin his business, but he decided to pursue it because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business into a new region.

loans.use: to purchase tools and electrical wires

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali, 42 years old, lives in Bint Jbeil, Southern Lebanon, with his wife and three children. Ali has owned a grocery store for seven years. He is requesting a second loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. 

His previous loans, that were repaid successfully, helped him improve his store by diversifying his merchandise. Ali has a prime business position with his store being located on the main street. His clients are his friends, neighbors and passerbys. When he started his business he rented the place; now he owns it. Ali decided to pursue his business because of his experience in trading. In the future, he plans on expanding his business and open a restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store

loans.name: Bassima

texts.en:
Bassima is 39 years old and lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon with her husband and their six children. Bassima has owned livestock to produce milk and cheese. She is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to increase her livestock. This is her second loan request after having successfully repaid her previous loans.
 
Bassima is recognized for her experience in dealing with her livestock. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and tourists. When she began her business, she faced stiff competition, however, she pursued it because of the high demand in her region. In the future, she plans on expanding her livestock.

loans.use: To increase her livestock.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi de l’association Tièssiri II est un regroupement de six femmes, mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames, elles ont en moyenne 45 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou (4ème  Région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ce groupe de femmes  fait essentiellement  le commerce d’articles divers tels, les  pagnes wax, les  calebasses, les condiments alimentaires, les  céréales etc. Elles sont très sollicitées et appréciées pour la qualité de leurs marchandises. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elles sont à leur 1ier prêt solidaire.
 Ce  prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 10 pièces de pagnes wax, 6 colis de calebasses, 2 corbeilles de tomates et de piments, un sac de mil et 300 kg de tamarin. Elles se ravitaillent en calebasses à Tonan, en pagnes wax et en condiments à Bamako, en mil et en tamarin dans les foires de Djonforo et Sirakorobougou. Elles revendent toutes leurs marchandises en détail au comptant et à crédit à domicile, au marché château de Ségou et en ambulant dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 29.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et la prise en charge des frais de santé des enfants.
Elles ont pour ambition de devenir des grossistes.
texts.en:
This Benkadi group, part of the Tièssiri II Association, unites 6 married women, mostly from polygamous families. Their average age is 45 and they have 3 children, on average. They all live in the Hamdallaye neighborhood of the town of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

This group of women mostly sell various items such as "wax"-brand "pagnes" (lengths of high quality African print cloth), gourds, condiments, cereals, etc. They are much in demand and the quality of their merchandise is greatly appreciated.

Wishing to increase their working capital, they decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their first solidarity loan. This loan will be used to buy 10 lengths of "pagne-wax", 6 packages of gourds, 2 baskets of tomatoes and hot peppers, 1 sack of millet and 300 kg of tamarinds. They buy their gourds in Tonan, their "pagnes" and condiments in Bamako, the millet and tamarinds at the weekly markets of Djonforo and Sirakorobougou.

They sell all their merchandise retail, for cash and credit, out of their homes, at the "château" market in Ségou, and walking through the residential neighborhoods, to a clientele composed of men, women, and children. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 29,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the loan and to pay health-related expenses for their children.

Their ambition is to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items for re-sale

loans.name: Fariza

texts.en:
Fariza is a 45 year old woman who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Fariza owns a clothing and accessory shop for children. She also works from her home as a sewer. Fariza is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop. This is her third loan request after having paid back her previous loans on time.  

Fariza is uniquely placed because she sells a large variety of products. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and tourists. When she first started, she didn’t have a lot of cash and wasn’t able to meet her clients demands. Fariza decided to pursue her business because she has experience in sales and likes working with children. In the future, she plans on expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan, 20 years old, lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Hassan has been working as a hairdresser for five years. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase beauty products for his work. This is his second loan request after having successfully repaid his previous loan.

Hassan is recognized for his work because of his skill and talent. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Hassan started his business, he had financial difficulties. However, he decided to pursue his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products

loans.name: Saleh

texts.en:
Saleh is 22 years old and lives with his wife in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Saleh has been working as a car electrician for five years. He is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase car batteries and tools for his work. This is the first time that Saleh has requested a loan.

Saleh is successful in his work because he does it well and charges competitive prices. His clients are his friends, neighbors and tourists. When he first started his business, he had financial issues. Saleh set up as a car electrician because he wanted to have independent and stable work. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase car batteries and tools for his work

loans.name: Samer

texts.en:
Samer is 26 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Samer has owned a barber's shop for seven years. He is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase sinks and a new chair for his shop. This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time.

Samer is successful because he is known for his good and talented work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Samer first started his business, he had financial issues. He set up as a barber because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase sinks and a new chair for his shop

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en:
Youssef is 46 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Youssef has worked as a mason for 20 years. He is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase tools for his work. This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time.

Youssef's previous loans helped him improve his business as well as his financial situation. Youssef is successful in his work because he does it well. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have experience, which made it difficult to build a network of clients. He also had to learn new masonry techniques in order to face the competition. Youssef set up as a mason because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabali est composé de six femmes (dont une célibataire et cinq mariées) vivant en majorité dans des familles polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans,  3 enfants et habitent dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de  Ségou (4ème  Région administrative de la république  du Mali).
Les femmes du groupe font de l’achat et de la vente des condiments alimentaires et  divers articles ménagers  tels les calebasses etc. 
 Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire.
Ce prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter,  20 colis de calebasses  et  4  corbeilles de condiments (l’ails, poivres, tomates fraîches etc.) Elles se ravitaillent en calebasses à Tonan et  en condiments alimentaires essentiellement à Bamako (capitale du Mali). Les calebasses sont revendues au marché château de Ségou, à domicile, dans les foires de Dougabougou, Siribala et Macina, quant aux condiments alimentaires, ils sont revendus au marché château de Ségou à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et subvenir aux dépenses familiales (savon et de l’habillement pour les enfants). 
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leurs activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
The Sabali group is composed of six women (one unmarried and five married), predominantly living in polygamous families. They average 35 years of age and 3 children, and live in the Hamdallaye neighborhood in the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women buy and resell food condiments, as well as various household items such as "calebasses" (containers made out of hollowed out and dried calabashes).

Eager to increase their working capital, they decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are seeking their first solidarity loan (group loan). This loan will be used to buy 20 packages of calebasses and 4 baskets of condiments (garlic, peppers, fresh tomatoes, etc). They get their supplies in Tonan for the calebasses, and mostly in Bamako (capital of Mali) for the condiments. Calebasses are resold at the Château market in Ségou, at home, and at fairs in Dougabougou, Siribala and Macina. Condiments are resold at the Château market in Ségou, to a clientele comprising mainly women.

The women count on turning an average monthly profit of XOF 30'000 (ca US$ 65), to be used to repay the loan and to provide for the family expenses (soap and clothes for the children). They ambition to diversify their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 20 packages of "calebasses" and 4 baskets of condiments (garlic, peppers, fresh tomatoes, etc)

loans.name: Alimata

texts.fr:
Madame  Alimata  B.  est âgée de 47 ans et vit avec ses  7  enfants et son mari dans une famille traditionnelle avec plusieurs autres ménages  dans le village de Zogofina de Ségou (4ème  région administrative du Mali). 
N’ayant pas été à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle fréquenta plutôt la medersa qu’elle abandonna en classe de 3ème  année (système scolaire du Mali). Elle a débuté le commerce tout seul en commençant par 4 kg de sucre et des thés. Très vite le commerce fleurit et elle devient aujourd’hui la seule détentrice d’une boutique de vente d’articles divers dans son village. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation et  d’une notoriété exemplaire. Sa boutique située chez elle est très facile d’accès. Ses articles disposés sur des étagères sont bien rangés. 
Pour augmenter son fonds de commerce et elle fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation depuis 30 mois. Après 5 prêts solidaires correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 1er prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 4 sacs de sucre, 3 sacs de sels de cuisine, 2 sacs de riz et 3 cartons de thé. Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises à Ségou et vend en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice de 45 000FCFA qui lui permettra d’acheter des bœufs et de faire l’embouche. 
Son ambition est de construire une maison.
texts.en:
Mrs. Alimata B. is 47 years old and lives with her 7 children and her husband in a traditional family with several other households in the village of Zogofina Ségou (4th Administrative Region of Mali). She did not attend school for societal reasons, she attended Madrasas but abandoned her studies while in 3rd grade class (school system of Mali). She started her business with only 4 kg of sugar and tea. Trade flourished very quickly and she became the sole proprietor of a shop selling various items in her village. She has a great and exemplary reputation. Her boutique is located in her home which facilitates easy access. The items she sells are neatly arranged and properly stored on shelves. She will use the loan funds, from Soro Yiriwaso with which she has had a relationship for 30 months, to increase her business. After 5 previous group loans that were fully reimbursed, this is her 1st individual loan, she intends to use the funds to buy 4 bags of sugar, 3 bags of cooking salt, 2 bags of rice and 3 boxes of tea. She buys and sells goods in Ségou, in cash and on credit to a clientele of men and women. With this loan, she plans to make a profit of 45,000F CFA which will allow her to buy and fatten cattle. Her ambition is to build a house.

Translated from French by Ryan Jones, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To Buy Diverse Articles.

loans.name: Zouhir

texts.en:
Zouhir is 40 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Bint Jbeil. Zouhir has been working as a stone carver for 15 years. He is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase a car for his work. This is the first time that Zouhir has requested a loan.

Zouhir is successful in his work because he does it well. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the start-up capital. Zouhir set up as a stone carver because he had experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business into a new region.

loans.use: To purchase a car for his work

loans.name: Bintou

texts.fr:
Madame   Bintou  Koussoubé est une veuve  de 43 ans et mère de 6 enfants. Elle  habite chez son feu mari dans une famille traditionnelle avec ses enfants et sa coépouse dans le quartier Pélengana Sébénikoro de la ville de Ségou (4ème  région administrative de la république  du Mali). 
Ayant abandonné l’école en classe de 6ème (système scolaire Malien) pour des raisons personnelles, elle commença le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après s’être intéressée à plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus, elle opta finalement pour le commerce d’habits depuis maintenant  2 ans, au marché château, en ambulant dans les différents quartiers et chez elle à la maison. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation dans ce commerce car ses habits sont des coupons de la CO.MA.TEX et  elle bénéficie d’une bonne clientèle car ses articles sont bons marchés presque à la portée de beaucoup de personnes.
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation  depuis 30 mois. Après 3 prêts solidaires et 1 prêt individuel tous correctement  remboursés, elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel. 
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 50 pièces de pagnes Fancy sur place à Ségou et effectue sa vente, en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Avec ce prêt  elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA qui va lui permettre de payer la scolarité de ses enfants vu que son mari n’est plus vie et également de rembourser ses dettes. 
Son ambition est d’être un import export  tel entre le Mali et le Burkina Faso.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bintou Koussoubé is a widow of 43, mother of 6 children. She lives in the home of her late husband, in a traditional family, with her children and her co-spouse, in the Pélengana Sébénikoro neighborhood of the town of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Having left school after the 6th grade (according to the school system of Mali) for personal reasons, she began in sales together with her mother, who sold condiments. After being interested in several money-earning ventures, she finally opted two years ago for selling clothing in the "château" market, as a door-to-door saleswoman, and out of her home. She has a good reputation in this business since the clothing she sells are lengths of cloth from CO.MA.TEX . She has a considerable clientele since these articles are so reasonably priced that many people can afford them.

In order to satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she came to Soro Yiriwaso with whom she has been working for 30 months. After 3 solidarity loans and 1 individual loan, all correctly reimbursed, she is on her second individual loan. She expects to use this loan to buy 50 lengths of Fancy-brand "pagne" (brightly colored African print cloth) right there in Ségou and she makes her sales, retail, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed of men and women.

With this loan she expects to make a monthly profit of 75,000 F CFA which will permit her to pay school fees for her children, since her husband is no longer living, and also to pay off her debts.

Her ambition is to work in import-export between Mali and Burkino Faso.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of  "pagnes" for re-sale

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is 27 years old and lives with his wife and child in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Ibrahim has been working as a fishmonger for six years. He is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase a new refrigerator for his work. This is his fourth loan cycle and he has always paid on time. 

Ibrahim's previous loans helped him improve his work as well as his financial situation. Ibrahim is successful in his work because he does it well and is known for the good, clean quality of his fish. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash. Ibrahim set up as fishmonger because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new refrigerator for his work

loans.name: Afaf

texts.en:
Afaf owns livestock and she also works in agriculture. She produces milk, cheese, wheat and oil. Afaf has outstanding experience dealing with livestock. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and tourists. When she first started her business, she didn’t have a lot of cash. Afaf decided on this business because it is in demand in her region and she likes working with animals.

Afaf is a 45-year-old woman who lives in Bint Jbeil, Southern Lebanon with her husband and their two children. She is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to increase her livestock. This is her second loan cycle and she has always repaid on time. In the future, she plans on expanding her livestock.

loans.use: To increase livestock

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Entente Est Bonne) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Benkadi  de l’association Sérieux sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Koko de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues essentiellement  à travers des liens   de voisinage.
Elles exercent presque la même activité qui est l’achat et la  vente de pagnes wax,  d’habits et des tissus brodés. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité et jouissent d’une grande notoriété. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Benkadi a décidé d’intégrer à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son sixième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des balles de wax en gros à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Ces wax  sont vendus en détail, au comptant et à crédit au grand marché de Koutiala et en ambulant à une clientèle constituée majoritairement de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 120 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus et l’ouverture d’une boutique  de vente d’habits.
texts.en:
The four women of this group called "Benkadi" (understanding is a good thing), belonging to the "Sérieux" Association, are all married. They have an average age of 35, 4 children on average, live in big traditional extended families in the Koko neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They know each other essentially because of being neighbors.

They do almost the same work, buying and selling "Wax" brand "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth), clothing, and embroidered cloth. They are much in demand in this business and have an excellent reputation.

So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, the Benkadi group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their 6th solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy bales of "Wax" cloth wholesale in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). This cloth will be sold retail, for cash or credit, in the big market of Koutiala and walking around the neighborhoods, to a clientele composed mainly of women. They each hope to make an average profit of 120,000 F CFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan, cover the needs of their extended family, investing the rest in their businesses.

Their ambition is to diversify their businesses by taking on other money-earning ventures and opening a shop to sell clothing.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of bales of "Wax" cloth

loans.name: Balimaya (La Sagesse) Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Balimaya sont toutes mariées avec en moyenne  34 ans, 5 enfants et vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Darsalam 1 de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et de parenté.
Elles exercent comme activité principale l’achat et la vente  des condiments  alimentaires. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Balimaya a décidé d’intégrer à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter une quantité importante de condiments (gros oignon, l’ail, les épices, de l’arachide pour les transformer en pâte)  au  grand marché de Koutiala. Les marchandises sont vendues en détail, au comptant dans les autres marchés de Koutiala et à la maison à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 115 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
The six women of the “Balimaya” (wisdom) group are all married and have an average age of 34, and 5 children on average. They live in big traditional extended families in the Darsalam 1 neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met through bonds of neighborhood and kinship. They all buy and sell condiments. They are much in demand for this activity.

So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, the Balimaya group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy a considerable amount of condiments (onions, garlic, spices, and peanuts to be processed into peanut butter) in the big market of Koutiala. The merchandise is sold retail, for cash, in the other markets of Koutiala and out of their homes, to a clientele essentially composed of women.

They each hope to make an average profit of 115,000 F CFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and cover the needs of their extended families, investing the rest back into their businesses.

Their ambition is to diversify their business by including other money-earning ventures.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Faïda (L’Élégance) Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Faïda sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Sogomougou de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et pour la pratique de la même activité.
Elles exercent presque les mêmes activités de vente de savons et de chaussures. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Faïda a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des balles de chaussures en plastique et des cartons de savons à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Les chaussures et les savons  sont vendus en détail, au comptant et à crédit au marché de Koutiala, dans les entreprises ou de maison à maison. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 110 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus telle que l’ouverture d’un magasin de produits de beauté.
texts.en:
The five women of the “Faïda” (elegance) group are all married. They have an average age of 34 and, on average, 5 children, and they live in big traditional extended families in Sogomougou neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met because they are neighbors and are in the same business. Their business is selling shoes and soap. They are much in demand for these products.

So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, the Faïda group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their 3rd solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy bales of plastic shoes and cases of soap in Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali). The shoes and soap are sold retail, for cash or credit, in the market of Koutiala, in businesses, or door-to-door. They each expect to make an average profit of 110,000 F CFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and cover needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Their ambition is to diversify their businesses by taking up other money-earning ventures such as opening a cosmetics shop.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of shoes and soap for re-sale

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is a 42 year old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Robert has been working as a hairdresser for twenty-six years.
