He requested a loan of $1,200 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase beauty products for his salon. Robert has been a microcredit client for ten years now and has always paid on time.

Robert is special in his work because he is known for his good and talented work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Robert first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products for his salon

loans.name: Sabali  (La Sagesse) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe Sabali sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 4 enfants, vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Darsalam 1 de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et souvent pour la pratique de la  même activité.
Elles exercent comme activité principale la  vente  d’habits  et comme secondaire la vente de condiments alimentaires. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Sabali a décidé d’intégrer à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, des pagnes wax, des brodés,  des prêts à porter  et une quantité importante de condiments alimentaires  à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Les habits  sont vendus en détail, au comptant et à crédit au marché de Koutiala, quant  aux condiments ils sont vendus à la maison et au marché. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 110 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
The eight women of this “Sabali” (wisdom) group are all married. They have an average age of 35 and on average, 4 children. They live in big traditional extended families in the Darsalam 1 neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met through being neighbors and, in many cases, by having the same business.

Their principal business is selling clothing and secondarily, selling condiments. They are much in demand in these areas.

So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, the Sabali group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their 3rd solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy “Wax”-brand “pagnes” (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) , embroidered fabrics, ready-to-wear, and a considerable amount of condiments in Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali). The clothing is sold retail, for cash or credit, in the market of Koutiala. The condiments are sold out of their homes and at the market.

They each hope to make an average profit of 110,000 F CFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to cover the needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Their ambition is to diversify their businesses by taking up other money-earning activities.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of clothing and condiments for resale

loans.name: Suzanne

texts.en:
Suzanne is a 31-year-old woman who lives with her husband and their two children in Saida, Southern Lebanon. Suzanne has been working as a sewer since 2004.

Suzanne requested a loan of $1,000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a new sewing machine and thread for her work. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.

Suzanne is special in her work because she is known for her good quality of work. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. She decided on her business because of her experience, since she learned it from her grandmother when she was young. However, when she first started her business, she didn’t have a lot of cash. In the future, she plans on expanding her business and hopes to have a shop.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine and thread for her work

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Benkadi de l’association Dembagnouma  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au premier quartier de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et de parenté.
Elles exercent presque la même activité la  vente  de condiments alimentaires  et la restauration. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Benkadi  a décidé d’intégrer à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, toutes sortes de condiments alimentaires, du riz et du haricot pour la restauration. Les condiments sont vendus en détail et au comptant  au marché de Koutiala et à la maison. Quant aux nourritures elles sont vendues la nuit devant la porte de leur maison. 
 Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 110 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leurs activités commerciales.
texts.en:
The 5 women of this “Benkadi” group, part of the Dembagnouma Association, are all married. They have an average age of 36, on average 5 children, and live in big extended traditional families in the first neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met because of being from the same neighborhood and being related.

They have almost the same business, selling condiments and cooked food. They are much in demand in these areas. So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, this Benkadi group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their 3rd solidarity loan (group loan). Both the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy all sorts of condiments, and rice and dried beans for cooked food. The condiments are sold retail and for cash in the market of Koutiala and out of their homes. As for the food, it is sold in the evening outside the doors of their houses.

They each expect to make an average profit of 110,000 F CFA over the course of this loan cycle. That money will be used to pay the interest on the loan and cover some needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses. Their ambition is to diversify their commercial activities.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying condiments and ingredients for cooked food service

loans.name: Omina

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

Омина Игамкулова- женщина 1975-го года рождения,замужем,мать 4-х детей, образование среднее. Муж водитель маршрутного такси, старшая дочь и сын учатся в школе. Заниматься торговлей хозяйственных товаров вот уже 5 лет. Начала свою деятельность с продажи мыла и моющих средств. Постепенно она расширила ассортимент товара, то есть добавила хозяйсвенные товаря для дома и бытовую косметику, а также расширила место деятельности. Сейчас её активы увеличились в два раза, в будущем она планирует добавить в свой ассортимент пластиковую посуду.
texts.en:
Born in 1975, Omina I. is married and has 4 children. She has a secondary education. Her husband is a taxi driver, and her oldest daughter and son are in school. Omina has been involved in sales of household goods for 5 years now. She started her business by selling soap and cleaning agents. She gradually expanded her goods assortment by adding household products for home and cosmetics, and she also expanded her store. Omina’s business assets now doubled, and she plans to add plastic dishware to her goods assortment in the future.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of five boxes of household soap

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Danaya sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans et 3 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au  premier quartier  de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage.
Elles exercent comme activités la vente  de bois de chauffe et divers produits (de cosmétiques et de quincaillerie). Elles sont très sollicitées et appréciées dans ces activités. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Danaya a décidé d’intégrer à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, des chargements de camions en bois de chauffe en brousse (auprès des paysans producteurs) et une quantité importante de produits cosmétiques et de quincaillerie à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Le bois de chauffe est  vendu en détail et au comptant à la maison,  quant aux divers produits ils sont vendus au marché de Koutiala où elles ont des places fixes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 80 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The 4 women of this “Danaya” (confidence) group are all married with an average age of 28, and on average 3 children. They live in big extended traditional families in the first neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met because of being from the same neighborhood.

Their businesses are selling firewood and various items (cosmetics and hardware). They are much in demand and highly thought of in these areas. So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, this Danaya group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their 3rd solidarity loan (group loan). Both the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy truckloads of firewood (directly from the rural producers) and a considerable quantity of cosmetics and hardware articles in Bamako (the capital of Mali). The firewood is sold retail and for cash out of their homes. As for the other items, they are sold at the market of Koutiala where the women have stands.

They each expect to make an average profit of 80,000 F CFA over the course of this loan cycle. That money will be used to pay the interest on the loan and cover some needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Imad

texts.en:
Imad is a 24-year-old man who lives with his wife and their two children in Saida, Southern Lebanon.

Imad has owned a barber shop since 2003. He requested a loan of $500 from Al Majmoua in order to change his salon’s décor and to purchase new tools for his work. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

Imad is special in his work because he does it well and has competitive prices. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on his business because of his experience, since he learned it when he was young. In the future, he plans on improving his business and purchasing the salon.

loans.use: To change his salon’s décor and purchase new tools for his work

loans.name: Kotognontala (Soyons Unies) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Kotognontala sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 31 ans et 4 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Koulikoro de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage au lieu de travail.
Elles exercent presque la même activité d’achat et de vente  de pagnes, d’habits  et de cosmétiques. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Kotognontala a décidé d’intégrer à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son onzième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, des pagnes de wax en gros et une quantité importante de produits  cosmétiques à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Les pagnes  sont vendus en détail, au comptant où à crédit au marché de Koutiala et au niveau des entreprises (privées et étatiques), quant aux produits cosmétiques, ils sont vendus en ambulant dans la ville de Koutiala . 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 110 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The 4 women of the “Kotognontala” (Let us be united) group are all married with an average age of 31, and on average 4 children. They live in big extended traditional families in the Koulikoro neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met in their workplaces because of being from the same neighborhood.

They have almost the same businesses buying and selling “pagnes” (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth), clothing, and cosmetics. They are much in demand in these areas. So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, the Kotognontala group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their 11th solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy high quality “pagnes” wholesale, as well as a considerable quantity of cosmetics, in Bamako (the capital of Mali). The “pagnes” are sold retail, for cash or credit in the market of Koutiala and in private companies or government offices. As for the cosmetics, they are sold on foot around the town of Koutiala.

They each expect to make an average profit of 110,000 F CFA over the course of this loan cycle. That money will be used to pay the interest on the loan and cover some needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "pagnes" and cosmetics for re-sale

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe Benkadi  de l’association Dokéyèrèyé sont toutes mariées. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 5 enfants et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Darsalam de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et  de parenté.
Elles exercent presque la même activité d’achat et de vente  d’habits  et de condiments. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Benkadi a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son quatrième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des balles de wax en gros à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali) et une quantité importante de condiments alimentaires. Les marchandises  sont vendues en détail, au comptant et à crédit au marché de Koutiala et dans les entreprises. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 120 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
The 8 women of this “Benkadi” (understanding) group, belonging to the Dokéyèrèyé Association, are all married. They have an average age of 35, and on average 5 children. They live in big extended traditional families in the Darsalam neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met because of being from the same neighborhood and related to each other.

They have almost the same businesses buying and selling clothing and condiments. They are much in demand in these areas. So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, the Benkadi group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their 4th solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy bales of high quality African print cloth wholesale in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and a considerable quantity of condiments. The merchandise is sold retail, for cash or credit, in the market of Koutiala and in work places.

They each expect to make an average profit of 120,000 F CFA over the course of this loan cycle. That money will be used to pay the interest on the loan and cover some needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses. Their ambition is to diversify their businesses by taking up other money-earning activities.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of African print cloth and condiments

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Benkadi de l’association Jeunesse sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans et 2 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Médina Koura de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et pour la pratique du même métier.
Elles exercent presque la même activité : la vente  de condiments  et de bois de chauffe. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Benkadi a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter toute sorte de condiments en gros au grand marché de Koutiala (oignon, tomate, sounbala, piment et épices) et une quantité importante de bois  de chauffe en brousse pour les revendre en   détail et au comptant au marché et à la maison. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 80 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus telle que  l'achat  de réfrigérateur pour la vente des boissons.
texts.en:
The 7 women of this “Benkadi” (understanding) group, belonging to the Jeunesse Association are all married. They have an average age of 29, and on average 2 children. They live in big extended traditional families in the Médina Koura neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met because of being from the same neighborhood and engaged in similar businesses.

They have almost the same businesses, selling condiments and firewood. They are much in demand in these areas. So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, this Benkadi group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their 3rd solidarity loan (group loan). Both the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy various sorts of condiments wholesale in the big market of Koutiala (onions, tomatoes, “sounbala”, red pepper, and spices) and a considerable quantity of firewood. This merchandise is sold retail, for cash, in the markets and out of their homes.

They each expect to make an average profit of 80,000 F CFA over the course of this loan cycle. That money will be used to pay the interest on the loan and cover some needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses. Their ambition is to diversify their businesses by taking up other money-earning activities such as buying a refrigerator so as to sell drinks.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments and firewood for resale

loans.name: Mansour

texts.en:
Mansour is 61 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Saida, southern Lebanon. Mansour has been working as a fisherman since 1970. He requested a loan of $1000 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase a fishing net and do some maintenance work on his boat. This is the first time that Mansour has requested a loan.

Mansour enjoys his work. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash. He set up as a fisherman because he learnt the skill when he was young and therefore had lots of experience. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing net and do some maintenance work on his boat

loans.name: Dembagnouma  (The Good Mother) Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Dembagnouma sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Darsalam 1 de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et pour la pratique de la même activité.
Elles exercent comme  activité principale: la vente  de condiments  et comme activité secondaire les légumes et les tubercules. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Dembagnouma a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son quatrième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter  des condiments en gros au grand marché de Koutiala (oignon, tomate, sounbala, piment et épices) pour les revendre en   détail et au comptant au marché et à la maison. Quant aux légumes et tubercules (ignames, patates douces, maniocs etc.) elles sont périodique et s’achètent au fur et à mesure. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 110 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
The five women of the group Dembagnouma are all married and average 35 years of age and five children, living in large traditional extended families in the Darsalam 1 district of Koutiala City (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). The women know one another through ties of community and from practicing the same business: mainly selling condiments. Their secondary business involves vegetables and tubers. The women are in high demand in this business. In order to satisfy the ever-increasing customer needs, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their fourth solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. The group members intend to use this loan to buy condiments wholesale (onions, tomatoes, sounbala, chili peppers, and spices) at the grand marketplace of Koutiala in order to resell them in retail cash transaction at the marketplace and at the house. As for the vegetables and tubers (yams, sweet potatoes, cassava, etc.), these are cyclical and are purchased over time. The group members each hope to realize an average profit of 110,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for the family, and to invest the rest in business. Their ambition is to diversify their commerce by embracing other revenue-generating work.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments, vegetables, and tubers

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
A. is a 34-year-old man who lives with his wife and their three children in Saida, southern Lebanon.

A. has owned a tow truck for nine years. He requested a loan of $2,000 from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his truck. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

A. is special in his work because of his punctuality. His clients can be anybody. When he first started his business, he had difficulty building networking. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To do some maintenance work on his truck

loans.name: Mhammad

texts.en:
Mhammad is 31 years old and lives in Saida, southern Lebanon. He has owned a grocery store for two years, but he also works in his cousin's restaurant in his free time in order to help his cousin. Mhammad requested a loan of $1800 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase merchandise and a small delivery van. This is Mhammad's second loan cycle and he has always paid on time.

Mhammad is successful in his work because he knows how to treat his customers, who are family members, friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash, and there were not a lot of passers-by. Mhammad set up his grocery store because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and a small delivery van

loans.name: Rami

texts.en:
Rami is a 25-year-old engaged man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon. He owns a restaurant where he does all types of sandwiches; he also serves homemade cocktails and has “narguileh” (also known as “shisha” in Egypt or hubble bubble or hookah in the United States). Narguileh is an ancient tradition enjoyed by the people of the Middle East. A tall (or short) water pipe is used to smoke fruit-flavored tobacco. Narguileh is enjoyed in cafes across the Middle East and is beginning to gain popularity in the US, Europe, and other countries.

Rami requested a loan of $2,000 from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his restaurant, do some maintenance, and purchase a car for delivery. Rami has been investing a lot to make his restaurant known by the public. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

Rami is speciA. in his work because he is known for his hospitality and for his good taste in sandwiches and drinks. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had a bad management. He decided on doing his business because of his experience, especially since he learned hotel management. In the future, he plans on improving and expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his restaurant, do some maintenance, and purchase a car for delivery

loans.name: Mhamed

texts.en:
Mhamed is 31 years old and lives with his wife and child in Saida, southern Lebanon. He has owned a barber's shop since 1993. Mhamed requested a loan of $1500 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to enlarge his salon and change its décor. This is the first time that Mhamed has requested a loan.

Mhamed is successful in his work because he does it well and charges competitive prices. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Mhamed set up as a barber because he learned the trade when he was young and therefore had experience. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To enlarge his salon and change its décor

loans.name: Mhammad

texts.en:
Mhammad is 27 years old and lives in Saida, southern Lebanon. He has owned a hairdressing salon for ten years. Mhammad requested a loan of $2400 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to change his salon’s décor and purchase women's beauty products. This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time.

Mhammad is successful in his work because he is known for his good work and competitive prices. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Mhammad set up his salon because that’s what he always wanted to do. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To change his salon’s décor and purchase women's beauty products

loans.name: Iyad

texts.en:
Iyad is a 39-year-old man who lives with his wife and their four children in Saida, southern Lebanon. Iyad has been working as a taxi driver for five years. He requested a loan of 2000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his car and to purchase new tires for it. This is his third loan and he has always repaid on time.

Iyad is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and has a clean car. His clients can be anybody. He decided on doing his business because he didn’t want to work for someone, he wanted to have independent work. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash and used to work as a driver. In the future, he plans on expanding his business by purchasing another taxi and renting it out.

loans.use: To do some maintenance work on his taxi and to purchase new tires for it

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 40-year-old married man living with his wife and 3 children. In 2008, he decided to open a car mechanic repair shop as his own private business, where he works hard to provide for his family. Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase new tools for his business.

loans.use: To purchase new tools

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en:
Fatmeh is 56 years old and lives with her husband in Saida, southern Lebanon. She has owned a grocery store for nine years. Fatmeh requested a loan of $1500 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase merchandise and an ice-cream refrigerator for her store. This is her third loan cycle and she has always paid on time.

Fatmeh is successful in her work because she knows how to treat her customers, who are family members, friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t have a lot of cash. Fatmeh set up her grocery store because she wanted to supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans on expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and an ice-cream refrigerator for her store

loans.name: Hicham

texts.en:
Hicham is 29 years old and lives in Saida, southern Lebanon. He has been selling fruit and vegetables for seven years. Hicham requested a loan of $700 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase merchandise for his work. This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time.

Hicham is successful in his work because he sells good quality products and knows how to treat his customers, who are friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Hicham set up his fruit and vegetable business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his work

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en:
Nadia is a 74-year-old woman who lives with her husband and their child in Saida, southern Lebanon. Nadia owns a grocery store. She requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise and an ice cream refrigerator for her store. Nadia has been a microcredit client for nine years now and has always paid on time.

Nadia is speciA. in her work because she knows how to treat her clients and is welcoming. Her clients are family members, friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. She decided on her business because she is an active woman who can’t stay home and always needs to be doing something. Also, she wanted to supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans on expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and an ice cream refrigerator for her store

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 39-year-old man who lives with his wife and their three children in Saida, southern Lebanon. He has owned a small restaurant for twenty years where he creates traditional Lebanese cooking like hummos (made from chickpeas) and ful (made from fava beans).

Ali requested a loan of 2500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his resaurant like vegetables, raw materials and drinks. This is his fourth loan and he has always repaid on time.

Ali is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and he sells a good quality product. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his restaurant

loans.name: Luz Cerito Group

texts.en:
To call Carmen R. anything less than an artist would be a misnomer as she is a talented craftsman of jewelry. The bracelets, necklaces and earring sets that she makes are both unique and beautiful. While she has occasionally sold her products in the past, this is the first time that she is trying to truly scale up her efforts. She is moving her sporadically lucrative hobby to a developed business venture.

Carmen R. (far left) is a bright and engaging 50-year-old woman. She is both passionate and a true leader as evidenced by the fact that she is one of the coordinators of group Luz Cerito. Resting at the base of the tropical hills of the Los Alcarrizos barrio (community), La Pared, Carmen lives with her husband and two grown sons.

One of the main barriers that prevented Carmen from previously scaling up her work was lack of capital. She simply did not have the means to purchase the supplies she needed to make her jewelry. With this loan, she will be able to purchase these materials from a supplier in Santo Domingo, the capital, which is about an hour away from her home. Carmen plans to sell her jewelry from her house and her sister’s salon as she figures women who have just had their hair done will be feeling beautiful and will be more willing to purchase jewelry to complement their new style.

Carmen is excited about the opportunities that this loan will provide. She thinks it is wonderful that her hobby is becoming her profession and looks forward to a life that is more stable, tranquil, and peaceful. On behalf of Carmen Ramirez, the bank Luz Cerito, and the microfinance institute Esperanza International, thank you for providing opportunities to those who need them most.

This profile was written by Anne Cherniss, Esperanza International Summer Fellow ´09

loans.use: To buy supplies to make jewelry: cord, clasps, beads

loans.name: Ana Rosa

texts.es: La señora Ana atienD. su tienda D. barrio ubicada en la zona D. Pampahasi, tiene diversos productos para atraer mas clientela, tiene un solo  hijo D. 9 años D. edad que está en edad escolar, y ella sola se dedica a su manutención, vive humildemente en la trastienda (parte trasera del negocio)en cuarto pequeño solo para los dos. Es una cliente puntual y no trabaja con otra institución. El crédito será invertido en la compra D. abarrotes como arroz, azúcar, fideo y harina por quintales.
texts.en:
Ana has a neighborhood store, which is located in the Pampashasi zone. She carries diverse products to attract more customers. She has one child, a nine year old son who is of school age. She raises and supports him by herself. They live very humbly in a small room in the back of the store. She is a punctual client, and she does not work with another institution. The loan is to buy groceries like rice, sugar, noodles, and quintales (one quintal is 46 kg.) of flour.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries (rice, oil, noodles, etc.)

loans.name: Las Dos Juntas Group

texts.es: Este grupo está compuesto por dos personas la sra. Juana C. que se dedica a la venta de comdimentos y la sra. Virginia B. que se dedica a la venta de crema chantilli(crema de leche). Ambas venden en la calle 23 de marzo, ubicada en la zona de Pampahasi, se conocen hace mucho tiempo y son muy buenas amigas. Doña Juana vive en la final de la calle 23 de marzo, con cuatro hijos que están en edad escolar, su esposo se queda en casa ya que tuvo un accidente y quedo paralítico, sin poder trabajar. Doña Virginia vive en la zona de Kupini, ella hace chantilli,hecha de leche batida manualmente con azúcar y limón, batido de bicervecina y frescos hervidos de manzana. Invertirán el crédito en incrementar su capital, doña juana en compra de condimentos,y doña Virginia en compra de leche por mayor cantidad.
texts.en:
This group is comprised of two people. Juana C. sells condiments, and Virginia B. sells Chantilly cream. They both sell on 23 de Marzo Street, which is located in the Pampahasi zone. They have known each other for a long time, and they are very good friends. Juana lives at the end of 23 de Marzo Street with her four school aged children. Her husband stays at home. Since he had an accident, he has been paralyzed. He cannot work. Virginia lives in the Kupini zone. She makes Chantilly, which is made of milk whipped by hand, sugar, and lemon; whipped “bicervecina” (dark beer); and drinks made from boiled apples. They will use the loan to increase their capital. Juana will buy condiments. Virginia will buy a larger quantity of milk.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies, vegetables and repairs to the boarding house

loans.name: Andres Magno

texts.es: El sr. Andrés es un cliente antiguo de la institución, se dedica a la venta de inciensos en el centro de la ciudad y viaja tambien a la ciudad de Oruro, donde su esposa vende tambien cosmeticos, ambos se colaboran mutuamente y son muy unidos. Tienen cuatro niños, viven humilemente en una casita pequeña. Es un cliente muy responsable y muy puntual, el crédito será invertido en el incremento de su capital, tanto de inciensos como en cosmeticos.
texts.en:
Andrés is an old client of the institution. He sells incense in the center of the city. He also travels to the city of Oruro, where his wife sells cosmetics. They collaborate mutually, and they are very united. They have four children, and they live humbly in a small house. He is a responsible client, and he is very punctual. The loan is to buy incense and cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy incense

loans.name: Victoria Jenny

texts.es: La señora jenny se encuentra en su cuarta secuencia de su credito individual dentro de la institucion, paralelamente la señora se encuentra trabajando en el Banco de Emprendimiento "El Condor" en el cual esta en su tercera secuencia durate todo el tiempo que a trabajado junto a la institucion siempre a demostrado ser una persona trabajadora y con ganas de superacion.  La actividad economica que realiza es la venta de comida en un pequeño local ubicado en la Plaza El Condor en la Calle Jose Maria Camacho No 1760.  Ella vive conjuntamente con el esposo y sus dos hijos, don Frenando Arias el esposo cuenta con un trabajo fijo con el cual ayuda con los gastos familiares.  La sañora Jenny invertira el prestamo en la compra de insumos para su negocio es decir arroz, fideo y algunos otros alimentos que se pudieran comprar por cantidad para si poder aminorar costos y generar mayor ganancia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Jenny is now in the fourth sequence of her individual loan with the institution, at the same time she can be found working at the entrepreneurial bank "El Condor" which is in its third sequence. Throughout the entire time she has been working together with the institution she has always proved to be a hardworking person who is eager to excel. The economic activity that she carries out is the sale of food in a small place located in the Plaza El Condor on Jose Maria Camacho Street. She lives with her husband and two sons; her husband, Mr. Frenando Arias has a steady job which helps with the household expenses. Mrs. Jenny will invest the loan in the purchase of basic goods for her business, such as rice, noodles and other foods that can be purchased in bulk to reduce the costs and generate greater profit.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of goods for the restaurant

loans.name: Future Winners Group

texts.en: Jestine W. is 25 years of age, and a high school graduate. She lives in Moulton Corner and is married with 3 children. She sells used clothes at her house and hopes to add new varieties if she receives a loan. She would like to buy slippers upon receiving her loan.

loans.use: To buy slippers for resale

loans.name: Martina Andrea

texts.es:
La señora Martina Andrea tiene 46 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudio secundarios completos , tiene 3 hijos que dependen económicamente de ella.
Martina  se dedica a la venta de menús (comida) los cuales los prepara en la cocina de su domicilio . Para posteriormente llevarlos a repartir a sus comensales.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió en la compra insumos como arroz, fideos, azúcar, menestras ,ajos , ají escabeche, rocoto , aceite , carne , pollo, etc.     
Empezó a comprar sus insumos  al por mayor y así poder estar abastecida y generar mayor  ganancia.
Con este crédito de 500 soles que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra de insumos  al por mayor así como utensilios de cocina  que requiere su negocio.
Martina tiene como sueño, incrementar su negocio para obtener dinero y seguir con la construcción de cuartos en su domicilio para alquilar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Martina Andrea is 46 years old and lives in the Salaverry district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. This entrepreneur completed her secondary education and has 3 children who depend economically on her. Martina is dedicated to the sale of food which she prepares from the kitchen in her home and then takes to distribute to her guests. With the first loan of 300 soles that she received from the communal bank "Las Emprendedoras II," she invested in the purchase of basic goods such as rice, noodles, sugar, menestras (a local vegetable stew), garlic, pickled peppers, pumpkin, oil, beef, chicken, etc. She began to purchase her supplies at wholesale and can therefore stock them to generate greater income. With this credit of 500 soles that will be repaid in 4 months, she will invest in her business, in the purchase of supplies in bulk as well as in cooking utensils required for her business. Martina's dream is to grow her business to obtain money and continue with the construction of rooms in her home to rent.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies in bulk: rice, sugar, oil, pasta, potatoes, etc.

loans.name: Rosa Del Socorro

texts.es: Rosa del Socorro habita junto a su mamá, 3 hermanas y 2 hijos menores en la zona # 7 en Juigalpa, tiene 2 negocios, uno de venta de ropa y otro de venta de tortillas; diario por la mañana madruga muy temprano a elaborar tortillas para vender a sus vecinos, actividad que es apoyada por su mamá, el marido labora como conductor de taxi y le apoya con los gastos familiares; posteriormente a la venta de tortillas visita a clientes que abastece de ropa nueva, generalmente clientes de credito les deja y le entregan un 50% de contado.  Tiene como planes futuros dedicarse  al 100% aka vebta de ropa y dejar a su mamá con el negocio de tortillas y asi lograr sacar adelante a su familia.
texts.en:
Rosa del Socorro lives with her mother, her 3 sisters, and her 2 children in the #7 area of Juigalpa.

She has two businesses -- one selling clothing and the other selling tortillas. Every day she wakes up early to make tortillas to be sold to her neighbors and her mother helps with the preparations. Her husband is a taxi driver and helps with the family expenses. After selling tortillas, she visits her customers to deliver new clothes they have ordered. She generally extends credit to her customers if they pay 50% cash upon delivery. Her future plans involve devoting herself 100% to her clothing business and letting her mother run the tortilla business. She believes this will allow her family to succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for selling clothes and making tortillas

loans.name: Maria Esperanza

texts.es:
La señora Maria Esperanza tiene 47 años D. edad, vive en el distrito D. Salaverry , provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudio secundarios completos, tiene 5 hijos D. los cuales los 2 últimos dependen  económicamente D. ella.
Maria Esperanza  se D. dedica a elaborar manualidades como: almohadas, manteles, adornos y muñecos D. corrospun los cuales los venD. a sus familiares, amistades, vecinos. También es profesora D. manualidades D. un centro educativo D. inicial.  
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió para comprar materiales como hilos ,telas, corrospum, cintas satinadas, cinta D. agua, lentejuelas , etc
Con este crédito D. S/ 2,000 soles, lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra D. más materiales para sus manualidades.
Maria Esperanza  tiene como sueño, implementar un taller D. m anualidades junto con la ayuda D. sus hijas a quienes les ha enseñado hacer manualidades para así  incrementar su negocio, ganar mas clientes y obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Sra. Maria Esperanza, 47, lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She has a high-school education. She has 5 children, two of whom still live at home. Maria Esperanza operates a crafts business, making products such as pillows, blankets, home decorations and "corrospun" [a kind of plastic] dolls and selling them to her relatives, friends and neighbors. She also teaches others how to make crafts at a local school. She used the first loan that she received from Las Emprendedoras II community bank, for 300 soles, to buy materials such as thread, fabric, corrospum, ribbons, sequins, etc. With this S/.2,000 [2,000 soles] loan, she will buy more materials for her business. Maria Esperanza dreams of setting up a workshop with her daughters, who learned how to make crafts from their mother, so that she can grow the business, gain more customers and increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for crafts business.

loans.name: Penty Hecky

texts.en:
Penty is 29 years old. He is married with three children. He is a tailor in Uthiru, Nairobi. His business is located in a busy market center in a one-room rented house. Penty has been in the business for five years and feels that he needs to expand. With this loan, he hopes to buy a buttonhole sewing machine, more fabric, and other sewing materials.

He has walk-in clients and regulars. He wants to expand his business to include selling clothing materials to other tailors, and he wants to open other branches of his business in other market centers.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy a buttonhole sewing machine and other materials for making clothes

loans.name: El Buen Futuro Group 1

texts.en:
At the age of 59, when many would like to retire, Rafaela R. has her eyes set on growing her business. She would like a loan to buy more ice and ice cream for her ice cream business. Rafaela has successfully completed four loan cycles and has proven herself a savvy businesswoman. Her strategy is to provide a greater variety of flavors than her competitors and it is paying off.

Rafaela is part of the solidarity group El Buen Futuro 1 (A Good Future) which takes out microloans as a group. The members of this group live in the small village of Casa Colorada which is a beautiful town surrounded by acres of sugarcane fields and lush greenery. The photo was taken in the grocery store of another group member.

Rafaela would like to keep growing her business in order to finish building her house. It is very expensive for Dominicans to build their own houses, therefore many people build out of cement and slowly add on over the years until their house is finished. Rafaela still has two children and one grandchild living at home and she would love nothing more than to be able to provide them with a house to be safe from the sometimes harsh tropical weather.

Rafaela and the entire El Buen Futuro group greatly appreciate the opportunities Kiva lenders like you have given them and hope to continue in their success!

loans.use: To buy more ice cream

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées, avec une moyenne d’âge de 25 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente d’habits pour enfants et du bois de chauffe.  
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, tous les deux  précédents  se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 20 colis d’habits pour enfants, 50 chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe. Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement au grand marché de Sikasso ville. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Hamdallaye de façon ambulante, dans le quartier et au grand marché à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 11.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne.
Certaines femmes du groupe Benkadi ambitionnent  acheter un terrain à usage d’habitation et d’autres  devenir des clientes individuelles.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Benkadi are all married and average 25 years of age and three children. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of Mali). The women run diverse businesses, including the sale of children's clothing and firewood. The group members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers and are now on their third solidarity loan. The two preceding ones have been settled. With this new loan, they intend to buy 20 packages of children's clothing and 50 cart loads of firewood. Supplies are gotten essentially at the grand market of Sikasso City. The merchandise is sold mostly in cash transactions at the Hamdallaye market in an itinerant manner in the area and also at the grand market. The customers are composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 11,500 francs CFA. Part of the profits will be used for family needs, and the other part will be put into savings. Certain women in the group have the ambition of buying a plot of land on which to live, and the others, becoming individual clients.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy children's clothing and firewood

loans.name: Monica Elizabeth

texts.es:
La señora Mónica Elizabeth M. C. tiene 35 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry , provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudio secundarios incompletos , tiene 5 hijos de los cuales 2 dependen de ella económicamente. 
Mónica Elizabeth  se dedica a la preparación de tamales junto con su madre y su padre es el encargado de salir a venderlos por las calles de su distrito.  Ella actualmente ese encuentra laborando en la Municipalidad del Distrito de Salaverry.

Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió en la compra insumos como harina , aceite . aceitunas para la preparación de su tamales (plato tipico de la región). 
Con la ayuda del préstamo empezó a comprar sus insumos  al por mayor y así poder estar abastecida y generar mayor  ganancia.
Con el crédito de 1.200 soles lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra de insumos para la preparación de sus tamales.
También tiene planificado en esta semana comprar productos de limpieza como desinfectantes, lejía. Ácido muriático, etc  los cuales va a ofrecer a sus amistades, compañeros de trabajo, vecinos y familiares.
Mónica tiene como sueño, incrementar su negocio para obtener dinero darles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos y poder ayudarlos en sus estudios.
texts.en:
Sra. Monica Elizabeth M. C., 35, lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She started high school, but didn't finish. She has 5 children, two of whom still live at home. Monica Elizabeth earns a living making tamales with her mother. Her father is responsible for going out in neighborhood and selling the tamales. She works in the Salaverry district. She used the first loan that she received from Las Emprendedoras II community bank, for 300 soles, to buy supplies such as flour, cooking oil, olives for making tamales (a traditional dish of the region). The loan allowed her to buy supplies in bulk so that she could be well-stocked and increase her earnings. She will use the 1,200 soles loan to buy supplies for making her tamales. She also plans this week to buy cleaning products such as disinfectants, bleach, muriatic acid, etc. which she'll sell to friends, co-workers, neighbors and relatives. Monica dreams of growing her business to get more money and give her children a better quality of life and help with their schooling.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for food business.

loans.name: Etoile Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Étoile sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente d’habits  pour enfants, des fruits, de bois de chauffe et  de boissons.  
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin croissant de la clientèle, elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, tous les  deux précédents  se sont bien dénoués. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 10 colis d’habits pour enfants,  30 chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe, 100 régimes de bananes et 20 casiers de boisson. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Hamdallaye de façon ambulante, dans le quartier et au  grand marché à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 13.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour la santé des enfants et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne.
Certaines femmes du groupe Étoile ambitionnent  devenir des grossistes  et d’autres  devenir des clientes individuelles.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Étoile are all married and average 35 years of age and have four children. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of Mali). The women run diverse businesses, including the sale of children's clothing, fruit, firewood, and beverages. With the goal of satisfying the growing customer need, the group members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their third solidarity loan. The two preceding loans have been settled. With this new loan, they intend to buy 10 packages of children's clothing, 30 cart loads of firewood, 100 bunches of bananas, and 20 cases of drinks. Supplies are gotten at the grand market of Sikasso City. The merchandise is sold mostly in cash transactions at the Hamdallaye market in an itinerant manner in the area and also at the grand market. The customers are composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 13,500 francs CFA. Part of the profits will be used for the health of the children, and the other part will be put into savings. Certain women in the group have the ambition of becoming wholesalers, and the others, becoming individual loan customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Ysolina Nancy

texts.es:
La señora Ysolina, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 23 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, es madre de 01 hijo y tiene estudios superiores (enfermera),  vive en el Barrio Revolución.

Inicia su trabajo con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos,  con un préstamo inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles el cual utilizó para comprar cosméticos de la línea  Unique. 

Su deseo es ejercer su carrera y seguir alguna especialización.

A ella le gusta la facilidad en los préstamos, los ahorros  y los beneficios que ofrecen a las mujeres.
texts.en:
Sra. Ysolina belongs to the Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa ["Powerful Women of Santa Rosa"] community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Puno. She is 23 years old, partnered and the mother of 1 son. She has studied nursing. She lives in the Revolucion neighborhood.

She began working with the Manuela Ramos movement, taking a first loan of S/.300 [300 soles], which she used to buy cosmetics from the Unique cosmetics line.

She most wants to practice her profession and follow some specialty.

What she likes best [about the community bank?] is being able to borrow easily, saving and the benefits they provide to women.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for resell.

loans.name: Lafia Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Lafia est composé de quatre  femmes  mariées  (dont une polygame et les trois autres monogames) qui ont en moyenne 28 ans, 4 enfants et qui  vivent dans le quartier Hamdallaye  de la ville de Sikasso  (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin croissant de la clientèle, elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, tous les prêts  précédents se sont été bien dénoués. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente d’ habits  pour enfants,  du savon, des parfums  et  de l’atieké.  
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 15 colis d’habits pour enfants, 40 cartons de savon, 30 cartons de parfums  et 20 tasses d’atieké. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Hamdallaye, de façon ambulante dans le quartier et au  grand marché à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10 000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour la santé des enfants et l’autre partie sera utilisée  pour rembourser le prêt.
Certaines femmes du groupe Lafia ambitionnent  devenir des grossistes  et d’autres  devenir des clientes individuelles.
texts.en:
The group Lafia is composed of four married women (of whom one is polygamous and three are monogamous). The women average 28 years of age and four children, and they live in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of Mali). With the goal of satisfying the growing customer need, they are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their third solidarity loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. The women run diverse businesses, including the sale of children's clothing, soap, perfumes, and atieké (couscous made from fermented cassava). With this new loan, they intend to buy 15 packages of children's outfits, 40 boxes of soap, 30 boxes of perfumes, and 20 tubs of atieké. Supplies are gotten at the grand market of Sikasso City. The merchandise is sold mostly in cash transactions at the Hamdallaye market, in the area by going door-to-door, and at the grand market. The customers are composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA. Part of the profits will be used for the children's health, and the other part will used for repaying the loan. Certain group members have the ambition of becoming wholesalers, and others, becoming individual clients.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Stephen Kyalo

texts.en:
Stephen M. is a 28-year-old married father of one. He has a business making and selling sofas, chairs, beds and other furniture. This will be his first loan from KADET, and it is the first time he has borrowed money to fund his business.

Stephen's business is five years old and a success. He now has three locations employing three full-time workers. His employees frame, fill and upholster the furniture he sells. With this 50,000 Kenyan shilling loan, Stephen plans to buy upholstery fabric, filling material such as foam and fabric scraps, wood to make sofa frames, and to pay employee wages.

In the future, Stephen hopes to own a first-class furniture shop and open a storefront in Mombasa's central business district.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions.

loans.use: To buy furniture-making materials and to pay employee wages.

loans.name: Mercedes Adela

texts.es:
La señora Mercedes Adela tiene 43 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudio secundarios completos, tiene 4 hijos y solo 2 dependen económicamente de ella.
 Mercedes se dedica  a la venta de cerveza en su domicilio y a la preparación de comida como: ceviches, pescado frito, chicharrón de pescado y arroz con mariscos.
Actualmente ha dejado de vender porque su vivienda se encuentra en construcción, pero en 15 días retomará el negocio.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió en la compra cerveza e insumos para la elaboración de sus comidas.
Con el crédito de 800 soles lo invertirá en la compra de cerveza, vajilla y utensilios de cocina que necesita su negocio.
Mercedes tiene como sueño aumentar la venta de cerveza y platos de comida para llegar a tener un restaurante.
texts.en:
Sra. Mercedes Adela, 43, lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She has a high school education. She has 4 children, two of whom still live at home. Mercedes operates a business from her house, selling beer and making and selling ceviche, fried fish, fried calamari, rice with shellfish and other prepared foods. She's not selling now because of construction work going on at her house, but she plans to start again in 15 days. She used the first loan that she received from the Las Emprendedoras II community bank to buy beer and supplies for making her food dishes. She will use the 800 soles loan to buy beer, tableware and cooking utensils that she needs for the business. Mercedes dreams of increasing her sales of beer and food so that can ultimately open a restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for food business.

loans.name: Israel Plus Group

texts.fr: Dégaule gère sa propre boutique et une moto taxi. Il a commencé son activité en 2001 avec un capital initial de $120. Sa petite boutique a bien prospéré grâce aux bénéfices accumulés et une bonne gestion qui ont fait croitre le capital à $800 en 2005. L’ambition de Dégaule d’ouvrir un jour un magasin de gros, l’a poussée d’intégrer en aout 2008, un des groupes de Hope RDC dénommé ‘Israel Plus’ pour recevoir des crédits afin de soutenir son rêve. Il a obtenu trois fois les prêts de Hope qu’il a remboursé totalement.  Le quatrième prêt qu’il a reçu au mois de juin dernier lui a servi de renforcer le stock de la boutique en achetant des cartons des sardines, savons, du lait, du sucre, des sachets d’eau pure, etc… à revendre dans le but d’accroitre le revenu. Actuellement, son capital propre est de $1200 et le bénéfice réalisé par mois est de $250. Dégaule a 35 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants dont leurs âges varient entre 4 et 9 ans. Deux d’entre eux vont à l’école.
texts.en:
Dégaule manages his own shop and a motorbike taxi. He started his business in 2001 with $120 in capital. His small shop really prospered, thanks to accumulated profits and good managing that have made his capital grow to $800 in 2005. His ambition is to open a wholesale store one day, and so he was driven to join a HOPE RDC group in August 2008 called “Israel Plus” in order to receive loans for supporting his dream. He obtained a loan three times from HOPE and has repaid them completely. The fourth loan he received in this past June was used to bolster the inventory in his shop by buying boxes of sardines, soaps, milk, sugar, baggies of Pure Water, etc. to resell with the goal of increasing his revenues. Currently, his capital amounts to $1,200 and the profits realized monthly come to $250. Dégaule is 35 years old, married, and the father of three children, ranging in age from 4 to 9. Two of them go to school.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sardines, soap, milk, sugar, etc. to stock her shop

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Veronica Azucena

texts.es:
La señorita  Verónica tiene 29 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.  Ella es socia del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”.
La empresaria presenta estudio de secundaria  completa. 
Verónica    se dedica  a la venta de productos de belleza de las líneas Esika, Unique y Avon. También se dedica a preparar chocolates.

Este es su primer crédito, Verónica requiere S/. 300 soles para comprar insumos para la preparación de sus chocolates como: chocolate en barras, manjar blanco, pecanas, pasas ,etc.  También comprará productos de belleza para aumentar su stock y vender con mayor facilidad.

Verónica tiene como sueño aumentar sus ventas y reunir dinero para poder estudiar una carrera técnica.
texts.en:
Srta. Veronica, 29, lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She is a member of the Las Emprendedoras II community bank. She has a high school education. Veronica makes a living selling Esika, Unique and Avon beauty products. She also earns money making chocolates.

This is Veronica's first loan. She needs S/.300 [300 soles] to buy supplies for making her chocolates: bars of chocolate, manjar blanco [a traditional sweet], pecans, raisins, etc. She will also buy beauty products to add to her stock and help her to sell more easily.

Veronica most wants to increase her sales and amass enought money to be able to study for a technical career.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to resell.

loans.name: Convenient Group

texts.en: Varney is single and has a daughter about 2 years old. He’s been involved in the sale kerosene for about 3 years now. He sells around town and sometimes at his home. He said, “I attract my customers to buy by means of friendship and having good talks”. His goal is to increase the sale by drums, gallons, tins, etc. and he also hopes build his house from the sales or revenue generated.

loans.use: To buy kerosene for resale

loans.name: Margarita Gaudiosa

texts.es:
La señora Margarita tiene 66 años D. edad, vive en el distrito D. Salaverry , provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios superiores, tiene 4 hijos y ninguno depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Margarita  se dedica, con la ayuda D. sus hijas, a la preparación y ventas  D. menú (comida), ha logrado instalar en su vivienda un restaurante.
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió en la compra insumos para la preparación D. sus menús como: arroz, aceite, azúcar, papas, fideos, etc.
Con la ayuda D. este préstamo empezó a comprar sus insumos  al por mayor y así poder estar abastecida y generar mayor  ganancia.
Con este crédito D. S/ 1,700 soles, lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra por mayor D. insumos para la preparación D. menús.
Margarita  tiene como sueño, incrementar su clientela..
texts.en:
Margarita is 66, and she lives in the Salaverry district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She has a college education. She has four children who are economically independent of her. Margarita, with her daughters’ help, makes and sells meals. She has set up a restaurant in her house. She received her first loan for 300 PEN from Las Emprendedoras II, her Community Bank. She used it to buy supplies like rice, oil, sugar, potatoes, noodles, etc. for the preparation of her meals. With the help of this loan, she started to buy wholesale supplies. This way she is better supplied, and she generates greater earnings. With this loan for 1,700 PEN she will buy wholesale supplies for meal preparation. Margarita’s dream is to increase the number of customers she has.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for meal preparation

loans.name: Zulma Diana

texts.es:
La señora Zulma Diana V. D. Z.  tiene 31 años D. edad, vive en el distrito D. Salaverry, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudio secundarios completos, tiene 3 hijos que dependen económicamente D. ella.
Zulma   se dedica a la venta D. productos D. belleza D. las marcas Unique, Avon y Esika los cuales los venD. a sus amistades, vecinos y familiares.
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió en la compra D.  mas productos para tener stock ante cualquier pedido.
 Con este crédito D. S/ 1,200 soles, lo invertirá en la compra D. mas productos D. belleza y en la compara D. una vitrina que utilizará como mostrador.
Tiene como sueño, implementar mas su stock debido a que esta aumentando su clientela.
texts.en:
Zulma Diana V. D. Z. is 31. She lives in the Salaverry district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She has a high school education. She has three children who are economically dependent upon her. Zulma sells Unique, Avon, and Esika brand beauty products. She sells to friends, neighbors, and family. She received her first loan of 300 PEN from Las Emprendedoras II, her Community Bank. She used the loan to buy more products so that she would have any order in stock. With this loan for 1,200 PEN, she will buy more beauty products. She will also buy a display case to use as a counter. Her dream is to increase her stock because she is getting more customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beauty products like perfume, creams, etc.  Buy a display case

loans.name: Allah Is Great Group

texts.en:
S. is happily married with 5 children of his own. He’s been involved in the sale of charcoal for the past 10 years now. He goes to the bush area (rural areas) to purchase and sell at retail prices (mainly by the bag).

"I am challenged by others because there are many people selling similar goods, but I am successful in that, I go for the driest product even during the rainy season and sell most especially when the product is in demand," he said. He deals in the Browerville community and dreams of owning a power saw to help reduce the intensive labor used.

loans.use: To buy charcoal for sale

loans.name: Lumiere Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Lumière  est composé de quatre femmes  (qui sont toutes mariées)  avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et  ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  (3ème région administrative du Mali.) 
Dans le but  d’augmenter la clientèle et le profit, elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, tous les deux prêts précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente d’ habits  pour enfants,  des boisson et des fruits.  
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 20 colis d’habits pour enfants, 40 cartons de boissons, 10 chargements de charrettes  en fruits (ananas). Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville.  Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Hamdallaye, de façon ambulante dans le quartier et au  grand marché à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée dans l’éducation et  la santé des enfants et l’autre partie sera utilisée pour rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The group Lumière is composed of four women (all married) who average 35 years of age and who have four children on average. The women live for the most part in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of Mali). With the goal of increasing their customer base and profits, they are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their third solidarity loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. The women run diverse businesses, including the sale of children's clothing, beverages, and fruit. With this new loan, they intend to buy 20 packages of children's outfits, 40 boxes of drinks, and 10 cart loads of fruit (pineapples). Supplies are gotten at the grand market of Sikasso City from wholesalers. The merchandise is sold mostly in cash transactions at the Hamdallaye market, in the area by going door-to-door, and at the grand market. The customers are composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 15,000 francs CFA. Part of the profits will be used for the children's education and health, and the other part will used for repaying the loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Manuela Candelaria

texts.es:
La señora Manuela tiene 53 años D. edad, vive en el distrito D. Salaverry, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios D. secundaria completa, tiene 3 hijos y ninguno depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Manuela tiene su peluquería que se encuentra ubicada en la avenida los incas D. la ciudad D. Trujillo, en donD. se dedica a la atención D. sus clientes, realizando cortes D. cabello, pintado, peinados, manicure, etc
Con su primer crédito D. 300 soles lo utilizó para comprar líquidos para ondulaciones, tijeras para el corte D. cabello, vidulis para ondular el cabello, etc.
Con este crédito D. S/. 800.00 soles, lo invertirá en comprar mas liquido D. ondulación, una  secadora y tijeras.
Manuela   tiene como sueño aumentar su clientela y posteriormente colocar otro salón D. belleza en Trujillo.
texts.en:
53-year old Señora Manuela lives in the district of Salaverry, Trujillo province, in the department of La Libertad, Peru. She is a businesswoman, has completed her high school education, and has three children, all of whom are financially independent. Manuela owns a hairdressing salon located on Avenida Los Incas in the city of Trujillo. She offers her clients services such as hair cuts, make-up, hair dos, manicures etc. With her first loan of 300 soles she bought perm solution, hairdresser’s scissors, curlers etc. With this loan of 800 soles, she will buy more perm solution, a hair dryer, and scissors. Manuela’s dream is to increase her number of clients and some time in the future open another beauty salon in Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy items for her hairdressing salon

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabougnouma est composé de six  femmes  toutes mariées (dont une monogame et  cinq  polygames) avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et  4 enfants. Elles vivent  à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Dans le but  d’augmenter la clientèle et le profit, elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de pagnes wax, de la pomme de terre,  des chaussures et  des savons.  
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 20 pièces de pagnes wax,  20 sacs de 50 kg de pomme de terre, 50 paires de chaussures et 20 cartons de savons. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville auprès des grossistes. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Hamdallaye de façon ambulante, dans le quartier et au grand marché de  la ville à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 7 500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée dans l’éducation  des enfants et l’autre partie sera épargnée.
texts.en:
The group Sabougnouma is composed of six women who are all married (of whom one is monogamous and five are polygamous). The women average 35 years of age and four children.
