They live in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of Mali). With the goal of increasing their customer base and profits, they are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their third solidarity loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. The women run diverse businesses, including the sale of Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), potatoes, shoes, and soaps. With this new loan, the intend to buy twenty bolts of Wax pagnes, twenty 50-kg sacks of potatoes, fifty pairs of shoes, and twenty boxes of soaps. Supplies are gotten at the grand market of Sikasso City from wholesalers. The merchandise is sold mostly in cash transactions at the Hamdallaye market, in the area by going door-to-door, and at the grand market. The customers are composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 7,500 francs CFA. Part of the profits will be used for the children's education, and the other part will be put into savings.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Rocio Del Pilar

texts.es:
La señora Rocio del Pilar tiene 42 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry , provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudio secundarios completos, tiene 5 hijos de los cuales 2 dependen de ella económicamente. 
Rocio del Pilar  se dedica a la venta de productos de alimentos como: azúcar, arroz, aceite, fideos, etc.,  también productos de limpieza como: lejía, cera, ácido muriático y golosina como: caramelos, galletas, chocolates, chupetines, etc
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió en la compra mas productos para vender en su tienda que se encuentra ubicada en su domicilio.
Con la ayuda del préstamo empezó a comprar sus insumos  al por mayor y así poder estar abastecida y generar mayor  ganancia.
Con este crédito de S/. 1.000 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de mas productos para abastecer su tienda:  arroz, acúcar, leche, fideos, etc..
Rocio tiene como sueño, incrementar su negocio para obtener dinero y darles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos y poder ayudarlos en sus estudios.
texts.en:
42-year old Rocio de Pilar lives in the district of Salaverry, Trujillo province, in the department of La Libertad, Peru. She is a businesswoman, has completed her high school education, and has five children, two of whom are still financially dependent on her. Rocio earns her living selling food products such as sugar, rice, oil, and noodles; cleaning products such as bleach, wax, muriatic acid (for cleaning brick, tile, concrete); and candy such as caramels, cookies, chocolates, and lollipops. With her first loan of 300 soles which she received from the “Las Emprendedoras II” Community Bank, she bought more products to sell in the store which is located in her home. The loan helped her buy items at wholesale prices so she was able to increase her stock and earn more money. With this 1,000 sole loan she plans to buy more products for the store: rice, sugar, milk, noodles etc. Rocio’s dream is to expand her business so she can earn more money, provide her children with a better standard of living, and be able to help with their education.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more products for her store

loans.name: Yrma Nida

texts.es:
La señora Yrma Nida tiene 71 años D. edad, vive en el distrito D. Salaverry , provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta sexto D. primaria , tiene 5hijos, todos son mayores y no dependen económicamente D. ella.
Yrma  se dedica a la elaboración D. manualidades como bisutería: aretes, cadenas . collares y también a la elaboración D. almohadas.
Con su primer crédito D. 300 soles compro mas materiales como: hilos, telas, alambres, perlas, etc  para que pueda hacer sus manualidades 
Con este crédito D. S/ 1,500 soles, lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra D. mas materiales para sus manualidades.
Yrma  tiene como sueño comprar una vitrina y mostradores para colocarla en la sala D. su casa y exhibir sus productos ya si aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Sra. Yrma Nida is 71 years old, and lives in the Salaverry district in the province of Trujillo, in La Libertad department of Peru. The businesswoman studied until the sixth year of primary school, and has 5 children, all of whom are older and do not depend on her economically.

Yrma makes handicrafts such as costume jewelry: earrings, chains, and necklaces. She also makes pillows. With her first loan of 300 soles, she purchased additional materials such as: thread, fabric, wire, and pearls, to make her handicrafts. She will invest this loan of 1,500 soles in her business, in the purchase of more materials for her handicrafts.

Yrma has a dream to buy a glass showcase and counters to put in a room in her house to exhibit her products and increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in her business, in the purchase of more materials for her handicrafts

loans.name: Chaska Group

texts.es:
Los socios del banco comunal “CHASKA”, son miembros que vienen trabajando juntos en su tercer ciclo, ellos residen en la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestros socios realizan diferentes labores, ellos son comerciantes minoristas, atienden personalmente sus diferentes negocios, como restaurante, tiendas de abarrotes, venta de artículos de belleza, venta de helados en la plaza de tupac amaru y siempre variando de trabajitos para mantener sus hogares e invertir en lo que en la época les proporcione ganancias. Los socios requieren el préstamo para poder reinvertir en sus diferentes pequeños negocios.

Ellos valoran y agradecen el esfuerzo y apoyo brindado mediante este medio y de la misma manera se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus deudas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The partners of the community bank CHASKA, are members who are working together for the third time. They live in the city of Cusco.

Our partners do different kinds of work. They are retail shop owners, personally attending to their different businesses, such as restaurants, grocery stores, selling beauty supplies, selling ice cream in the Plaza de Tupac Amaru, and always varying their work in order to maintain their homes and invest in that which at the time will provide them with profits. The partners request the loan in order to reinvest in their different small businesses.

They value and are thankful for the effort and support offered through this means, and likewise, they promise to fulfill their payments in the time period established.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in small businesses

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
La señora Elena tiene 53 años D. edad,  vive en el distrito D. Laredo , provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta sexto D. primaria, tiene 5 hijos y solo 1 depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Elena se dedica a a la venta D. ropa para niños, caballeros y damas.
Con su primer crédito D. 300 soles compro abarrotes como: arroz, azucar,aceite,fideos,papas, gaseosas, golosinas, etc que vendía en su tienda. En la actualidad se dedica a la venta D. prenda D. vestir.
Con este crédito D. S/ 2,000 soles, lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra D. ropa para caballeros, damas y niños.
También comprará útiles escolares como: cuadernos, colores, lapiceros, lápices, goma, tijeras, etc
Elena  tiene como adecuar un espacio en su domicilio para poder vender los utiles escolares y poco  apoco anhela tener una librería .
texts.en:
53-year old Elena lives in the district of Laredo, Trujillo province, in the department of La Libertad, Peru. She is a businesswoman, has completed 6th graD. of primary school, and has five children, only one of whom is still financially dependent on her. She earns her living by selling clothing for children, men and women. With her first loan of 300 soles Elena bought food items such as rice, sugar, noodles, potatoes, soft drinks, and candy which which she sold in her store. Currently she only sells clothing. With this loan of 2,000 soles she will buy more clothing for men, women, and children. She also plans to buy school supplies such as notebooks, crayons, pencils, pens, erasers, scissors etc. She has maD. space in her house from which to sell these items, and hopes one day to open a bookstore.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and school supplies to sell in her store

loans.name: Irma

texts.es:
La señora Irma tiene 48 años D. edad vive en el distrito D. Laredo, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to D. secundaria , tiene 3 hijos , pero ninguno dependen D. ella económicamente.
Actualemnte Irma  se dedica  a la venta D. ropa para niños, caballeros y damas.
Con su primer crédito D. 300 soles compro productos D. limpieza como: desinfectantes, aromáticos, lejía, ácido muriático. etc. para el negocio que antes tenía.
Con este crédito D. S/ 2,000soles, lo invertirá en su actual negocio, en la compra D. ropa para caballeros, damas y niños.
Irma tiene como sueño tener un stand D. ropa para todas las edades en un centro comercial D. Trujillo
texts.en:
Irma is 48 years old, lives in Laredo district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Peru. The businesswoman has completed 5th year of secondary school, has 3 children, but none of them are economically dependent upon her. Today Irma sells clothing for children, men, and women. With her first loan for 300 soles she bought cleaning products such as disinfectants, air fresheners, bleach, and muriatic acid, etc. for the business that she used to have. With this loan for S./2000 soles, she will invest in her current business, buying clothing for men, women and children. Irma dreams of having a clothing for people of all ages in a stand in the Trujillo central market.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing for children, men, and women.

loans.name: Bakary

texts.fr:
Monsieur Bakary Diakité est âgé de 24 ans, sans enfant, il vit avec sa femme dans la grande famille, chez son père dans le quartier Massablacoura de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Bakary Diakité n’a pas été inscrit par ses parents à l’école pour des raisons sociales. Très vite il commença les activités  génératrices de revenus. Il a tenté pendant des années différentes activités sans succès. Il finit par opter, apprendre le métier de soudeur,  auprès de son oncle maternel. Avec une expérience de 8 ans auprès de ce dernier,  Bakary Diakité maîtrise bien ce métier et est très apprécié et sollicité à Bougouni.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires pour mieux rentabiliser son atelier (en l’équipant de courant électrique indispensable pour son activité), il décida d’intégrer le programme de crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Ce prêt servira à payer les frais d’abonnement au réseau électrique de la Société Énergie du Mali (EDM) de son atelier situé dans son quartier de résidence.
Avec une clientèle est composée de toutes les catégories sociales, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour améliorer davantage son entreprise.
Il ambitionne  attirer plus de  clientèle et mieux les satisfaire.
texts.en:
Mr. Bakary Diakité, age 24, has no children. He lives with his wife in a large family in his father's place in the Massablacoura district of Bougouni City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). He was not placed into school by his parents due to societal reasons. Soon, he started earning an income. For some years, he tried different businesses without success. He ultimately opted to learn the trade of welding from his maternal uncle. With eight years of experience with his uncle, Bakary now has a good command of this trade and is much appreciated and in high demand in Bougouni. In his search for supplemental financial resources to make his workshop more profitable (by equipping it with the electrical power indispensable for his work), Bakary decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He is now on his first individual loan. This loan will be used to cover the costs of joining the power grid of the energy company of Mali Société Énergie du Mali (EDM) for his workshop located in the area where he lives. With customers from all walks of life, he envisions realizing a monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used to improve his enterprise. His ambition is to attract more customers and to do better in satisfying them.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Subscription to the electrical grid (EDM)

loans.name: Irma Martha

texts.es:
La señora Irma Martha tiene  51 años D. edad vive en el distrito D. Laredo , provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to D. secundaria , tiene 5 hijos y solo 1 depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Irma D. dedica a  la venta D. productos D. belleza como: colonias, perfumes, talcos, cremas, etc., D. las marcas Unique, Esika y Avon.
Con su primer crédito D. 300 soles compró mas productos D. belleza lo cual le permitió aumentar su stock y vender con mayor facilidad

Con este crédito D. S/. 1,200, lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra D. ropa para caballeros, damas y niño. Así como en la compra D. productos D. belleza.
Irma tiene como sueño tener un stand D. ropa y productos D. belleza en el mercado.
texts.en:
Martha is 51 years old, lives in Laredo district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Peru. The businesswoman has completed 5th year of secondary school, has 5 children, and only 1 is economically dependent upon her. Today Martha sells beauty products such as: cologne, perfume, powders, creams, etc. from manufacturers such as Unique, Esika and Avon. With her first loan for 300 soles she bought beauty products which enabled her to increase her stock and sell more easily. With this loan for S./1200 soles, she will invest in her business, buying clothing for men, women and children as well as beauty products. Martha dreams of having a clothing and beauty product stand in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing for men, women and children as well as beauty products.

loans.name: Señor De Los Milagros De Chimpahuaylla Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “SEÑOR D. LOS MILAGROS D. CHIMPAHUAYLLA”, se encuentra ubicado a 35 minutos D. la ciudad del Cusco perteneciente aún ala comunidad D. Chimpahuaylla.

Nuestros socios alternan sus diferentes actividades con los negocios, ellos tienen pequeños comercios, son vendedores D. salchipapas, (comida rápida, elaborada a base D. salchichas fritas con papas fritas), venden granos (maíz, habas, cebada, trigo), venta D. verduras, algunos son docentes y otros tienen sus tiendas D. abarrotes, los socios requieren el préstamo para poder invertir en sus diferentes negocios y D. esa manera mejorar sus servicios.

Los socios se encuentran agradecidos con el préstamo otorgado y el apoyo prestado mediante este medio y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago D. sus deudas en el tiempo establecido.
texts.en:
The Señor D. los Milagros D. Chimpahuaylla Community Bank is located 35 minutes from the city of Cusco in the Chimpahuaylla community. Their members have different, small businesses. Some sell “salchipapas” (fast food maD. from fried sausages and fried potatoes), grains (corn, beans, barley, wheat), and vegetables. Some are teachers and others have grocery stores. The members need a loan to invest in their different businesses. That way they can improve their services. The members are appreciative of the loan and the support given this way, and they promise to pay their debts on time as agreed upon.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Set up small businesses

loans.name: Betty Soledad

texts.es:
La señora BETTY SOLEDAD tiene  51 años D. edad vive en el distrito D. Laredo , provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to D. secundaria , tiene 3 hijos y solo 1 depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Betty tiene una tienda en su casa en la cual venD. abarrotes como: arroz , azúcar, aceite, fideos, gaseosas, jugos, golosinas, tarjetas D. celulares, etc
Con su primer crédito D. 300 soles compro productos D. belleza lo cual le permitió aumentar su stock.
Con este crédito D. S/. 800.00, lo invertirá en la compra D. mas abarrotes, golosinas, jugos, gaseosas, útiles D. escritorios, tarjetas D. telefónica, etc
Betty tiene como sueño abastecer mas su tienda y vender todo lo que sus clientes necesiten.
texts.en:
La señora BETTY SOLEDAD tiene 51 años D. edad vive en el distrito D. Laredo , provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to D. secundaria , tiene 3 hijos y solo 1 depenD. económicamente D. ella. Betty tiene una tienda en su casa en la cual venD. abarrotes como: arroz , azúcar, aceite, fideos, gaseosas, jugos, golosinas, tarjetas D. celulares, etc Con su primer crédito D. 300 soles compro productos D. belleza lo cual le permitió aumentar su stock. Con este crédito D. S/. 800.00, lo invertirá en la compra D. mas abarrotes, golosinas, jugos, gaseosas, útiles D. escritorios, tarjetas D. telefónica, etc Betty tiene como sueño abastecer mas su tienda y vender todo lo que sus clientes necesiten.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries, candy,  juices, soda pop, office supplies, cell phone cards, etc.

loans.name: Arcoiris Group 2

texts.en:
Marcia M. D., pictured in the middle, is the coordinator of her five-member group. She resides in Carlo Alvares, a small town in the sector of Villa Mella, part of Santo Domingo Norte. Marcia is a single mother and lives with her two sons. The youngest is 16, and is a senior in high school and wants to study electronics. The eldest, 18, is a sophomore in college who wants to study informational engineering and is learning Japanese. Marcia has had six years of experience working as a massage therapist, going home to home.

With this loan she plans to buy two massage machines that would help her avoid unnecessary strain on her hands, so she can have more sessions per day. She would also invest in massage lotions and ointments to sell which boost her income. Through Esperanza, Marcia plans to take marketing courses in order to become a better businesswoman.

Through the additional income from her business as a result of this loan, Marcia hopes to be able to pay for her son's college without it being such a huge burden on her household. She also hopes to begin to save part of her income so her eldest son can study abroad in Japan in a year or two. One of her dreams is to open her own aesthetic center, where she would have others work for her, and only attend lifelong customers, while she manages the business.

Marcia will share this loan with the other members of her group.

loans.use: Massage machines, massage ointments and lotions

loans.name: Mercedes Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Mercedes tiene 37 años de edad, reside en el barrio Hialeah, casada, y con dos hijos de 10 y 14 años de edad que cursan la, su esposo es pensionado. Su negocio es la venta de enchilada y otra variedad de fritanga anteriormente vendía productos de cosméticos, tiene un año de vender comida, lo inicio con el propósito de obtener mejores ganancias ya que la comida se vende diario, este es su cuarto ciclo en Afodenic el cual va invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, bloques, hierros, cemento entre otros para construir un cuarto y poder estar en mejores condiciones junto a su familia. Da las gracias a la institución por el apoyo para lograr su objetivo de mejorar su vivienda como ayudar a sus hijos que estudien.
texts.en:
Mercedes is 37 years old, lives in the Hialeah neighborhood, is married, has two children ages 10 and 14 who are in school, her husband is a pensioner. Her business is selling enchiladas and other fried snacks. Previously she sold cosmetics. She has been selling food for a year, and began with the idea of obtaining greater income because food she can sell daily. This is her fourth loan cycle with Afodenic. She will invest in buying construction materials such as: rock, sand, blocks, iron, cement and other items to be able to build a room and have better living conditions for her family. She is grateful to Afodenic for its support in helping her achieve her objective of improving her home in turn helping her school-aged children.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials to build a room

loans.name: Las Pariguanas Group

texts.es:
Los socios de la comunidad de Yarcaccunca, integran un banco comunal llamado “LAS PARIGUANAS”, estos socios viven a 2 horas de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestros socios alternan sus diferentes actividades del hogar con la agricultura y la ganadería, ellos trabajan la tierra, siembran tubérculos y verduras, también cereales de acuerdo ala época, nuestros socios viven de la venta de sus productos, para lo cual requieren el préstamo para poder comprar las semillas, algunos animales y alquilar terrenos para tener mayor producción en su nueva cosecha.

Los socios se encuentran muy agradecidos y valorando el préstamo se comprometen a cumplir con el pago total de su deuda en el tiempo establecido.
texts.en:
The members of the Yarcaccunca community make up a communal bank called “Las Pariguanas.” These members live 2 hours from the city of Cusco. Our members have different activities in the home around agriculture and livestock. They farm, grow tubers and vegetables, also grains depending on the season. Our members earn a living by selling their products. They require a loan to be able to buy the seeds, some animals, and rent the land in order to have a greater production in their new crop. The members are very grateful and value the loan. The promise to pay their entire loan within the established timeframe.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seeds and rent farmland.

loans.name: Erick Danilo

texts.es: El joven Erick Danilo L. es un hombre trabajador desde hace seis años se dedica ala venta de queso, frijoles y ropa el cual inicio con fondos propios y con la experiencia ya que su mama tiene este tipo de negocio. Sus planes es poder tener su  propia casa. Tiene 23 años de edad, casado y le tienen una niña de tres años de edad. Este es su segundo ciclo en Afodenic el cual va invertir en inventario en la compra de ropa y granos básicos para ofertar  a sus clientes y poder tener mejores ganancias. Su objetivo es poder tener una tienda en el mercado oriental ya que es el mercado mas visitado por los nicaragüenses por sus bonitos y baratos productos en general. Da las gracias a la institución por los logros alcanzado en su negocio.
texts.en:
Erick Danilo L. is a hard-working man. He has been selling cheese, beans and clothing for six years, a business he began with his own savings and with the experience he gained as his mother has this type of business. His plans are to be able to have his own home. He is 23 years old, married, and he has a three year old daughter. This is his second loan with Afodenic, which he will invest in buying an inventory of clothing and basic grains to offer his customers and be able to have greater profits. His objective is to be able to have a store in the oriental market as it is the market Nicaraguans visit the most because of its variety and inexpensive products. He is grateful to Afodenic for the achievements he has been able to accomplish in his business.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing and basic grains

loans.name: Albertina Eliana

texts.es:
La señora Eliana, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Flor Azangarina II”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 38 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 3 hijos, ella tiene estudios de segundaria completa,  vive en el Barrio Vilcapaza.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 02 años, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, se retiro 1 año y medio por motivos de viaje,  ahora ella vuelve para continuar su negocio de  compra y venta de ropas. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 500.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de ropas para adultos en todas sus tallas, así como chompas, pantalones, camisas, medias, truzas, etc.

Su mayor sueño es poder ampliar su negocio, y darles estudios a sus hijos para que sean profesionales.

A ella le gustan los ahorros, y los encuentros de los Bancos Comunales
texts.en:
Eliana belongs to the Flor Azangarina II Community Bank, which is located in the Azangaro district, Azangaro province, Puno department. She is a 38 year old single mother with three children. She has a high school degree. She lives in the Vilcapaza neighborhood. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for two years. Her first loan was for 500 PEN. She withdrew for a year and a half because of a trip. Now she has returned to continue her business of buying and selling clothes. She now needs a loan for 500 PEN to buy adult clothes in all sizes. She will buy sweaters, pants, shirts, socks, and underwear, etc. Her biggest dream is to expand her business and give her children an education so that they can become professionals. She likes the savings and the meetings in her Community Bank.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pants, shirts, socks, and underwear, etc.

loans.name: Haydee De Jesús

texts.es: Haydee D. Jesús O. D. G. D. 45 años D. edad, resiD. en Cojutepeque junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos. Ella posee un bazar en el mercado D. Antonio Mejía en Cojutepeque y comercializa ropa, zapatos accesorios para el cabello, regalos para toda ocasión y así mismo cajas y bolsas para guardar los regalos. Haydee solicita un préstamo ya que desea surtir su negocio, ella desea aprovechar al máximo las ventas que realiza y es por esto D. espera obtener más productos para su negocio y así mismo obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Haydee D. Jesús O. D. G. is 45 years old and lives in Cojutepeque with her husband the three children. She owns a bazaar in the Antonio Mejía market in Cojutepeque and sells clothing, shoes, hair accessories, and all occasion gifts as well as boxes and bags to store gifts. Haydee is seeking a loan so she can stock her business. She wants to take the maximum advantage of the sales and in this way she hopes to obtain more products for her business and generate greater profits.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more merchandise for her bazaar

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: San Juan De Quihuares Group

texts.es:
Los socios del banco comunal “SAN JUAN DE QUIHUARES”, son de la provincia de Acomayo, ubicado a 3 horas de Cusco.

Los socios alternan sus actividades con la agricultura y la ganadería, ellos se dedican a cultivar sus tierras con los diferentes productos que la zona brinda, como es las diversas variedades de papa, el maíz, el trigo, la cebada, el olluco, la oca y verduras. Nuestros socios necesitan el préstamo para poder invertir en la compra de mayor numero de semillas y abonos para fertilizar sus tierras y en la compra de algunos ganados vacunos, que también los engordan y los venden, de igual manera sacan los derivados de la leche y hacen pequeños negocios con ellos. Aquí 8 socios se encuantran bailando para el Señor de Qoylloriti, que es una montaña con la copa nevada, que desde los tiempos de los Inkas se le rindió homenaje por ser parte de su Dios, el que les proveé de agua.

Los socios agradecen el préstamo otorgado y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago total de sus deudas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The members of the Communal Bank “San Juan de Quihuares” are from the Acomayo province, located 3 hours from Cusco. The members alternate their work between farming and livestock. They farm a variety of products in this area of the country, such as a varieties of potato, corn, wheat, barley, sweet potato, oca (a starchy tuber), and vegetables. Our members need a loan to be able to invest in buying a large number of seeds and fertilizer for their land and to buy some calves to fatten and sell as well as make dairy products from the milk and other small business sales. Here 8 members are dancing for the de Qoylloriti, which is a snow-capped mountain, which historically the Incas have provided homage to for being part of their God, providing them water. The members are grateful for the loan and they promise to repay it in its entirety within the established timeframe.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy livestock, seeds, and fertilizer

loans.name: Mujeres Con Cristo Group

texts.en:
Maricela M. leads the group Mujeres Con Cristo which translates to Women With Christ. She is asK. for her fourth loan from Esperanza for her business selling women’s clothes and shoes. She was chosen as the leader for her group because of her vast experience with Esperanza. She formed a new group because she moved to the Samana region, and had to leave her old group behind. Within days of moving to Samana, she easily organized a group of five women to approach Esperanza for a loan. She has the ability to quickly convince these women of how Esperanza can change their lives because it allows them to borrow money to invest in their own businesses.

As I said earlier, Maricela is on her fourth loan from Esperanza, and has an excellent reputation for repayment and for growth in her business. Her group is lucky to have her as a role model for conducting themselves in a successful business manner. She has used her previous three loans to go from selling on a very small scale from inside her home to a business where she is able to go through several neighborhoods each week to sell her products.

Her goals are to keep receiving loans from Esperanza in order to grow her business and to also recruit others in her neighborhood, so they can enjoy the benefits of investing in one’s own business.

loans.use: To purchase more women's clothing including shoes, blouses, shirts, etc.

loans.name: La Solucion 3 Group

texts.en:
Evelyn R. approached Esperanza a couple of months ago inquiring about how to receive a loan for her business selling bedspreads, sheets, soap, and other household items. After several meetings explaining the loan terms and putting together a group of five women, she is ready to accept her loan in order to invest in and grow her small business. This is a rare opportunity for someone in her economic status, and she reinforced several times how grateful she was and how she couldn’t wait for her business to grow with this new investment.

Evelyn explained that, with new loan, she would be able to increase her merchandise and also be able to explore new markets for her products. She explained she wants to grow her business in order to hopefully proviD. a better life for her children. She has two boys aged 11 and 3, and she has one daughter aged 15. She speaks very highly of her daughter who is an excellent student who has dreams of attending college and becoming a professional. She explained her boys are typical boys who both love playing baseball.

In the future, Evelyn hopes to expand her business through new loans, and her long term dream is to own real estate that she could rent out. She has ambitious goals, but she knows she has to start small in order to fulfill her long term goals.

loans.use: To purchase bedspreads, sheets, soap, and other household items

loans.name: Esteban

texts.es:
"El Señor Esteban S. C., tiene como actividad la venta de motores y repuestos de automóviles, actividad que realiza en la feria 16 de Julio de la ciudad de El Alto, el cliente actualmente es una persona muy responsable, con sus obligaciones.
Por la actividad que realiza el cliente necesita aumentar su capital de trabajo, ya que se especializa en la compra y venta de motores usados, los cuales los acomoda a los transportistas.
texts.en:
Mr. Esteban S. C. sells engines and car parts, a business he has on the 16 de Julio street in El Alto city. This client is very responsible with his obligations. This client needs working capital for his business since he specializes in buying used engines which he provides to those in public transportation.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es: Doña Rosario vive  en la zona urbana contiguo al mercado municipal de Nueva Guinea, está solicitando su 10mo credito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda en la Construccion de un pantriella necesita este prestamo para construir un pantri y asi brindarle mejor comodidad a su familia, trabaja como directora  en la casa de la mujer  desde hace 16 años, se caracteriza por ser una mujer emprendedora que ha ayudado a muchas mujeres campesinas y de la cuidad que vienen de diferentes comarca a dar a luz a sus bebes en la casa de la mujer,  Chayitoha hecho muchas gestiones por estas mujeres para darles alojamiento y comida y tambien se les imparten charlas de planificacion y como cuidar a sus bebes, ademas  es una mujer lider y ejemplo para todas la mujeresen Nueva Guinea, tambien se desempeña como consejal de la Alcaldia de Nueva Guinea, profesa la religion evangelica, su sueño es tener una vivienda con mejores condiciones, estabilidad laboral para así  ayudar a su familia y siempre seguir apoyando  al que lo necesita.
texts.en:
Rosario lives in the city next to the Nueva Guinea municipal market. She is seeking her 10th loan to invest in improving her home by building a pantry, thereby providing greater comfort to her family. She has worked as a director for a women’s home for 16 years, and is an enterprising woman who has helped many rural and urban women that come from different regions to give birth to their baby in the women’s home. She has made many efforts on behalf of these women, providing lodging and food and also family planning and baby care seminars. In addition to being a leader and role model for all the women in Nueva Guinea, she also works as a town councilor in Nueva Guinea and is an evangelical Christian. Her dream is having a home with better living conditions, steady work to support her family, and always able to continue supporting those who need it.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a room

loans.name: Sandra Maria

texts.es: Doña Sandra Maria es soltera, tiene 1 hija cursando el 5to grado de primaria, habita de  la zona Urbana de Nueva Guinea, esta solicitando su 6to crédito a AFODENIC para invertirlo en construccion de los servicios higienicos de su casa y de esta forma tener mejores condiciones de vida de ella y de su hija, esta clienta labora como docente de educacion secundaria en el Instituto Ruben Dario, a pesar que ella no tiene la ayuda de del padre de su hija ha podido darle lo necesario, por que ella ha luchado para que no le falte lo basico en el hogar,  Sandra es una mujer  trabajadora, responsable y con muchos deseos de superacion personal y profesional, ademas  a demostrado buena conducta y moral en la comunidad.
texts.en:
Sandra Maria is single and has one daughter in 5th grade in elementary school. She lives in the Urbana zone of Nueva Guinea. She is seeking her 6th loan from Afodenic to invest in building a bathroom in her home and in this way have better living conditions for herself and her daughter. She works as a teacher at Instituto Ruben Dario, a secondary school. In spite of not having her daughter’s father’s help, she has been able to give her daughter what she needs, for which she has fought hard so they have their basic needs at home met. Sandra is a hard-working, responsible, woman with great desire to succeed personally and professionally, in addition to demonstrating good and moral conduct in the community.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a bathroom

loans.name: Luis Alberto

texts.es: Luis Alberto es casado, trabaja en el CETA INATEC como sub- director desde hace 12 años, tiene una niña de 6 añitos estudia su 1er grado de educacion primaria, su esposa es ama de casa la cual se encarga del cuido de la niña y de los quehaceres del hogar; está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 8vo crédito para Construir los servicios Higienicos de su casa, se ha caracterizado por ser muy responsable, servicial,  honesto y muy trabajador que ha luchado por ir poco a poco mejorando su vivienda ubicada  en la zona # 4 de Nueva Guinea, es un hombre con alto espiritu de superación personal y laboral, su sueño es tener estabilidad, salud y una vivienda  bonita, este cliente se siente agradecido con AFODENIC, ya que con los créditos anteriores  ha logrado construir poco a poco su vivienda.
texts.en:
Luis Alberto is married and has worked in CETA INATEC as an assistant director for 12 years. He has a 6 year old daughter who is in first grade in elementary school. His wife is a housewife and is in charge of taking care of their daughter and their home. He is seeking a refinancing loan, his 8th loan cycle, to build a bathroom in his home. He is a very responsible, serving, honest, and hard-working man who has fought to improving their home little by little. Their home is located in the #4 zone of Nueva Guinea. He is a man with a high spirit to succeed personally and in his profession. His dream is to have stability, health, and a beautiful home. This client is grateful to Afodenic, as his previous loans have been used to little by little build his home.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a bathroom

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas 1 Group

texts.en:
With four children and 14 grandchildren, Altagracia is an absolutely wonderful grandmother who is currently on her seventh loan cycle with Esperanza. She owns a little building next to her house from which she sells gasoline to the passing motorcyclists and vehicles. She also offers repairs and she supplements these sales with her own homemade cookies, sweets and other treats. One of Altagracia’s grandchildren, Leonard, helps her with running the business when it comes to repairing motorcycles. Much of his time is spent working on motorcycles and repairing them, while Altagracia focuses on the sales of the gasoline and baked goodies.

Altagracia is excited to see her business continue to grow. Through the loan cycle progression at Esperanza, she was able to buy the little building next to her house and she has continually increased her inventory. Most recently, her loan has gone to buying gasoline, baking goods and parts for repairing motorcycles. She loves her business and for now is almost completely focusing on its growth and putting extra profits back into her enterprise. However, in the future, Altagracia wants to fix up her home a little bit, including finishing off a cement floor throughout her entire house. For now, most of her house has a floor – but some of it is still dirt.

Altagracia (second from left) is the coordinator of this group of five women within the Mujeres Unidas Bank of Hope near Samaná, Dominican Republic. Altagracia is very thankful for any help you can provide!

loans.use: To buy gasoline, motorcycle parts and baking supplies

loans.name: Saribel

texts.es: Saribel es casada,  vive en la comarca la  Ceiba a 9 km  de Nueva Guinea, trabaja como docente de esa comarca en la Escuela Manteles Verdes desde hace 10 años, tiene una niña de 9 años estudiando primaria, está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 8vo crédito con AFODENIC, ya obtuvo un credito con el financiamiento de KIVA para invertirlo en simpre en mejora de su vivienda construyendo satisfactoriamente una habitacion, ahora solicita un nuevo credito para continuar con las mejoras  cambiando el zinc a la cocina que esta en mal estado, su esposo trabaja como agricultor y la apoya con los gastos, todos los dias se levantan a las cuatro de la mañana para hacer los quehaceres del hogar, en la finca donde viven siembran diversos cultivos como yuca , quequisque, piña, sandias,  los cuales comercializar en la zona urbana de Nueva Guinea,  Saribel es una mujer que trabaja de la mano con su marido para asi mejor sus condiciones de vida,   su sueño  es  terminar de estudiar la carrera en ciencias de la Educacion, salud  y estabilidad laboral.
texts.en:
Saribel is married, lives in the La Ceiba district 9 km from Nueva Guinea, and has a 9 year old daughter in elementary school. She has been a teacher for 10 years in the Manteles Verdes school district.

She is requesting her 8th AFODENIC loan, which will be funded through KIVA, to continue improvements on her structurally-sound one bedroom house. She will be changing the zinc in her kitchen, which is in poor condition.

Her husband is a farmer and helps with the household expenses. He wakes up at 4am every morning to begin his work. He raises crops -- such as cassava, taro root, pineapple, and watermelon –- and sells them in the urban markets of Nueva Guinea. Saribel works closely with her husband to improve their living conditions. Her dream is to finish her studies in educational sciences, enjoy good health, and have a stable job.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replace the kitchen ceiling

loans.name: Bernardina

texts.es:
"La señora Bernardina F. C., tiene como actividad la venta de ají y condimentos esta actividad la realiza en Caranavi, poblacion a unos 200 kilometros de la ciudad de La Paz, los días lunes, martes, miércoles, y jueves.
La cliente actualmente es una persona muy responsable, con sus obligaciones, siendo cliente antigua de Emprender quien trabaja cumpliendo con nuestra institución.
texts.en:
Señora Bernardina F. C. works at selling chili peppers and condiments in Caranavi, which is located some 200 kilometers (125 miles) from the city of La Paz. She works Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. This client has thus far been very responsible with her payments, and is a long-term client of Emprender who works to meet the requirements of that institution.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es: El sr. Ricardo se dedica al servicio de transporte, tiene su movilidad que trabaja como radio taxi, vive con su esposa y sus hijos pequeños, en una casita ubicada en Valle de las Flores. Recientemente en sociedad con dos amigos adquirió una empresa de radio taxis, con que están empezando a trabajar, es una persona muy responsable y muy puntual, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de una computadora y aparatdo telefónicos para la microempresa y así mejorar el servicio.
texts.en:
Señor Ricardo works at public transit; he has a vehicle which he uses as a radio taxi. He lives with his wife and small children in a house located in the Valle del las Flores (Valley of the Flowers). Recently, he and two friends acquired a radio taxi business which they have begun to operate. He is a very responsible person and very punctual. The loan will be used to purchase a computer and telephone equipment for the business so that they can improve their service.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a computer and telephone equipment

loans.name: Marianela

texts.es: La Srta. Marianela C. C., tiene como actividad economica la venta de Pan y Galletas en su puesto de venta que esta ubicado en la Av. Manco Kapac y Av. Buenos Aires, actividad que desarrolla todos los dias, constituyendose en su principal fuente de ingreso para ella y su familia. Su familia esta constituida por dos hijos, a los que ella con su actividad los hace estudiar, ya que el esposo se fue a buscar horizontes mejores para su familia a la republica Argentina.
texts.en:
Señorita Marianela C. C. works at selling bread and cookies at her stand which is located at the corner of Manco Kapac and Buenos Aires Avenues. She does this every day as this represents her principal source of income for herself and her family. Her family includes her two children and this is also how she pays for their school expenses, since her husband has gone to look for better opportunities for their family in the Republic of Argentina.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk products to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Rogelia Rosario

texts.es: La Sra. Rogelia Rosario C. A., tiene como actividad economica la fabricacion de muebles de estilo antiguo (Luis XV) los mismos que vende a distintas tiendas y a pedidos especiales, que es su principal fuente de ingreso para ella y su familia. El esposo es el que diseña los muebles y los construye, la Sra. Rogelia es la los vende.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rogelia Rosario C. A. operates a business that specializes in furniture in the style of Louis XV. She sells the furniture in different stores and by special order. This is the main source of income for her and her family. Mrs. Rogelia’s husband is responsible for designing and building the various pieces, while she handles all sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wood for making furniture

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es: La Sra. Esperanza P. Q., tiene como actividad económica la fabricación de azas para ollas, cacerolas, sartenes y otras, las cuales distribuye a las diferentes fabricas de ollas, actividad que realiza juntamente con su hija y un empleado que le ayudan en dicha actividad, que es la fuente de ingreso para ella y su familia; se encuentra separada de su esposo.
texts.en:
Esperanza P. Q.’s economic activity is making handles for pots, saucepans, frying pans, etc., which she distributes to different kitchenware factories. She performs this activity together with her daughter and an employee who helps them. This business is the source of income for her and her family; she is currently separated from her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a compressor and tools for her workshop

loans.name: Unidos Para Progresar Group 1

texts.en:
Miguelina D. L. S. is a 29-year-old single mother of three children, ages 9, 7 and 4. With her first loan she opened her own store selling jewelry and for the past three years it has been growing. She says her store has been successful because she has a lot of young women as customers who like the style of jewelry she sells. With this loan she will buy more bracelets, necklaces and rings from the nearby town of San Pedro to sell in her store.

Miguelina has successfully completed five loan cycles and is excited at the possibility of increasing her business even more. With her past loans, Miguelina has been able to keep her children well fed and healthy. Her dream is to one day own her own house and make enough money to send her children to college. With this loan she will be one step closer to achieving her dreams.

Miguelina is the leader of the group Unidos Para Progresar 1 (Progressing Together) which takes out microloans as a group in Hato Mayor, Dominican Republic. On behalf of Miguelina and everyone in the Unidos Para Progresar group, thank you for the opportunities you proviD. to the people who need them most!

loans.use: To buy bracelets, necklaces and rings

loans.name: Cinthia Mercedes

texts.es: La señora Cinthia es una persona joven y muy trabajadora. Se dedica a la venta de masitas (pastele), ella prepara las masitas en su casa y su especialidad son las "Llauchas" (empanadas con queso), una especie de empanada grande y con mucho queso. Además también hace pasteles y tortas para cumpleaños y matrimonios. Vive en su casa de la Calle 5 de Pampahasi junto a su esposo Omar y sus dos hijos pequeños. Cinthia inició esta actividad hace dos años y actualmente solicita el crédito para una tienda que funcionará como puesto adicional de venta de las masitas. Ella es una persona muy responsable con su trabajo y dedicada con su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Cinthia is a hardworking young woman. She sells “masitas” (a type of pastry), which she prepares from her home. Her specialty is "Llauchas", a large empanada filled with lots of cheese. She also bakes pies and cakes for birthdays and weddings.

She lives in a house on #5 Pampahasi Street with her husband Omar and their two young children. Cinthia started her business two years ago and is requesting a loan so that she can open a store where she can sell more pastries. She is very responsible at her work and dedicated to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase two display cases and pay 3 months rent

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Rosalia’s Daycare is a home-based daycare that cares for and educates a total of fourteen children, ages 2 months to 9 years. The owner, Maria, started the business five years ago and her husband and kids play an active role in caring for the children as well. Maria’s husband works in construction, but with the current economic situation, work has been slow for him and the income from her daycare is the only consistent source of financial support for their family of four children. The steady income has also helped pay for her oldest daughter’s education.
 
Maria says that she is not confident in her English skills and was always concerned that this language barrier would prevent her from getting a loan. For quite a while Maria had been making a list of all the furniture, games, and supplies she needed for the fourteen youngsters she cares for.
 
Maria believes strongly in giving back to the community. She currently has a few clients who can’t afford to pay for childcare and she offers reduced fees. She says that she knows what it’s like to struggle and wants to help people if she can.
 
Maria takes pride in educating the children and wants to continue to improve her center to provide quality care and ensure all her children are motivated to graduate from high school and go on to college.

loans.use: To buy furniture, books, and games for her daycare

loans.name: Juan Gerardo

texts.es:
Juan Gerardo V. U. trabaja como bombero desde hace 4 años en esta ciudad al servicio de la comunidad, aunque es un trabajo muy importante y riesgoso no tienen tantos beneficios como casas de interés social que le mismo gobierno da la oportunidad de adquirir pagando poco.  Entonces el opto por conseguir una vivienda por medio de su hermano y esta pagando. Pero ahora el se ve a la necesidad de pedir un préstamo en esta institución ya que el Señor ha tenido varios intentos de robos y el teme que perder algo  de su casa que con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación a comprado a lo largo de los años.
Para que su hija y su esposa estén protegidas ante la delincuencia el quiere comprar protecciones para poner en las ventanas de su casa.
texts.en:
Juan Gerardo V. U. has worked as a firefighter in his city for 4 years. Even though this is a very important and risky job, there are not many benefits apart from government housing, which the government offers at low cost. Juan chose instead to buy a house through his brother. He is currently asking for a loan because there have been several attempted burglaries at his home, and he is afraid to lose anything from his house, since he has put much effort and dedication into purchasing things over the years. Juan wants to purchase safety bars to install on the windows of his home so that he can protect his wife and daughter against crime.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Protecting his home

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en:
Pilar R. P. is a member (and the official secretary) of the communal bank “Manos Maravillosas” (Marvelous Hands) and lives in the city of Pucallpa. Pilar sells cooked food at a seasonal restaurant next to the sawmills located along the Ucayali River, which flows past the city. During the winter months, when the water level rises with the frequent rains, Pilar must move her restaurant further inland. Pilar sells soups, grilled meat and fish, stews and other local dishes. Many of her customers are the men who work at the sawmills.

Pilar has been working with Manuela Ramos for five years and used her very first loan to purchase items for a small shop that she had at that time. Pilar will use this loan of 2,000 Nuevos Soles to purchase food items such as rice, sugar, oil and meats for her restaurant.

Pilar is married and has three children, aged 17, 15 and 12. She works hard to save money through Manuela Ramos’s mandatory savings program. Her primary motivation for working and saving is the improvement of her children’s future.

According to Pilar, Manuela Ramos has been a great help. Loans from Manuela Ramos allow women like her to invest in activities they know how to do and earn money—without this capital, many would not be able to work.

loans.use: To buy food items for her restaurant

loans.name: Buyanjargal

texts.en:
Buyanjargal B. lives with his wife and two small children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His oldest son is 10 years old and goes to a local school and his 4-year-old daughter goes to a local kindergarten.

Buyanjargal has a small business in local freight transportation. He owns a truck that he uses for transporting wood between woodcutters and the local market for cut wood. He has been in the transportation business since 2000 and is known by his business in the town. In the last nine years, his business capital has expanded from 100,000 MNT to 4,000,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT). His wife also helps in his transportation business. In the future, he hopes to reinvest his profit and replace old tires with new good ones.

Buyanjargal requests a loan to purchase fuel and some accessories for his truck.

loans.use: To purchase fuel and accessories for his truck

loans.name: Tuul

texts.en:
Tuul M. lives with her husband and two teenage children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her 14- and 18-year-old daughters are high school students in the town.

Tuul makes various household items and souvenirs from esgii. Esgii is a hand-made felt and commonly used to make various household items, including toys, and even shoes. She has been making felt products since 2004 and has been quite successful as her business capital has increased from 200,000 MNT to 800,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT) in five years. She is recognized by her work in the town and she usually makes her felt products upon locals' requests. In the future, she hopes to open her own small-scale factory, producing felt-products for locals.

Tuul requests a loan to purchase more felt for her business.

loans.use: To purchase wool as a raw material

loans.name: Lira

texts.en:
Lira V. C. has a small stand in front of her home where she sells candy, snacks and cigarettes. She also has a business with her sister-in-law selling clothing in rural areas outside the city. With this loan of 1800 nuevos soles, Lira plans to invest in more items for her stand as well as clothing for her shared venture with her sister-in-law.

Lira lives with her partner and their five children, ranging in age from 3 to 21. She is a member of the communal bank Manos Maravillosas (Marvellous Hands) and lives in the city of Pucallpa. Lira has been working with Manuela Ramos for five years and invested her very first loan in candies for her business. According to Lira, Manuela Ramos has been a great help. She has had a good experience working with this organization and appreciates the fact that the interest rates are not too high. Lira eventually hopes to sell more and expand her business by putting up a kiosk in front of her home.

loans.use: To buy clothing and also candies and snacks to sell

loans.name: Batdulam

texts.en:
Batdulam B. lives with her husband and two small daughters in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her oldest daughter's name is Zolzaya and she goes a local secondary school. The youngest daughter, Monhzaya, is 3 years old and goes to a local kindergarten.

Batdulam's husband has a small business in local freight transportation. She owns a small truck that is used for transportating various products between local towns. Although she started this transportation business last year, she has done well and her business capital has increased from 80,000 Mongolian tugriks to 200,000 tugriks (US $55 to $139).

Batdulam and her husband say that they would like to see their daughters well educated and they are working hard to make their dreams come true. Batdulam requests a loan to purchase necessary accessories and fuel for the truck in their business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts and fuel

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma C. M. is a member of the communal bank “Manos Maravillosas” (Marvellous Hands) and lives in the city of Pucallpa. She has a small cart from which she sells cooked foods such as french fries and hot dogs, fried chicken, hamburgers, and “juanes” (a rice dish typical of the region). Every evening Irma brings her cart out to the main road near her home to sell her meals. Irma’s two adult daughters (aged 20 and 21) help her with this business.

Irma has been working with Manuela Ramos for 2.5 years and plans to invest this loan of 1500 Nuevos Soles in new pots and food for her business.

Irma is separated from her husband and lives with her three children; the youngest is a 13-year-old son. All depend on her. Irma is very thankful to be working with Manuela Ramos. With the help of her loans from Manuela Ramos Irma has been able to expand her business, improve her home, and purchase many basic household items. Although Irma has health problems, she wants to continue working at her food cart at least until January in order to support one of her daughters through university. At that time she hopes her eldest daughter can take over most of the work so Irma can dedicate herself to a less strenuous job.

loans.use: Food and new pots for the business

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria S. V. D. R. is a primary school teacher. She also sells clothing, jewelry and beauty products out of her home. In the mornings she teaches and in the afternoons she dedicates herself to her business. Gloria is widowed and has three children. The two youngest, ages 22 and 11, still depend on her. Her 22-year-old is finishing a university degree.

Gloria is a member of the communal bank Manos Maravillosas (Marvellous Hands) and lives in the city of Pucallpa. She has been working with Manuela Ramos for about five years and used her first loan to purchase clothing to sell. With this loan of 3000 nuevos soles, Gloria will purchase more clothing from Lima to expand her inventory.

Gloria has been pleased to be able to expand her business venture with the help of Manuela Ramos. Gloria’s goals are to help her children have professional careers and to eventually have her own little shop in the center of town where she can sell her goods.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma E. owns and operates a business venture running a sari-sari (variety) store and videoke machine. Her main source of income comes from selling a variety of different products in her community. Elma is just starting this business. She is 41 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Zone 4, Kabacsanan, Iligan City.

In 2009, Elma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business and to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for a sari-sari store

location.town: Zone 4, Kabacsanan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Lastenia

texts.en:
Lastenia G. L. has her own small shop where she sells cold drinks and also runs a taxi transportation service together with her husband. Lastenia has many goals for her drink-selling business--she wants to eventually purchase a larger refrigerator and refurbish her business locale in order to begin selling groceries as well. She also hopes to purchase additional cars for the transportation enterprise she shares with her husband.

Lastenia has two children, one of whom (an 18-year-old son currently studying at a local university) is still dependent on her. She is also raising her 6-year-old niece.

Lastenia is a member, and the official treasurer, of the communal bank Manos Maravillosas (Marvelous Hands) and lives in the city of Pucallpa. Lastenia has been working with Manuela Ramos for 2.5 years and used her first loan to start her drink-selling business. Lastenia will invest this loan of 1700 nuevos soles in more inventory for her business. Lastenia is thankful for the support she has received from Manuela Ramos and is very pleased that things have been going well with her business.

loans.use: To purchase more soft drinks and juices

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion T. makes and sells homemade food products. The main source of income for her business comes from selling rice cakes and bibingka (a type of pudding) in the local community. She is 35 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Purok 14, Kabacsanan, Iligan City. Salvacion has been in this business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

Salvacion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business and to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a food business

location.town: Purok 14, Kabacsanan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta is a loving wife to Roberto and a good mother to their three children. Her husband used to operate a tricycle but due to sickness, they let their neighbor drive their tricycle and now just ask for a fee for their boundaries. Violeta is 50 years old and she has been managing a hog-raising business for almost ten years. To further improve her business, she is now requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP as additional capital. Through her business, she can continue to support the needs of her family and provide medication for her husband.

Their children are: Albert - 26 years old, high school graduate, now working as a helper in a feeds factory; Anime - 23 years old, college graduate; and their youngest is April - 19 years old, first year college.

She hopes that her children will have a better future and hopes that she can put up her own vending stall through God’s grace.

loans.use: Capital for hog-raising business

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli manages a general store in their village in Research Minante 1, Cauayan City. She is 53 years old and married to Danilo, a driver. The couple is blessed with four children. According to Arceli, people in their community are hard-working and are doing their best to surpass the hardships of life. 

Arceli wants to borrow PHP10,000. She is positive that this amount can improve her store and also increase her income. She wants to develop her business so she can assist her husband in providing for the needs of their family and, most important, the needs of their children. She wants her business become productive and for this, she is patiently doing her best.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Filomena

texts.en:
Filomena manages a hog raising business in her village. She is now 43 years old and resides in Barangay Research Minante 1, Cauayan City. The community where she lives has access to a market and most of the residents are involved in labor and small enterprise. Filomena is married to Fred and blessed with two children: Finalyn - 17 years old and a college freshmen and Princess Nińa - 8 years old and a grade 3 student. 

Filomena manages a hog raising business and at the same time, she is also engaged in retail/wholesale trading of rice grain. She usually earns a monthly income of PHP4,000.00, which she needs to budget for her family.  She is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders of PHP15,000.00.  She plans to use the loan for the improvement of her small businesses.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Juvelyn

texts.en:
Juvelyn Q. is from the village of Purok 11, Bangko Bonbonon, Iligan City. She is 30 years old. Juvelyn is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Juvelyn works in someone else's business selling coco shell products and making and selling food products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling coco shells in the local community. Juvelyn is just starting the making and selling of food products business.

Juvelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juvelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase coco shells and ingredients for her food business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Juvelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase coco shells and ingredients

location.town: Purok 11, Bangko, Bonbonon, Iligan City, Lanao del

loans.name: Max

texts.en:
Max N. is 38 years old and still single.  He is a manufacturer of polvoron (a powdered milk candy, made of flour, sugar, butter and powdered milk, and shaped into round or oval molds) and a hog raiser. He resides with his family in Barangay Research Minante 1 of Cauayan City. 
Aside from managing his small businesses, Max is also working in the City Hall of Cauayan as a simple staff.  He decided to set up his own business for additional income to support the education of his siblings.  All his sacrifices are for the welfare of his family.  Due to lack of capital, Max would like a loan of PHP 15,000 from the Kiva lenders.  This amount will help him in meeting the demands of his customers who are requesting his products. Aside from selling them in his office, he also delivers some of it to some stores in the village.  He wishes to become successful someday through his businesses.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly C. operates a hog raising business and food processing business at the same time. She is now requesting a loan of PHP10,000 that she can use to support her small businesses.  She hopes that Kiva lenders will grant her request so she can help her husband in providing a better life for their family.  
	
She used to manage a store for five years but then due to some problems, her business failed so she decided to venture into hog raising and food processing.  Merly is 39 years old and her husband, Fernando, is working as a welder abroad.  They have two children: one already stopped his studies and the other one is currently in high school.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly is 45 years old and already a widow.  She makes her income from vending different merchandise to support the needs of her four children. Her eldest child is helping her to earn a living to support the education of her three children who are all in high school.  They are living in the large village of Research Minante 1 of Cauayan City, Isabela.
	
At the moment, she is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders of PHP8,000.  She plans to use the loan to purchase more products that she can sell in their village.  She usually roams inside or outside their village by walking just to sell her products.  She does not care how hard it is, she just wants to provide a better life for her children.  She hopes that Kiva will give her the opportunity to make her business grow and become progressive.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn S. is from the village of Kabacsanan, Iligan City. She is 29 years old. Jocelyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a business making & selling ice and ice candies. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling ice and ice candies in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month for these activities.

Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her product offering

location.town: Kabacsanan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 40 years old and married to Rodel who is working in a funeral parlor and part-time as a tricycle operator. They have three children: Richard - 23 years old, college graduate; Rodelyn - 20 years old, H.R.M. graduate and their youngest daughter Rachelle - 18 years old, third year college student. Her family resides in Barangay Research Minante 1, Cauayan City. 
Myrna would like to borrow a loan of PHP15,000 for the improvement of the hog raising business that she has been managing for almost three years.  She believes that this amount will really help her maintain her business and increase her income.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina G. is married to Samuel who works part time as a house carpenter in their village. At the age of 35 years, she and her husband are now blessed with four children. Three of them are currently studying but unfortunately, the other one is not due to lack of financial assistance. Cristina aims to send her children to college but she is worried that somehow she can’t afford to do so. However, she is not losing hope. 

Upon learning about the Kiva loans, Cristina was encouraged to join and asked for PHP13,000 to further improve her general store business. If ever her loan will be granted, Cristina plans to buy more products for her store. She also intends to use the loan to venture into fish vending as part of her business expansion. Being a smart woman, she carefully budgets her income in order to support her family and her children’s education as well. She really is hoping to improve her small business in their community.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Dhalia

texts.en:
Dhalia is a hardworking mother. She sacrifices a lot for the welfare of her family. She used to venture in different businesses to help her husband improve their poor living conditions. She thinks positively and works out the things that are good in the eyes of the people around her. 

Dhalia now manages a vegetable vending stall in their house. Aside from vegetables, she is also raising a backyard piggery. To further improve her business, Dhalia is requesting a from Kiva lenders of PHP18,000. She is now 52 years old and has seven children. Three of them are now married and some are still currently attending school. Her husband is a local farmer in their place. She hopes someday that her business will become successful for the progress of their daily living.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga and her husband live happily in the village of Nabbotuan Solana, Cagayan, where farming is the main livelihood of most residents. Her husband has a skill in woodcarvings and carpentry thus, sometimes works in that type of labor on a part-time basis. They are blessed with 10 children who serve as their inspiration to improve their humble living conditions. 

Raising pigs in their backyard is her source of income. In lieu of this, she is borrowing a loan of PHP15,000 from Kiva lenders to support her hog raising business financially and to buy enough supply of feed to further grow her livestock. She hopes that through this, she can help her husband generate more income for the studies of their children, which she really wants to give their children more than anything else.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Renalyn

texts.en:
Renalyn V. is from the village of Zone 14, Kabacsanan, Iligan City. She is 26 years old. Renalyn is married. To make a living, Renalyn owns & operates a business making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling rice cakes in the local community. Renalyn has been engaged in her business over a year and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In June 2009, Renalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Renalyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Renalyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients

location.town: Zone 14, Kabacsanan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Emiliana

texts.en:
Emiliana raises pigs to help her husband support and improve their poor living situation. She is now 54 years old and a mother of five who are all married. Her husband is a local farmer in their community. They live in the rural area of Nabbotuan Solana, Cagayan.
 In order to support her hog raising feed supply, Emiliana is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders of PHP7,000. The amount will be of great help to her business. Aside from that, Emiliana sometimes sells vegetables in their village. 
Her dream is to make her business grow and she is thankful because Kiva came in the right time at the exact place. She hopes that Kiva loans will become successful in their mission to help the needy people, especially those who are small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina T. is 49 years old and lives in Barangay Nabbotuan Solana, Cagayan with her family. She is married to Abelardo T. who is 48 years old and still strong and able to till their farm lot. They are blessed with 8 children. Josefina says that her children are her treasure in life, however she feels sad that she was not able to provide them with a better education.

Josefina runs a hog raising business to help her husband provide for their financial needs. She dreams of being successful in her business thus, she was motivated to request a loan of PHP15, 000 from Kiva lenders. She will utilize the loan in purchasing piglets, feed and vaccines for her hogs. She believes that the improvement of her business also depends on hard work and perseverance so she is trying her best to maintain those attitudes.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, feed and vaccines for her hogs

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine A. is 43 years of age and single. She lives with her parents in Barangay Nabbotuan Solana, Cagayan. She helps her parents earn a living by managing a general store in their village. According to Josephine her business is doing great because she has a lot of customers. However, she still wants the business to grow and expand to generate higher income.

With this aim in mind, she is asking for a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP27, 000 as additional working capital. She is helping her parents and sisters to provide for their family’s basic needs and also helps her nieces by giving them allowances and buying school supplies for their studies. She is happy with her life now and thankful that she has a business to be able to extend help to her family.

loans.use: Business capital to expand her store

loans.name: Levie

texts.en:
