Levie A. is from the village of Nabbotuan Solana, Cagayan. She is married to Ricardo and they have three children, all enrolled in a public school in their community. Despite the difficulties of their life, the couple still manage to send their children to school to finish a degree course, which will someday help them get a good job for their future.

Levie runs a hog raising business, which she wants to grow progressively with help from a PHP11, 000 loan from Kiva lenders. The loan will not only assist her in improving her hog raising business but also in sending her children to school, providing them with enough school allowance and tuition fees. She believes that she will always be able to overcome the trials that her family encounters.

loans.use: Business capital to grow her hog raising business

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Wanting to have a store in their village, Luisa M. of Nabbotuan Solana, Cagayan is requesting the amount of PHP16, 000 to start up a village store to help her husband earn their daily living. With the loan she hopes that she will be able to purchase many products for her to earn more income. Through that, she knows that she will help her husband uplift their lives.

Luisa is 60 years old and married to Condrado who is a local farmer. They have five children who are living independently from them.

loans.use: Business capital to open a village store

loans.name: Tuon

texts.en: Tuon Y. is 32 years old and lives in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She is married with one young child who is enrolled in school, while her husband works as a security guard in the Angkor Wat Temple. Tuon Y. is currently a teller for a company and gets a set salary to better meet her family’s daily foods needs. She will be using this loan to add to her savings to purchase tools for a carpenter to build them a new house. This new home will make her family’s living conditions more comfortable.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en:
Having three children who are all studying is really difficult. That is according to Ma. Luz of Nabbotuan, Solano, Cagayan. Ma. Luz is married to Roderick who, like most of the residents in their community, works as a farmer. Ma. Luz, on the other hand, has been engaged in the hog-raising business for almost five years. However, her income is only seasonal, based on when her hog is big enough to sell at market.

This situation means that the couple are having a hard time meeting their daily expenses as well as their children's school allowances. With this in mind, Ma. Luz is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP from Kiva lenders. She believes that this amount will be a big help in developing her livestock business. She is also hoping that through Kiva’s continuous financial support, accompanied by patience and hard work, her business will grow some day. Ma. Luz's real desire is to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: As business capital

loans.name: Belarmina

texts.en: Belarmina M. is from the village of Barangay Kabcsanan, Iligan City. She is 47 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. Belarmina owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale in their garden. She is just starting this business. In June 2009, Belarmina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and to support the education of her children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use to expand her business

location.town: Kabcsanan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza A., from the village of Zone 14, Kabacsanan, Iligan City, is a 41-year-old married mother of four school-aged children. To make a living, Riza buys green bananas and sells them in the local community. Riza has been engaged in her business for over a year, earning approximately 1,000 PHP a month.

In June 2009, Riza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP in order to expand the business. This will be Riza's first loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Zone 14, Kabacsanan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma A. is from the village of Zone 14, Kabacsanan, Iligan City. She is 34 years old and married with one school-aged child. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Emma has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In June 2009, Emma joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will Emma's first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Zone 14, Kabacsanan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Yasmin Elizabeth

texts.es: Yasmin Elizabeth R. de 37 años de edad reside en el municipio de Apopa ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. Yasmin vive junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos aun menores de edad que actualmente se encuentran estudiando. El esposo de Yasmin aporta mensualmente 200$ para los gastos familiares. Yasmin se dedica la venta de ropa de manera ambulante, viaja en  el transcurso de la semana a diferentes departamentos del país ofreciendo sus productos, Yasmin solicita un crédito para surtir su inventario en ropa.
texts.en:
Yasmin Elizabeth R. is 37 years old and lives in the town of Apopa, located in the San Salvador district. Yasmin lives with her husband and their two dependent children who are students. Yasmin's husband earns $200/month for family expenses.

Yasmin sells clothes as a street vendor. During the week, she travels to different districts throughout the country offering her products. Yasmin is requesting a loan to increase her inventory of clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Santos Aida

texts.es: Santos Aida R. B. reside en el municipio de Armenia en el departamento de Sonsonate. Aida es madre de tres hijos de los cuales todos son mayores de edad independientes económicamente pero ayudan a su madre con 200$ mensuales, dinero el cual Aida administra muy bien ya que es el único ingreso estable económico, es por ello que Aida se decidió a abrir su propio negocio y es así como inicio su venta de pupusas  en su casa, tiene una clientela muy estable y su demanda va incrementando poco a poco es por ello que solita este crédito para compra de materia prima para sus pupusas.
texts.en:
Santos Aida R. B. lives in the town of Armenia in the Sonsonate district. Aida is the mother of three adult children who support themselves financially. They help their mother by providing her $200 monthly, which Aida manages very well since it is her only stable source of income.

For this reason, Aida decided to open her own business selling “pupusas” (flatbread stuffed with meat, cheese, or vegetables) from her home. She has a very stable customer base and demand for her product is growing little by little. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to purchase ingredients for making pupusas.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients

loans.name: Ángela Gladis

texts.es: Ángela Gladis G. D. D. D. 42 años D. edad vive en el departamento D. La Libertad junto a sus esposo quien se dedica a la albañilería y sus tres hijos D. los cuales dos D. ellos aun son menores D. edad y se encuentran estudiando, mientras el otro hijo quien es ya mayor D. edad ayuda a Ángela en el negocio  se dedican a la venta D. frutas y verduras, el negocio lo tiene ubicado en el mercado municipal, pero también maneja un Pick up lleno D. mercadería para ofrecer D. manera ambulante es allí cuando  Ángela recibe la ayuda D. su hijo Melvin, este crédito lo solicita por quiere invertir en mercadería para su puesto y la que venD. en el pick;  D. esta manera la familia obtendría mayores ganancias al aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Ángela Gladis G. D. D. is 42 years old and lives in La Libertad district with her husband and three children. Her husband works as a mason. Two of her children are students and still minors. The eldest child is an adult and helps Ángela with selling fruit and vegetables. Her business is located in the municipal market, but she also operates a delivery truck full of merchandise to sell on the street. Ángela’s son, Melvin, helps with the deliveries.

She is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise to sell from her market stall and from her delivery truck. This will allow her family to earn more profit by increasing their sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Bibi Saheab Group

texts.en:
Bibi Saheab is the group leader of Bibi Saheab Group. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to receive money to purchase more materials for their businesses and make a good income for their family in future.
Bibi Saheab and Qaseyma want to take a loan for their business of tailoring, to buy one or two new machines for tailoring. Saefadine wants to take a loan for car part selling. He wants to buy the necessary materials for his business. Shakofa wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. And she wants to enlarge her businesses. They all want to expand and progress their businesses and want to earn more money to support their families. With this loan, they can expand their businesses, support their families and make a better future for themselves and for their families in the future.

loans.use: To buy new machines for tailoring

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 19-year-old man living with his parents. In 2009, he decided to open his own call center. In order to expand his shop and his career, Hassan is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase equipment.

loans.use: To purchase call center equipment

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita T. is from the village of P-8C, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 42 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Anita works in someone else's business venture in the retail sector, running a sari-sari (variety) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Anita has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In June 2009, Anita joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Anita's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand the business and to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Purok 8C, Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Men S., 39, is a good homemaker. She stays at home to care for the kids and cooks delicious meals for the family as well. The family’s daily expenses are contributed to by her husband, who works driving a trailer motorbike taxi (tuk tuk). He generates an income of $6 each day to sustain his family's expenses more stably. This humble couple has two children who are of school age. Men S. is applying for a loan for her husband to replace his old taxi that has not attracted the customers.

loans.use: To replace her husband's old taxi

loans.name: Christiane

texts.en: Christiane is a 32-year-old woman living with her parents. She has owned a small copy center since 2007 to improve life conditions for her parents. Today, Christiane is requesting to borrow $500 to purchase an additional small photocopy machine to increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase an additional small photocopy machine

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma B. is already 46 years old. She is married to Andres, and they are currently residing in Barangay Linao Norte of Tuguegarao City. She has 6 children, namely, Jenilyn, Joverlyn, Jodel, Jhon, Vergel, and Jose. Their children are all studying; thus Norma is working very hard to help her husband support their children’s education, for them to have a bright future.

Norma is selling fruits and vegetables in their village. She manages a vending stall, but, unluckily, she is lacking financial capital. That is why she is requesting from Kiva lenders an amount of 11,000 PHP as additional working capital. She is thankful that her children are very understanding and helpful.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa B. is from the village of Purok 8C, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 45 years old. Teresa is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Teresa owns & operates a business venture in the food sector, selling fish through peddling. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fish in the local community. Teresa has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In June 2009, Teresa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Teresa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and supplement the family income.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish and aquatic resources to sell

location.town: Purok 8C, Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Elena Rutilia

texts.es: Elena Rutilia E. D. C. D. 34 años D. edad resiD. en el departamento D. La Libertad junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos Alexander D. 15 años D. edad y Wilfredo 10 años D. edad ambos niños estudian. Elena posee un chalet ubicado en una escuela D. Sonsonate donD. venD. variedad D. productos para el consumo D. los estudiantes y docentes, el destino del crédito que solicita Elena es para surtir el chalet, D. esta manera ella aprovecharía las ventas con más variedad D. productos dentro D. su negocio.
texts.en:
Elena Rutilia E. D. C. is 34 years old. She lives in the department of La Libertad, along with her husband and two children, Alexander, who is 15 years old, and Wilfredo, who is 10. Both boys are students. Elena has a kiosk located in the Sonsonate school, where she sells a variety of products to the students and teachers. The purpose of the requested loan is to stock the kiosk so that she can have better sales by having a greater variety of products available at her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock her business

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario B. is requesting a loan of PHP30,000 from Kiva lenders to aid in the development of her general store, hoping to eventually expand it in order to increase her daily income for her family. She has also been managing a hog-raising business for 10 years.

Rosario, 52, is married to Pedro, a simple farmer in their village, and they are blessed with five children: Arnel, now 32 years old; Arnold, 29 years old; Aaron, 27 years old; Karen, 22, and Romalyn, who is 11 years old. Two of them are already married and live separately while the other three are still single. Romalyn, the youngest, is the only one who is studying. Rosario has always wanted a better life for her children, so she is doing her best to become successful in her chosen livelihoods.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Edit Esperanza

texts.es: Edit Esperanza G. D. P. resiD. en el municipio D. San Pedro Masahuat  ubicado en el departamento D. La Paz. Edit tiene 56 años D. edad vive junto a sus tres hijos Adelina D. 12 años, Francisco D. 11 años y Juan D. 10 años D. edad, todos los niños se encuentran estudiando. Edit se dedica a su negocio, un comedor el cual ella lo ha llamado “Dios proveerá”, donD. venD. variedad D. comida todos los días, Edit solicita un crédito el cual lo destinara para comprar materia prima, ya que sus ventas han aumentado y necesita sacar mayor producción diaria D. comida
texts.en:
Edit Esperanza Grando D. P. lives in the city of San Pedro Masahuat located in La Paz. Edit is 56-years old and lives with her three children: Adelina (12), Francisco (11) and Juan (10). All of the children are currently studying. Edit is dedicated to her job at a diner where she is known as “Dios Proveera” (The God provider) where she sells a variety of meals all day. Edit requests a loan to purchase raw materials as her sales have increased and she needs to maximize her daily production of meals.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita manages a hog-raising business in their village of Barangay Linao Norte of Tuguegarao City. Now 49 years old, she has three children: Avelyn, 25 years old and working in Manila; Arthur, a soldier in Abra, and Vernon, 21 years old and a fourth year college student. Teresita’s husband Francisco works as a policeman in Tuguegarao City.

While grateful for her happy and blessed family, Teresita needs to help her husband in order to sustain their daily living and the education of her youngest child. This hardworking mother and generous neighbor is therefore requesting a loan from Kiva lenders of PHP 15,000 for the maintenance of her hog-raising business.

loans.use: Business Maintenance

loans.name: Haidee

texts.en:
Haidee R. is from the village of Purok 8C, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 27 years old. Haidee is married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Haidee works in someone else's business venture, operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Haidee has been engaged in the business for over 5 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In June 2009, Haidee joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Haidee is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Haidee from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Purok 8C, Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Hun T. was born in 1986. She a resident of Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, where she has been selling a few cooking ingredients and sweets to the people who live in the village for years. She is a young mother with one child who is still not enrolled in school. She is married to Tum Mao, 24, who helps support the family by working in construction.

Hun T. is taking out this loan in order to purchase a motor for her family’s traveling needs, especially for riding to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motor for family’s traveling needs

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion operates a variety store in her village in Centro 1, Mallig, Isabela. Some of her items include bags, clothes, school supplies, and other merchandise that are in demand. She is 43 years old and married to Vivencio, a farmer. They a daughter named Angelica, a high school graduate who is now working abroad and hoping to raise their standard of living.

Because of her desire to develop her business, Consolacion was encouraged to apply for a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP30, 000 as additional working capital for her store. She plans to use the loan to buy more goods so she can expand her business and venture into other types of business. For Consolacion, the loan will be a big help in making her business grow and in helping her family have a better way of living.

loans.use: To expand her variety store

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie D. is from the village of Purok 8C, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 29 years old. Julie is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Julie owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Julie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In June 2009, Julie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Julie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Purok 8C, Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Ludisma

texts.en:
Ludisma is engaged in a hog raising business. She would like to borrow PHP15,000 from Kiva lenders as business capital. She will use the loan to buy a supply of feed for her hogs.

Ludisma is married to Ronaldo, a simple employee. They were gifted with two children: Ronald Vhon Louis and Dustin Rowen Lhord. She is thankful for the support of her husband in her business. She is hoping that someday her children will be able to finish their college education and be employed in good jobs with good salaries.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her hogs

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine E. is from the village of Purok 4A, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 50 years old. Josephine is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In June 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Purok 4A, Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Rosalita

texts.en:
Rosalita is 48 years old and still doing her best for the welfare of her family. She manages a general store business and also engages in making dresses in her village for additional income.

Rosalita is still single and lives in the simple village of Centro 1 Mallig, Isabela with her nieces. Rosalita worked abroad for 15 years; when she went home, she decided to stay and start her own business, which is a general store.

Rosalita wants her business to continue to grow, so she would like to borrow PHP15,000. She hopes to expand her business and be able to double her daily income. She was happy that her nieces assisted her in the business during vacations and weekends. According to her, she must do her best and be patient always.

loans.use: To expand her store

loans.name: Lo

texts.en:
Lo S., 46, helps support her whole family by selling grocery items. For additional income, she also sells beef soup to her neighbors in the evening. She is married with one young child. Her husband raises pigs out of their home.

Recently, Lo S. sold nearly all the items from her store, so she needs to buy more grocery inventory in order to continue selling. However, she does not have enough money to do so. That is why she has decided to ask for a loan of $600 from Kiva’s partner HKL. This will provide her with additional income to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To replenish her grocery inventory

loans.name: Jcille Gia

texts.en:
Jcille Gia E. is from the village of Purok 4A, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 24 years old. Jcille Gia is single and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Jcille Gia owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food like banana cue. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling and making snacks like banana cue and mango in the local community. Jcille Gia has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In June 2009, Jcille Gia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jcille Gia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jcille Gia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

location.town: Purok 4A, Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Asadulalah Group

texts.en:
Asadulalah is the group leader of Asadulalah group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for his/her own business.

Norya and Pakay each want to take a loan for their bakery businesses. Asadulalah wants to take a loan for his business of carpentry. They all want to see progress in their business and to earn more money to support their families better. 

They say that these loans can be very useful because they provide a chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine A. is from the village of Purok 8C, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 56 years old. Josephine is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In June 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and supplement her family's income.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma C. is from the village of Purok 24, Tag-ibo, Dalipuga, Iligan City. She is 46 years old. Emma is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In June 2009, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fist loan taken out by Emma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and supplement her family's income.

location.town: Purok 24, Tag-ibo, Dalipuga, Iligan City, Lanao de

loans.name: Lok

texts.en:
Mrs. Lok L., 29, lives in a rural area of Siem Reap Province. She currently earns her daily revenue by selling fresh fishes and some meats to villagers in front of her home. Her husband, Mr. Tun Pouv, age 28, works in building. The couple has one young child who is of school age.

This family faces difficulty with transportation because they have no own vehicle. Therefore, Lok L. would like a loan to buy a used motor for her family’s traveling needs; it will be used to support her business as well.

loans.use: To buy a used motor for her family’s traveling needs and for her business

loans.name: Kossiwavi

texts.fr:
Cette femme est une revendeuse de produits cosmétiques, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2007 et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé, elle a associé à ce commerce la vente de mèches et perruques. Elle a poussé un peu loin ses études, ce qui lui a permis d’avoir certaines notions de gestion et lui permet de bien gérer son commerce. Elle veut agrandir son stock et sollicite de WAGES  un crédit pour acheter 15 pièces de pagnes, des mèches et de perruques.
Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman is a retailer of cosmetics. She has been in this business since 2007 and acquires her supplies at the grand marketplace of Lomé. She includes with this business the sale of hair extensions and wigs. She went a bit further in school, enabling her to gain certain management concepts. This allows her to manage her business well. She wants to expand her inventory and is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 15 bolts of pagnes (colorful West African cloth), hair extensions, and wigs. She is married and the mother of two.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extension, wigs, and various cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Ibrahima Drissa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Ibrahima Drissa T. est  un célibataire qui est âgé de 26 ans et n’a pas d’enfant. Il vit chez son père (avec ses autres frères et sœurs) à Bougouni dans le quartier Dialanicoro (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mener beaucoup d’activités génératrices de revenus à Bamako sans succès, il décida de retourner en famille à Bougouni pour apprendre le métier de tailleur auprès de son oncle. Avec 6 années d’expérience, il maîtrise bien son activité dans laquelle il est très apprécié et sollicité.
Après avoir correctement remboursé son premier prêt (d’ailleurs par anticipation), il est à son deuxième prêt individuel qui sera utilisé pour acheter de la mercerie à Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès des grossistes.
Très sollicité par les femmes de Bougouni qui composent la majeur partie de sa clientèle, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 50 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice il compte améliorer son atelier et se marier.
Il ambitionne acheter un lot à usage d’habitation et le construire pour avoir un chez soi..
texts.en:
Mr. Ibrahima Drissa T., age 26, is unmarried and has no children. He lives at his father's place (with his brothers and sisters) in Bougouni in the Dialanicoro district (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run unsuccessfully many revenue-generating businesses in Bamako, he decided to go back to his family in Bougouni to learn the trade of tailoring from his uncle. With six years of experience, he has a good command of his business, where he is in high demand and much appreciated. After having correctly repaid his first loan (moreover, ahead of schedule), he is on his second individual loan that will be used to buy sewing supplies in Bamako (capital of Mali) from wholesalers. In high demand by the women of Bougouni who compose the bulk of his customers, he plans to realize a monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA. With this profit, he plans to improve his workshop and to get married. His ambition is to buy a plot of land on which to live and to have his own place.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Saibou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Saibou Touré a 37 ans et vit avec son enfant et son épouse dans une famille nucléaire dans le quartier Niebala de la ville de la préfecture de  Bougouni (région de Sikasso).
N’ayant pas fait l’école moderne, très jeune il commença les activités génératrices de revenus, mais sans succès telles  l’achat et la vente des motos à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Quelques années après Monsieur Saibou Touré revient auprès de son oncle  qui est un commerçant chevronné à Bougouni pour apprendre l’achat et la vente des pièces détachées. Avec une expérience de 5 ans, il maîtrise bien son activité et ouvre une boutique de pièces détachées, de lubrifiants etc qui est très fréquentée.
Afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle Saibou Touré décida de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son deuxième prêt individuel, après avoir bien remboursé son premier prêt.
Il compte acheter des pièces détachées à Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès des grossistes. Il effectue sa vente à Bougouni dans sa boutique  au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de propriétaires de véhicules, de réparateurs et de mécaniciens.
Monsieur Saibou Touré compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 58 750 FCFA qu’il  envisage utiliser pour construire une maison, agrandir son entreprise et  subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Saibou Touré, age 37, lives with his child and wife in a nuclear family in the Niebala district of the city in Bougouni prefecture (Sikasso region). Not having had modern schooling, he started earning an income when very young, although without success, such as in the sale of motorbikes in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). A few years later, he returned to learn from his uncle, who is a seasoned merchant in Bougouni, how to buy and sell spare parts. With five years of experience, Saibou has a good command of his business and opened a shop for spare parts, lubricants, etc. His shop is busy. To satisfy his customers better, Saibou decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his second individual loan, after having repaid his first one. He intends to buy some spare parts in Bamako from wholesalers. He makes his sales in Bougouni in his shop, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of vehicle owners, repairmen, and mechanics. He plans to realize a monthly profit of 58,750 francs CFA that he envisions using to build a house, to expand his enterprise, and to cover family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Victoire

texts.fr:
Cette femme fait le commerce de friperie, elle a commencé ce commerce depuis 2002, son ancienneté fait qu’elle maîtrise parfaitement son commerce, elle s’approvisionne au GHANA et au NIGERIA ce qui fait qu’elle réalise de meilleures marges bénéficiaires sur ses ventes. Actuellement elle veut augmenter  son stock de marchandises, elle sollicite son premier crédit de WAGES pour commander au GHANA des friperies.
Elle est mariée et a 03 personnes à charges.
texts.en:
This is a woman who does commerce in second-hand clothing. She started this business in 2002. Her seniority in it means she has mastered it. She supplies herself from GHANA and from NIGERIA, which means she realizes some of the best profit margins on her sales. Currently, she wants to increase her stock of merchandise. She is requesting her first loan from WAGES for ordering used clothing from GHANA. She is married and has three people to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Diakaridia

texts.fr:
Monsieur Diakaridia Koné est un célibataire de 20 ans  qui  n’a pas d’enfant. Il vit chez son oncle dans la  quartier Hérémakono Nord de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après ses études fondamentales où il obtient son diplôme d’étude fondamentale D.E.F.(au Mali le D.E.F. ouvre la voie aux études secondaires). Monsieur Diakaridia Koné n’a pas été orienté dans un établissement secondaire pour raison de scolarités. Il est resté très longtemps sans activité génératrice de revenu. Ces parents n’ayant pas les moyens de lui payer ses études, il décida de suivre son grand frère pour apprendre le commerce notamment la vente  d’articles divers de  boutique. Avec son courage et sa persévérance, Monsieur Diakaridia est parvenu à se frayer un chemin en ouvrant une boutique dans le quartier.  
Ainsi pour avoir un fonds de roulement pour développer ses activités, Diakaridia Koné décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son premier prêt individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter des articles divers pour sa boutique (sardine, briquet, lait en poudre, sucre, savon, thé, eau de javel, insecticide anti-moustique etc).  Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni auprès des commerçants grossistes  et effectue sa vente à une clientèle  diverse et variée au comptant, en détail et à crédit payable mensuellement.
Avec ce prêt, Diakaridia Koné compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 22 500 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  agrandir sa boutique, et financer ses études.
texts.en:
Mr. Diakaridia Koné, age 20, is unmarried and has no children. He lives at his uncle's place in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After his primary schooling, when he obtained his DEF (a diploma of basic studies), Diakaridia was not guided to a secondary establishment for scholastic reasons. (In Mali, the DEF opens the way for secondary studies.) He remained quite awhile without income-generating work. Because his parents lacked the means to pay for his schooling, he decided to follow his older brother and learn commerce, notably selling various shop items. With his courage and perseverance, Diakaridia managed to clear a path for himself by opening a shop in his area. Thus, to obtain more working capital for developing his business, he decided to collaborate with micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his first individual loan. He intends to use this loan to buy for his shop: sardines, cigarette lighters, powdered milk, sugar, soap, tea, bleach, anti-mosquito insecticide, etc. Supplies are gotten in Bougouni from wholesale merchants, and sales are made to a diverse and varied customer base, in cash transaction and on credit, payable monthly. With this loan, he plans to realize a monthly profit of 22,500 francs CFA that will be used to expand his shop and to finance his schooling.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy diverse goods for his shop

loans.name: Dramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Dramane Dembélé est âgé de 34 ans et père de 4 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier Faraba de la ville de Bougouni.(troisième région administrative du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école, dès son jeune âge il s’intéressa  aux activités génératrices de revenus. Pendant 10 ans il faisait les travaux journaliers auprès des commerçants notamment le transport de leurs marchandises avec un pousse pousse au marché et dans les différents quartiers de Bougouni, mais sans succès. C’est ainsi qu’il décida d’apprendre la vente d’articles divers de boutique auprès de son oncle.  Depuis maintenant 4 ans il exerce cette activité et est très sollicité. 
Afin de renforcer de son commerce, Monsieur Dramane Dembélé décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
Il est son premier prêt individuel qu’il compte utiliser pour  acheter des articles divers pour sa boutique.  Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Sa clientèle est composée de la population locale.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Dramane Dembélé compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Dramane Dembélé, age 34, is the father of four. He lives with this wife and children in the Faraba district of Bougouni City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having gone to school, he got interested at an early age in income-generating work. For ten years, he used to work daily with merchants, especially in merchandise transport by cart at the marketplace and in the different district of Bougouni, though he was unsuccessful. So he decided to learn from his uncle how to sell various shop goods. For four years now, he has been working at this business and is in high demand. To bolster his business, he decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He is now on his first individual loan, which he intends to use to buy various goods for his shop. He stocks up in Bamako (capital of Mali). His customers are composed of local people. With this loan, he plans to realize a monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA that he envisions using to expand his shop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items for his shop

loans.name: Lamine

texts.fr:
Monsieur Lamine Sangaré est âgé de 28 ans et n’a pas d’enfant. Il vit  chez son père avec son épouse et d’autres parents dans le quartier Dougounina de Bougouni. (troisième région administrative du Mali).
Nanti d’un diplôme en comptabilité, il  reste pendant des années dans le chômage. Pendant cette période, il a tenté plusieurs activités sans réussite. C’est ainsi que Monsieur Lamine Sangaré décida  d’apprendre  l’activité de meunier auprès de son père qui détenait un moulin. Avec une expérience de 10 ans, Monsieur Lamine Sangaré maîtrise  bien cette  activité et est sollicité par une clientèle  composée surtout  des femmes.
Dans le souci de rénover son moulin il décide de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Monsieur Lamine compte acheter un nouveau dynamo  à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès du représentant de sa marque.
Il espère réaliser  un bénéfice mensuel de 65 000 FCFA qu’il compte utiliser pour entretenir son moulin, payer les intérêts du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Lamine Sangaré is 28 and has no children. He and his wife live with his father and other relatives in the Dougounina neighborhood in Bougouni (third administrative region of Mali).

Although he has a diploma in accounting, he has been out of work for years. During this period, he tried various business activities without success. Thus, Mr. Lamine Sangaré decided to learn to be a miller together with his father who has a mill. With 10 years experience, Mr. Lamine Sangaré is very knowledgeable in this business and is much in demand with a clientele made up primarily of women.

With the intention of repairing his mill, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso with whom he is on his first individual loan. He intends to buy a new dynamo in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from the representative of that brand of mill.

He hopes to make a monthly profit of 65,000 F CFA that he intends to use to maintain his mill, pay the interest on the loan, and contribute to family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a dynamo for his mill

loans.name: Hourt

texts.en:
Mr. Hourt R. is 21 years old. His wife’s name is Srey Ren, and she is age 20. This young couple make a living as local tailors. They also buy clothes, sew them to produce other kinds of clothing, and sell their clothes in bulk to market sellers. This couple has been married a year but still have no child.

Hourt R. has used his business investment very well and has attracted a number of clients to use his services. To make more his business successful, he would like a loan in order to purchase a pair of sewing machine he can use to perform his work more quickly.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of sewing machine

loans.name: Abou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Abou Koné est âgé de 27 ans et père de 2 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans la  quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni.(troisième administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, très vite il commença les activités génératrices de revenus. Pendant des années Monsieur Abou Koné faisait le transporteur des bagages avec un pousse-pousse. Il a pu économiser pour finalement ouvrir une boutique de ventes d’articles divers. Depuis 2 ans Monsieur Abou Koné vend au marché de Bougouni où il a sa boutique. Il est très sollicité et apprécié dans la ville de Bougouni
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il décide de rejoindre  Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel..
Avec ce prêt Monsieur Abou Koné compte acheter des articles divers pour sa boutique afin d’attirer  beaucoup plus de clientèle.
 Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente au marché de Bougouni à une clientèle riche et variée.
 Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Abou Koné compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA qu’il envisage investir exclusivement dans sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Abou Koné is 27 and the father of 2 children. He lives with his wife and children in the Hérémakono Nord district of the town of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having been able to go to school, he began early to earn his living. For years, Mr. Abou Koné transported baggage with a rickshaw. He was able to save up enough to open a little general store. For two years, Mr. Abou Koné has been selling at the market of Bougouni where he has his shop. He is much sought after and respected in the town of Bougouni.

In need of complementary financing, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso with whom he is on his first individual loan. With this loan he intends to buy various items for his shop so as to attract more customers. He buys his merchandise in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from wholesalers and makes his sales at the market of Bougouni to a vast and varied clientele. With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 30,000 F CFA which he hopes to invest exclusively in his shop.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing various items for re-sale

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr:
Ce jeune homme a abandonné les études pour se lancer dans la vie active, il a appris la maintenance et a ouvert plus tard sa boutique de réparation et de décodage des téléphones mobiles, il a ouvert cette boutique en 2005 et a à ce jour plusieurs clients. Sa boîte à décodage a eu une panne, il veut en acheter un autre, raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter une boîte à décodage. 
C’est avec ce commerce qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This young man dropped out of school to get started in life. He learned maintenance and eventually opened his shop for repairing and decoding mobile phones. He opened this shop in 2005 and today has several customers. His decoding device is malfunctioning. He wants to buy another one, so he is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy a decoder. With this commerce, he provide for his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a decoder

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Prok

texts.en:
Prok P. is 41 years old and resides in the rural area of Kompong Cham Province. She and her husband are currently local cultivators who grow all kind of crops. This family has been blessed with six children, three of whom are sewing staff in the garment industry.

Prok P. has been depending on the farming business only, so her family’s income is not stable. Because of this bad condition, she would like a loan to use as capital for her husband to start a service repairing vehicles in front of their home. She plans to use the rest of the loan to buy more fertilizers to fatten her crop yield.

loans.use: To start a vehicle repair service and buy fertilizer

loans.name: Zuhair

texts.en:
Zuhair is 31 years old and single. He owns a small computer repair shop in Ramallah, Palestine, where he specializes in computer sales, CD writing, typesetting, and computer repairs.

Zuhair is seeking this loan in order to purchase new and used computers and computer spare parts. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new and used computers and computer parts

loans.name: Rosa's Group

texts.en:
Rosa is the group’s leader. She has five adult children. Before starting this business, she discussed everything with her family and made all the necessary calculations. As a result, for the last fifteen years she has been successfully raising cattle. Even though she has a big family, she has been able to make quite a decent living by this activity, and thus has not been dependent on her children. She mainly purchases young calves and resells them after breeding.  With this loan, she plans to make some home improvements. In the near future, she wants to increase the number of her cattle and buy a new flat in the capital. 

The other members of the group are Taalaibubu, Zinaikul, and Balbubu. Taalaibubu is a married woman of 51. She has two daughters and two sons. All of her children are adults. Currently, she sells dairy products, and she is able to supply six to seven liters of milk a day for sale.  During the last ten years, she has been able to pay for her two daughters' education and buy a refrigerator, a TV, and a DVD player. Now she needs a loan to repair her house. 

Zinaikul, another member, is divorced and the mother of two daughters, both of whom go to school. Following her brother’s advice, she bought a cow and a calf, in addition to two carpets which she bought for the house. For four years she has been raising livestock. Now she wants to use her loan to buy more livestock and gradually increase their number. Then she plans to buy a refrigerator and furniture.  Once this set-up is in place, in the near future, she wants to open her own shop. 

Balbubu is 41, and is the mother of five children. She earns only about 45 dollars per month. Nevertheless, she has great plans of selling strawberries and apples from her own garden and sending her daughter to college. She needs this loan to repaint her house. 

This group is a great example of striving women who never give up. They believe in a better life, and make real advances towards it.

loans.use: Housing repairs and livestock purchase

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan is a 24-year-old single man who lives in Nablus city, Palestine.  He ownes a grocery store where he sells vegetables, chocolate, and canned food. Hasan has requested a loan of $1500 US from Ryadain order to purchase more merchandise to sell. Hasan is special in his work because of his honesty and good behavior with his clients. Hasan is grateful for your support and generosity.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise for his store

loans.name: Si

texts.en: Si N., 41, is a rural villager in the Province of Siem Reap where she makes a living planting a variety of crops as her  business. Her husband works fishing in and around Tunle Sap River which is the main area for fish. This older couple  lives with five children. Two are working in construction, while the others are unemployed but work on the farm field. Because this is the rice harvesting season, Si N. has requested a loan to hire harvesters to cut her crops and to buy fertilizers to begin growing her new plants.

loans.use: To hire harvesters to cut her crops, and to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Reine

texts.fr:
KOUSSOUHO Reine est mère de deux enfants, âgés de trois ans et de  six mois.  Reine est mariée à NOUDJENOUNME  Jean, qui est chauffeur de taxi.  Reine habite avec sa famille à Cotonou, la ville la plus grande du Bénin.  

À Cotonou, Reine vend  de tomates, piments, oignons, légumes, qui sont utilisés pour préparer les sauces des plats Béninois.  Reine vend dans sa boutique au bord de la rue.  Reine achète ses produits au Marché Houejbo à Cotonou.  Dans le future, Reine voudrait vendre ses produits en gros, mais actuellement Reine n’a pas les moyens financiers nécessaire.  Pour augmenter le volume de son activité, Reine cherche un prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
KOUSSOUHO Reine is the mother of two children, ages six months to 3 years old. She is married to NOUDJENOUNME Jean, a taxi driver, and lives with her family in Cotonou, the largest city in Benin. In Cotonou, Reine sells tomatoes, chili peppers, onions, and legumes that are used in making sauces for Beninese dishes. She sells in a shop on the roadside. She buys her goods at the Houejbo Market in Cotonou. In the future, she would like to sells her goods wholesale, but currently she does not have the necessary financial means. To increase her business volume, Reine is seeking a loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, chilis, onions, etc.

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr:
A. Odette est mariée et mère de quatre enfants.  Trois de ses enfants sont  âges respectivement de 12, 8, 5 ans et vont à l’école.  Le quatrième enfant  qui a 10 mois reste avec sa mère.  Le mari d’Odette est agent de sécurité.  Odette habite avec sa famille à Cotonou, la ville le plus grande et la capitale économique du Bénin.  

À Cotonou, Odette vend des produits diverses y compris de farine, arachides, l’eau potable et des produites esthétiques comme vernis à ongles.  Odette vend ces choses chez elle et au bord de la rue.  Odette  a commencé cette activité il y a cinq ans.  Odette  cherche un prêt de ALIDé pour augmenter son activité et acheter plus des produits qu’elle vend.  Dans le future, Odette voudrait ouvrir une boutique dans laquelle elle peut vendre sa marchandise.
texts.en:
A. Odette is married and the mother of four children. Three of them are, respectively, 12, 8, and 5 years old, and they go to school. The fourth one, who is 10 months old, remains at home. Odette's husband is a security agent, and she lives with her family in Cotonou, the largest city and the economic capital of Benin. In Cotonou, Odette sells various goods, including flour, peanuts, potable water, and beauty products, such as nail polish. She sells these things at her house and on the side of the road. She started this business five years ago. She is seeking a loan with ALIDé to increase her business and to buy more of the goods she sells. In the future, Odette would like to open a shop in which she can sell merchandise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products, flour, peanuts, and potable water

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a striving butcher in the city of Ramallah, Palestine. He is 25 years old, single, and lives with his parents and four younger brothers. Ahmad has requested a loan of US$2000 to improve and expand his business. Let's support Ahmad who has a lot of courage and strength to live. Your generosity can change his life.

loans.use: improve and expand his business

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en: Fadi is a 37-year-old married man with 2 children. He has owned a car repair shop since 1992. After this long experience in the field, Fadi is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase merchandise for his shop to be able to satisfy the demand of the market and increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Nabelah Group

texts.en:
Nabelah is the group leader of Nabelah Group. There are three members in this group. They would like to receive money for their businesses.
Masoma wants to take a loan for her husband’s business, a general store. Nabylah wants to take a loan for her business of embroidery. M. wants to take a loan for his business, a fresh fruit cart. They all want to see progress in their business. They all want to receive the loan for their business progress and they want to make their business larger.
They are all thankful for the Kiva process in Afghanistan that supports poor people in this country.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: God Is Good Group

texts.en: Yatta is a mother of 3 children and additional 2 extended family members. She sells retail goods (flour, oil, sugar, etc) within the Moulton corner, Browerville Community, especially at her house. She encourages her customers with smiles,  and dreams of seeing her business grow gradually. She says she is really interested in bringing all of her children up for a better tomorrow.

loans.use: To buy sugar, flour, oil, etc. for resale

loans.name: God's Devine Favor Group

texts.en: Oliver is the father of three children; the youngest is just 3 months old. He deals in petroleum products (gasoline) along with scratch cards being sold by GSM Companies in Liberia, and he has been in the business for the last five years. He buys the product wholesale and sells it at retail prices. He sees the shortage of customers as his greatest challenge. "The secret to my success in this business is buying more products to get more profit," he says. He dreams of going back to school to continue his education and also to take care of his children.

loans.use: To purchase wholesale drums of gasoline for retail sales

loans.name: Christians Group

texts.en:
Hawa B. is married with 8 grandchildren. She sells fresh vegetables (peppers, garden eggs, salts, etc). She goes to the general market (Duala Market) to buy goods and sells them at her house.

She says: "I love the business and so I continue it, I have been in it for the past 30 years now. I am successful but don’t really sell during the rainy season and I see this as a challenge. I talk so nicely to my customers as I call them to buy from me. I will do all of this to help all of my grandchildren."

loans.use: To buy vegetables for resale

loans.name: Kokoè

texts.fr:
Cette dame s’est lancée en 2006 dans le commerce de vêtements, elle vend des articles de mercerie  elle a associé à cette activité le commerce des chemises et des cravates.Ce commerce marche bien pour elle, des employés de bureau viennent acheter les chemises et cravates chez elle, elle s’approvisionne auprès des grossîtes qui font l’importation des vêtements. Elle veut acheter de nouvelles gammes de chemises, cravates et quelques articles de mercerie, elle sollicite alors un crédit pour acheter 15 chemises, 50 cravates, 10 boubous pour homme et divers articles de mercerie.
Elle est mariée et mère d’01 enfant.
texts.en:
This is a woman who got started in the commerce of clothing in 2006. She sells sewing supplies. She has included with this business the sale of dress shirts and ties. This commerce is going well for her. Office employees come and buy shirts and ties from her. She acquires her supplies from wholesalers, who import clothing. She wants to buy new assortments of shirts, ties, and some sewing items. She is therefore requesting a loan to buy 15 shirts, 50 ties, 10 boubous (long, flowing outfits) for men, and various sewing supplies. She is married and the mother of one child.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies and shirts

loans.name: God's Love Group

texts.en: Agnes is married with five children along with two extended family members. She has been engaged in the sale of dry goods such as dry peppers, sugar, garrie, garden eggs, etc. within the Moulton corner, East road community Browerville for about six years now. Her customers are attracted to her business due to the lower prices she offers and this actually encourages them. Her goal is to buy more goods at wholesale to generate more profit.

loans.use: To buy dry goods for resale

loans.name: With God Group

texts.en: Walter has been involved in foreign exchange within the Browerville Community for two years now. He’s desirous of generating more money to change his business to transport (he wants to buy a car for transport). He says, “I am successful because I give my customers a good exchange rate as compared to others and sometimes a higher rate to motivate them."

loans.use: For a foreign exchange service

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Union Fait La Force) Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi est un regroupement de 7 femmes du quartier  Moussabougou de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso) qui se sont connu depuis des années. Elles ont en moyenne 43 ans,  sont mariées et mères d’au moins 6 enfants.
Elles mènent différentes activités  génératrices de revenus telles la  vente d’habits  et de tasses. Très expérimentées dans leur domaine respectif, les activités de ces femmes marchent bien et elles  sont réellement sollicitées et enviées.  
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres  du groupe Benkadi ont décidé d’intégrer le programme de crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursés les deux précédents prêts, elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter  un important stock de tasses (thermos, aluminium etc.) et des habits pour  enfants, femmes et adolescents. Elles effectuent leurs ventes en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes.
Elles comptent réaliser en moyenne au cours du cycle 110 000 FCFA. de bénéfice. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille
texts.en:
This "Benkadi" (union makes us strong) group brings together 7 women from the Moussabougou neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region) who have known each other for years. They have an average age of 43, are married, and the mothers of at least 6 children.

They have various businesses such as selling clothing and dishes. Very experienced in their respective areas, these women have businesses that are doing well, and they are really in demand and highly thought of.

Wishing to increase the size of their businesses, the members of this Benkadi group decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After having correctly reimbursed their two previous loans, they are on their third solidarity loan (group loan).

This loan will be used to buy a big quantity of containers (thermos, aluminum etc.) and clothing for children, women and adolescents. They sell their merchandise retail, for cash or credit, to a clientele essentially made up of women. They expect to make an average profit of 110,000 F CFA over the course of this loan cycle. This profit will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover current expenses for their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing and dishes for resale

loans.name: Women Of Success Group

texts.en:
Bendu is a single mother with 2 children ages 4 and 11 years. Her children attend a private institute within the Red Hill field Community in Browerville. She sells table goods and sometimes fries doughnut (a flour product).

"I am successful in this business because the goods sold are truly needed in the community," she explained. She’s desirous of opening a bakery from proceeds generated from the business in the future.

loans.use: To buy goods for resale, and for flour to produce doughnuts

loans.name: Djiguiya  (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Djiguiya est un regroupement de cinq femmes du quartier  Moussabougou de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso) qui se sont  connu depuis des années. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants. 
Elles mènent différentes activités génératrices qui sont entre autres la vente de produits cosmétiques, d’habillements, de savons etc.
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter une quantité importante de produits cosmétiques et d’habillements à  Bamako (la capitale de la république   du mali) auprès des grossistes. Elles effectuent leurs ventes en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et de quelques hommes.
Elles ont une expérience dans leur domaine respectif, avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne au cours du cycle 115 000 FCFA. de bénéfice. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille.
Dans l’avenir, les membres du groupe Djiguiya compte obtenir chacun un prêt élevé  soit pour  ouvrir  une boutique de produits de beauté soit pour  élargir et diversifier leurs activités.
texts.en:
“Djiguiya” (hope) is a group of 5 women from the Moussabougou neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region) who have known each other for years. They have an average age of 38, are married, and the mothers of at least 4 children.

They have various businesses, among others, selling cosmetics, clothing, soap, etc. Wishing to increase the size of their businesses, the members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom, they are on their third solidarity loan.

This loan will be used to buy a big quantity of cosmetics and clothing in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from wholesalers. They sell their merchandise retail, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed of women and some men. They have experience in their respective sectors, and with this new loan they expect to make an average profit of 115,000 F CFA over the course of the loan cycle. This profit will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover current family expenses.

In future each of the members of this Djiguiya group expects to receive a bigger loan, either in order to open a cosmetics shop or to expand and diversify her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cosmetics and clothing for resale

loans.name: You Thinking Group

texts.en:
Abie J. is a mother of 3 children whose ages range between 7 – 15 years. She resides in the Outland community in Browerville and sells variety of goods on a table (fresh milk, rice, oil, sardines, etc.). 

She says, “The business is profitable and does well during the rainy season despite it being slow. I am successful because of the way I talk to my customers and the management of the business. I am also dreaming of having a very big business in the future.” She desires to train her children to become good leaders for tomorrow.

loans.use: To buy goods for resale

loans.name: Kobèkun (Encaisser Tous). Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kobèkun est composé de sept femmes du quartier Koko de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso) qui se sont connues depuis des années. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans et sont mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants. 
Elles mènent  comme activité principale la vente du bois de chauffe et le jardinage comme  activité secondaire.
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités commerciales, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après le premier prêt qui fut remboursé sans aucune difficulté, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter  quelques chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe dans les villages de Belesso Sirakélé et Tiesso, auprès des paysans, qui seront revendus à la maison au comptant et en détail à une clientèle composée de femmes, de boulangers etc.
Elles ont de l’expérience dans l’achat et la vente du bois de chauffe car elles sont équipées de charrettes à âne  et de conducteurs. Ainsi avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne au cours du cycle 55 000 FCFA de bénéfice chacune. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt  de Soro Yiriwaso et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille. 
Dans l’avenir, le groupe compte obtenir  un prêt élevé pour pouvoir se procurer des chargements de camions remorques.
texts.en:
The group “Kobèkun” (everyone stands to gain) is composed of 7 women from the Koko neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region) who have known each other for years. They have an average age of 33, are married, and the mothers of at least 4 children.

Their primary business is selling firewood and secondarily, gardening. Wishing to increase the size of their businesses, the members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After their first loan which was reimbursed without difficulty, they are on their second solidarity loan.

This loan will be used to buy several cartloads of firewood in the villages of Belesso Sirakélé and Tiesso, from the rural folk. The firewood will be sold out of their homes, for cash, retail, to a clientele composed of women, bakers, etc.

They have experience with buying and selling firewood, since they are equipped with donkey carts and drivers. With this new loan they each expect to make an average profit of 55,000 F CFA over the course of the loan cycle. This profit will be used to reimburse the interest on the Soro Yiriwaso loan and cover current family expenses.

In future, the group expects to obtain a larger loan so that they can get loads of wood in big trucks.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing firewood for resale

loans.name: Cetti

texts.en:
Cetti S. D. S. is a member of the communal bank “Cesar Vallejo” and lives in the city of Pucallpa. Cetti has a small grocery shop next to her home where she sells snacks, dry goods, drinks and vegetables. Cetti also raises chickens for sale.

Cetti has been working with Manuela Ramos for eight years and was a founding member of her communal bank. She used her very first loan to purchase goods for her shop, which has since grown a lot. Cetti will use this loan of 1000 Nuevos Soles to resupply her store. She makes a point to carefully search around for the best prices before investing in more goods.

Cetti has eight children, three of whom are still dependent upon her. She is raising these three, aged 14, 16 and 19, as a single parent. Cetti wants to continue to grow her business and is pleased to have a good location and customer base for her shop. She is happy with the help from Manuela Ramos and has been successful at paying back previous loans.

loans.use: Resupplying the store

loans.name: God Will Provide Group

texts.en: Kebbeh is a mother of three children with ages ranging between 8 – 19 years. She’s currently involved in the sale of fish and cold soft drinks. She’s been in this business for nine years now and has been meeting the needs of all her children, educationally, medically, and nutritionally. She sees this as her greatest challenge. Her goal is to get all of her children educated and be able to represent them in the outside world. She says, “I attract my customers to my business by means of the lower cost offered to them every day; they should buy goods so that I can be able to increase my offerings.”

loans.use: To buy fish and soft drinks for resale

loans.name: Layla

texts.en:
Layla is a 49-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon. Layla has owned a clothing shop for twelve years. She also sells perfumes and accessories. She requests a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase beauty products and clothes for the summer season. Layla has been a microcredit client for eight years and has always paid on time. 

Layla is special in her work because of her competitive prices. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When Layla first started this business, she didn’t face difficulties. She decided on doing her business because she likes trading. In the future, she plans on expanding her work by opening another shop.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products and clothes for the summer season.

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en:
Mostafa is a 22 year old man who lives with his wife in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Mostafa has owned a mini-market for four years. He requested a loan of 2,000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his market like cheese, yogurt, bread, water, cans and lots more. This is his second loan and he has always repaid on time.

Mostafa is special in his work because he has a big variety of products and opens till late in the evening. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had to face the competition because there are other markets in his region. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to increase his income, as well as he likes trading. In the future, he plans on expanding his business by becoming a supermarket.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his mini-market

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma P. A. is a member of the communal bank “Cesar Vallejo” and lives in the city of Pucallpa. Norma sells beauty products from Avon, Esika and Unique. She also sells sewing materials and makes and sells beaded jewelry.

Norma has been working with Manuela Ramos for nine years and used her first loan to purchase sewing materials and fabrics. Norma will use this loan of 2000 Nuevos Soles to expand her line of products for sale. She plans to purchase gift items such as soaps, hair elastics and some clothing items.

Norma is 63 and lives with her husband, her mother and her niece's 7-year-old child, whom she is raising. Norma has five of her own children, all of whom have moved out of the home. Norma must spend a lot of her time and money caring for her husband, who was incapacitated following a stroke. She has had less time lately to sew and make her jewelry products as a result. Norma has been happy working with Manuela Ramos and feels that she has been well supported by the organization. She is also pleased to have a lot of savings through Manuela Ramos’s mandatory savings program.

loans.use: To purchase gift items for sale, such as soaps, clothing and hair elastics

loans.name: Eldith

texts.en:
Eldith R. A. is a member of the communal bank “Cesar Vallejo” and lives in the city of Pucallpa. She sells clothing and shoes, most of which are ordered in advance by her customers, and also jewelry, cosmetics and perfumes.

Eldith has been working with Manuela Ramos for 11 years and used her first loan to purchase cigarettes for sale. When this business did not go well, Eldith switched to her current enterprise of selling clothing and shoes. During the day, Eldith has a job caring for the three-year-old twins of a neighbor. In the evenings, she heads out to sell her goods in nearby neighborhoods where she has regular clients who have known her a long time.
