La actividad económica a la que ella se dedica es la venta y elaboración de tortillas. Hace más de 12 años que se dedica a este negocio. La ubicación de su negocio es su humilde vivienda, por lo que la mayoría de sus clientes recurren a su vivienda. Las dos son mujeres muy luchadoras. El financiamiento que solicitan es para capital de trabajo para la compra de materia prima. El sueño de Johana es obtener una pulpería para ayudarles a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The support group "Amor y Paz" (Peace and Love) is comprised of Karla Vanesa P. Hernández and Johana del Socorro Bermúdez. Karla has two children who are minors. She has had a business selling CDs and DVDs for more than four years. Sometimes she sells her products as a street vendor so her customers will know what the new movies are and she can offer them the most recent ones since one of her goals is to offer her customers better service. The financing she is requesting will go towards working capital so she can increase her working capital. Karla's dream is to buy two motorcycle rickshaws so she can generate more income for her family. Her friend Johana has three children who are under her care. She makes and sells tortillas. She has had this business for more than twelve years. It is located in her humble home because the majority of her customers come to her home. These two women are fighters. The financing they are requesting will go towards working capital to buy supplies. Johana's dream is to own a grocery store to help her children.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en: Salamatu is a 32 year old, single young woman. She lives with her family at Sefwi, in the western region of Ghana. She is a food vendor and sells rice with gravy stew at the community where she lives. She started her operation about four years ago to take care of her home. Her food production is on a low scale because of inadequate funds to support her business. She wants to use the loan to buy more meat, vegetables and bags of rice to increase her efficiency to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and allow her to raise more income to support and finance her business growth. Currently she finances her food preparations with the sale of cosmetics.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat and firewood, etc.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa is 56 years old. She is married and has two children. One is in schooling and one is working. Her husband has been very supportive in taking care of the children. Theresa works very hard and approaches her business with commitment. For two years, she has been trading in gari sales. Gari is produced from cassava and it is one of the carbohydrate supplements. She obtains her supplies from the farming communities and retails to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy gari in bulk quantities to meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of her profits to pay her child’s educational fees.

loans.use: To buy bulk quantities of gari.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia is married with four children and they are all in school. Felicia is a 42 year old trader. She believes in hard work and dedication as the primary antidote to minimizing poverty. She is very serious with her business. 

She trades in food items like plantain. She started this business eighteen years ago and she has been very resourceful to her family. She wants to use the loan to buy a larger supply of plantains to serve her customers throughout the season. She has been facing increased prices due to the current food crisis in the country. She believes that with this loan she can buy bunches of plantain directly from the farmers, preventing middlemen who retail to her at high prices.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of plantains.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is a 41 year-old, local restaurant operator. She is married and blessed with eleven children. Currently all of her children are in school.

In her restaurant, Theresa prepares and sells local foods like "fufu" and "banku." Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain, and taken with all kinds of soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and is taken with hot pepper or soup. Theresa has been in business for the past 8 years. She says that the prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditures. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials, like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is married and mother to two children, who are currently in school. She is a 30 year-old trader. She trades in lace materials, textiles and clothing materials. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations. She mostly sells through hawking. She says hawking makes her clothing materials moves very fast. For lack of adequate working capital, she buys minimal stock of lace materials and sells through hawking. She believes the loan will enable her to expand her business to the expected level. With the loan, she wants to purchase bulk quantities of lace materials and textiles. She hopes to use part of her profit to provide her children with a quality education.

loans.use: To purchase bulk quantities of lace materials and textile.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas is a 41-year-old trader. He is married with no children. He is a very resourceful man whose hard efforts brings livelihood to the family. He supports his family through the sale of used clothing. Selling of used clothing has a very big market share in Ghana. Brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore selling of used clothing has created market for many Ghanaians. Thomas has been in this business for the past 26 years. He travels to a nearby city, called Kumasi, to purchase his stock of goods. He wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase his inventory. He believes this loan will help him save for the future.

loans.use: To buy increased bales of used clothing.

loans.name: Noelia

texts.en:
Noelia Téllez García runs a general store in the municipal market in Chinandega, the capital of the department of Chinandega, near Honduras and only one block from the beautiful El Calvario Church. 

“Variedades Noelia” or Noelia’s Variety is the name of her store where Doña Noelia sells a range of products, including hair combs and accessories, razors, pens and pencils, toothpaste, keychains, dolls and other gifts.

A 50-year-old mother and grandmother, Doña Noelia has run her store for 15 years. Before that she was a street vendor. This is her third loan with Kiva and her 24th with Kiva microfinance partner, CEPRODEL. Doña Noelia has successfully repaid her previous loans, including her first Kiva loan of $800 and her second loan of $400.

The previous loans were used to purchase additional products to sell. With this new loan she can have cash on hand to increase her inventory and obtain product discounts.

About CEPRODEL:

Founded in 1991, the Centro de Promoción del Desarrollo Local (CEPRODEL) is a nonprofit organization (NGO) based in Managua that provides socioeconomic development programs in rural and urban communities throughout western Nicaragua. More than 75% of Kiva’s CEPRODEL loans are to women. Join the Fans of CEPRODEL Kiva Lending Team at http://www.kiva.org/team/ceprodel_nicaragua.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her store

loans.name: Kafui

texts.fr: Kafui T. est une jeune femme de 39 ans mariée et mère de 3 enfants. elle est propriétaire d’un salon de coiffure à Lomé la capitale togolaise. kafui exerce cette activité depuis 5 ans et désire avec ce crédit accroître la capacité de son activité en achetant un séchoir et des mèches pour la revente.
texts.en:
Kafui T. is a thirty-nine-year-old woman and mother of three children. She is the owner of a hairdressing salon in Lomé, the capital of Togo. Kafui has been in this activity for five years. She is seeking a loan to increase the capacity of her business by purchasing a hair-dryer and locks of hair for resale.

Translated from French by Andrew Whiteman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a hair-dryer and locks of hair for resale

loans.name: La Solucion Group 4

texts.en:
Kerlyn E. is a young entrepreneur who has approached Esperanza in hopes of securing a loan to expand her small business of selling perfumes and other cosmetics throughout her neighborhood. She led the effort to organize five women to form a group, so they could come to Esperanza and request a loan.

Kerlyn currently deals primarily with perfumes that she sells door to door. In the future, she would like to expand into other cosmetic areas. She wants to sell facial creams, lipstick, and all types of makeup. With her current business, she is able to sell all of the perfume she buys, but she is constrained by how much she can purchase at one time. With the loan, she hopes to buy not only more perfume, but also other cosmetic products, so that she can reach an untapped market.

Kerlyn is a single mother raising a two-year-old daughter. One of her main aspirations is to provide a better life for her daughter She feels she begin to fulfill this aspiration by investing in her business that has, so far, been successful on a very small scale. She recognizes the opportunity to receive a loan can be rare in considering her economic situation, but she believes whole-heartedly in the potential success of her business.

loans.use: To purchase lipstick, perfumes, facial creams, and other cosmetic supplies.

loans.name: Luz En El Camino 2 Group

texts.en:
Just a few kilometers from Samaná, in the Dominican Republic, Anita H. has made a living selling cake, cookies, candies and other treats from her home to those in her neighborhood. Using the recipes she learned as a child, along with a few of her own, Anita has a corner on the baked goods market in her area. She sells these treats from her house, where she lives with her husband José and their five children. Anita loves her job. She began selling baked goodies because she is good at it and because she considers it to be less complicated than other tasks. She states that she doesn’t want the complications of taking people’s clothes to wash, or other services – she enjoys the simplicity of giving someone a few cookies over the counter in exchange for payment.

Anita has exciting goals for the future of her family and her business. She has a passion for wanting her business to continue to grow – and with this being her 6th loan cycle with Esperanza, she has shown commitment to her work. She started out small, and with each loan cycle she has been able to expand her business even more. This has benefitted her family as well. Anita is seeking to build up savings for her children. She will be able to help with any future costs, including university tuition fees. These savings will give Anita the ability to help her family in a greater array of situations that may arise in the future. This is the reason that she is focusing on saving and expanding her business.

Anita, pictured here far left, is the leader of this group of women named Luz en el Camino (Light on the Road), and her story is emblematic of the other women in her group.  Anita and the rest of Luz en el Camino thank you for your help with this Kiva loan!

loans.use: To buy ingredients used for cookies, bread and other baked goods.

loans.name: Siempre Amigas (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Siempre Amigas pertenece a la comunidad de El Valle, aproximadamente 20 minutos fuera de la ciudad de Cuenca, en el sur de Ecuador. El grupo consiste de 12 socias, es un grupo muy puntual y cumplido y las socias se llevan muy bien entre ellas.

La señora Luz tiene 46 años, es casada y tiene 6 hijos, 5 de los cuales viven con ella. Ella trabaja desde su casa, se dedica a la ganadería y la agricultura. Cría cuyes, gallinas, vacas, chanchos y ovejas, y además cosecha frijoles y maíz para consumo familiar. Ella está pidiendo un préstamo de $165 para comprar alimentos y vitaminas para sus animales, por ejemplo, hierba y harina para sus cuyes. Para el futuro, ella quisiera crecer su negocio, pero cree que no puede todavía porque está invirtiendo mucho dinero en los estudios de sus hijos, algunos de los cuales están en la universidad actualmente. “Ojala que ellos sean algo en la vida, y que salgan adelante,” dice la señora.

La señora Maria Transito es la hermana de la señora Luz. Ella tiene 53 años, es divorciada, y tiene 6 hijos, dos de los cuales viven con ella todavía. Ella hace pequeños negocios para poder pagar los estudios de sus hijos: vende leña, hace quesillo de la vaca que tiene y lo vende. Ella tiene algunas dificultades en su vida: tiene varios problemas de salud, incluyendo artritis, problemas del oído, y problemas de la vista, por eso es difícil que ella trabaje mucho. Está pidiendo un préstamo de $110, el cual usará para comprar más leña para posteriormente vender.

La señora Maria tiene 42 años, es casada, y tiene 3 hijos adolescentes. Se dedica a la crianza de animales, como cuyes, gallinas, y chanchos; además, tiene una vaca lechera. La señora también cosecha maíz, habas y porotos en sus terrenos, y dice que trabaja duro para poder hacer estudiar a sus hijos, los cuales quieren hacer algo con sus vidas. Usará su préstamo de $110 para comprar maíz para alimentar a los pollos como también alimentos para sus chanchos. Dice que este dinero le alcanzará para unos 15 días de comida.

El grupo está comprometido a pagar este préstamo puntualmente. Las socias han sido muy responsables con sus créditos anteriores.

Nota: La señora que aparece en la foto a mano derecha es la señora Rosa C., la tesorera del banco comunal. Ella no podía asistir a la reunión en la que se sacó la foto grupal, entonces se sacó una foto aparte. El jóven que sale sentado a mano izquierda en la foto es el promotor de crédito del grupo, Pedro Vasquez.
texts.en:
The communal bank group “Siempre Amigas” (Friends Forever) gathers in the community of El Valle, about 20 minutes outside the city of Cuenca in southern Ecuador. The group consists of 12 members who are punctual, courteous, and get along very well with each other.

Mrs. Luz is 46 years old, married and has 6 children, 5 of whom live with her. She works from home, raising livestock and cultivating crops. She breeds guinea pigs, chickens, cows, pigs and sheep, and also harvests corn and beans for her family’s consumption. She is requesting a loan of $165 to buy food and vitamins for her animals, such as grass and grain for her guinea pigs. In the future, she would like to grow her business, but she cannot believe that she still spends lots of money on her children’s education. Some of them are in college now. "Hopefully they will turn out to be something in life and succeed," she said.

Mrs. Maria Transito is the sister of Mrs. Luz. She is 53 years old, divorced and has 6 children, two of whom live with her. She has two small businesses that help pay for her children's education: selling wood and cheese she makes from the milk of her own cows. She has faced a few challenges in her life – including health problems such as arthritis, hearing problems, and vision problems that have made it difficult for her to do much work. She is asking for a loan of $110, which will be used to buy firewood to sell later.

Mrs. Maria is 42 years old, married and has 3 teenage children. She raises animals such as guinea pigs, chickens, pigs and dairy cows. This woman also grows corn, broad beans and kidney beans in her fields. She said that she works hard so that her children can study and make something out of their lives. Maria will use her loan of $110 to buy feed for her chickens and pigs. She said that the money will be enough to feed her animals for 15 days.

The group is committed to pay the loan on time. The members have been very responsible with previous loans.

Note: The lady who appears in the photo on the right is Mrs. Rosa C., the treasurer of the community bank group. She could not attend the meeting when the group photo was made, so a separate photo was taken. The young man sitting on the left is the group’s loan officer, Pedro Vasquez.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase animal feed

loans.name: Arcoiris Group 1

texts.en:
Teofila P., pictured on the right, is the coordinator of her 5-member group. She resides in Carlo Alvares, a small town in the sector of Villa Mella, part of Santo Domingo Norte. She lives with her husband and four children: two girls ages 18 and 13, and two boys ages 9 and 6. The oldest girl currently studies tourism in college. Teofila works hard so all of her children can attend school. She currently operates a "san" business. This is a business where people order a product from her, and then pay her weekly or monthly. Once they have paid enough for the item, she buys it and delivers it to them.

Teofila plans to use this loan in order to stock up on the items with the greatest demand, such as pressure cookers, cooking wear, and sandals. By buying them before they have been ordered, she can purchase them in bulk at lower prices and proviD. faster service. As a result, she will be able to handle more customers investing in her "san," and increase her flow of income. With the increased income, she hopes to be able to afford a technology course for her 13-year-old and take beauty classes.

Some of Teofila's long term goals are to place all four of her children through college and to improve her current living situation.

loans.use: Pressure cookers, cooking wear, and sandals.

loans.name: Cesar

texts.en:
César is 50 years old, married and has two children who are 14 and 5 years old. For twenty-eight years he has worked as a bus driver in Cusco, located in the Sacred Valley of Perú. César has graduated through two loans with Arariwa, making all of his payments on time and participating in monthly group meetings.

Currently César is building a new home for his family. Construction is in the final phase, and he needs a loan to purchase adobe bricks and cement. He plans to run a small general store from his home as well to supplement his income as a driver.

loans.use: To buy building materials for home construction

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es: La Sra. Maria Esther L., es cliente antigua, trabajo desde el año 2006, juntamente con su esposo, quien es transportista, ella tiene un hijo pequeño, por lo que se dedica más a esta actividad de repartir a crédito la mercaderia de cosmeticos, ya que anteriormente tambien tenía otra actividad, la de trabajaar como ayudante en la guarderia de Chasquipampa, ella vino recomendada por su Sra. mamá, quien era cliente de Emprender, hasta la fecha ella tiene buen historial y trabaja con puntualidad y responsabilidad en el crédito.
texts.en:
Maria Esther L. is an old customer who has worked since 2005 alongside her husband who is a truck driver. She has one small child. The activity to which she will be dedicating the majority of her loan is selling cosmetics. Previously, she also had another job working as an assistant at the Cashquipampa daycare. She came recommended by her mother, who was a customer of Emprender. Until today, she has had a good history paying her loans on time and working responsibly.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Ramona's Group

texts.en:
Gregoria G. M., pictured second from the right and dressed in white, is the group coordinator for her 5-member group called "Trabajadores Unidos", which means "United Workers". She is the single mother of three children: a daughter of 22, and two boys ages 18, and 10. They reside in Paraiso Escondido, a small town in the sector of Punta de Villa Mella, in Santo Domingo Norte. Her daughter began studying law last year, her oldest son is a sophomore in high school, and her youngest son is a talented baseball player.

Her home, along with her previous business, a general store in her home, was swept away when a river flooded near her house last year, taking four other houses with it. As a result, her two oldest children had to stop going school to meet their basic needs. She is starting over now by opening up a similar store from her home, selling general care products and basic medicines.

Gregoria plans to invest in such products as hair-smoothing cream, deodorants, shampoos, medicines, and sandals, which she buys in bulk and says are the products in highest demand. The home she is living in now, Gregoria says, is located in a very strategic business location relative to her town. At the end of this loan, she hopes her store will be firmly reestablished, providing her once more with a steady source of income. With this steady income, she hopes to start saving for her daughter's education, and to be able to pay for her sons' schooling and for the baseball coaching and cleats for her youngest son. She also plans to continue working on finishing her current home, as she has placed 800 out of 1,300 cinder blocks for it so far. Since her business is run from her home, having it completed would allow her business to expand.

Some of her long-term goals are to be able to pay for her daughter's law school education, and also to be able to continue to encourage and support her youngest son, as they hope he makes it to the big leagues.

loans.use: To buy hair-smoothing cream, shampoos, deodorants, sandals and medicines

loans.name: Herlinda

texts.es:
La señora Herlinda vive con su esposo Enrique Mascorro y sus dos hijos de edad escolar, ella le lleva la contaduría a  su esposo ya que el es contratista de diferentes casas residenciales (realiza la construcción con sus empleados de las casas).
De acuerdo a sus ingresos son una familia estable económicamente, pero tienen un proyecto que le están realizando a su vivienda, que es la ampliación del frente de su casa, llevan un gran avance, pero están requiriendo la compra de más material, ya que en dicha ampliación desean establecer un negocio de ferretería.
Este es el proyecto a realizar de esta familia, motivo por el cual tramitan este crédito.
texts.en:
Herlinda lives with her husband Enrique Mascorro and their two children who are school age. She manages the accounting for her husband since he is a contractor for different residential houses (he does construction with his employees in the homes). In accordance with their income, they are a family who is stable economically, but they have a project that they are working on in their home: extending the front of the house. They are taking a big step forward but they need to buy more material since, in this extension, they want to build a hardware business. This is the project that this family is trying to achieve and for which they have requested this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Extension of the front of their house.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.es:
La señora Ofelia Z. vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos, su esposo labora en una empresa de repartición de frituras desde hace 3 años. 
Ella es propietaria de una tiendita de abarrotes de nombre “Abarrotes Ofelia “ negocio establecido desde hace  3 años, demostrando constancia para que su negocio vaya creciendo y por tal motivo esta solicitando este crédito para la inversión en compra de mas mercancía y así cubrir las necesidades de sus clientes y lograr un mayor ingreso.
texts.en:
Ofelia Z. lives with her husband and their two children. Her husband has worked in a fast food businessfor three years. She is the proprieter of a little grocery store named "Abarrotes Ofelia" (Ofelia's Groceries), established three years ago which is showing certain growth. As a result, she is requesting this loan in order to invest in more merchandise and cover her customers' needs and earn greater income.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment for business.

loans.name: Carminia

texts.en:
Carminia is 27 years old and has two children (2 and 5 years old) with her common-law husband. She has a small general store in Cusco, located in the Sacred Valley of Perú. Carminia needs a loan to have the capital available to place daily orders of vegetables and meats for her store.

Carminia is a member of an Arariwa communal group called "Cusco Sur" which meets every month with a loan officer to review payments and discuss how everyone's business is doing.

In the future Carmen hopes to save enough money to build her own home for her family.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and meat in bulk for general store

loans.name: Jesus Joaquin

texts.es:
El señor Jesús Joaquín es soltero y vive con sus papas, donde contribuye con los ingresos para los gastos familiares. 
El es propietario de un taller eléctrico de nombre “Hermanos tres G. “donde realiza la reparación de televisiones, radios, esteros, bocinas, etc. 
Negocio que tiene establecido desde hace 5 años, fructífero con la dedicación que se le debe de dar a un negocio propio, ya que cuenta con su clientela establecida. 
Esta solicitando este crédito para la compra de mercancía y tener en bodega las partes y herramientas para sus reparaciones.
texts.en:
Jesús Joaquín is single and lives with his parents to whom he contributes money for the family's bills. He is the proprieter of an electronic shop named "Hermanos tres G." (The Three G. Brothers) where repairs of televisions, radios, stereos, speakers, etc. are conducted. His business was established five years ago, now fruitful from the dedication that one ought to give to his own business and with an established clientele. He is requesting this loan in order to purchase merchandise and to have parts and tools on hand for his repairs.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in the business.

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es:
La señora Guadalupe y su hermano David viven juntos y tiene un negocio que acaban de iniciar de nombre “Estética Biby” donde realizan cortes de cabello, tintes, bases, etc. 
El motivo de esta solicitud de crédito es para la inversión en compra de mercancía y materiales que requieren al momento de realizar un trabajo a sus clientes y así cubrir sus necesidades.
texts.en:
Guadalupe and her brother David live together and have a business that they just started, named "Estética Biby", where they cut, color and style hair. This loan is requested in order to invest in merchandise and materials that they need when they are working on their customers, so that they have what they need on hand.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Kamsvaag, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in the business

loans.name: Yecenia

texts.es: Yecenia tiene 40 años, vive con su pareja quien es albañil y sus hijos; Katy de 15, Malú de 12, Herbert de 10 y Brayan de 3 años en su casa propia. Se dedica a la renta de su carro y motocarro en el distrito de Comas de la ciudad de Lima, ya que eso le da buenas ganancias y puede realizarlo desde casa, ya que sus hijos le demandan tiempo ya que se encuentran en edad escolar. Yecenia siempre ha sido muy trabajadora y ha desempeñado variedad de oficios, pero es conciente que sus hijos están en una edad en que necesitan de su apoyo, es por eso que decidió incursionar en este negocio, ya que el sueldo de albañil de su esposo no cubre todas las necesidades de su hogar, además siendo los dos los que trabajen se hace más llevaderos los gastos. A Yecenia le gusta mucho su trabajo, pero también es un riesgo alquilar sus vehículos, puesto que siempre regresan con algún daño lo cual no le conviene pues las reparaciones son caras, por ello sólo alquila a personas confiables. Para el futuro le gustaría comprar otro auto para poder tener una flota, los cuales le arrojen buenos ingresos. Este es su primer préstamo individual y se siente muy feliz de trabajar con Microfinanzas PRISMA porque siempre le fue muy bien. Con el dinero que ahora solicita refaccionará su auto para dejarlo en óptimas condiciones para que pueda trabajar y lograr mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Yecenia is 40 years old and lives in her own home with her spouse, who is a bricklayer, and their children: Katy - 15, Malú - 12, Herbert - 10, and Brayan - 3. She rents out her car and motor cart in the Comas district of Lima, because this produces good income and is something that she can do from home, since her children, who are school-aged, need her. Yecenia has always been very hard-working and has done a variety of jobs, but she is aware that her children are of an age now that they need her support. This is why she decided to start this business, because her husband's wages as a bricklayer is not enough to cover the household's living expenses, while with two people working the expenses are more manageable. Yecenia enjoys her work a lot, but it is also risky to rent out her vehicles, because they often come back with some kind of damage, which is a problem because repairs are expensive. For that reason she only rents to trustworthy people. In the future she would like to buy another car in order to have a fleet, which could bring in good income. This is her first individual loan and she is very happy to be working with Microfinanzas PRISMA because things have always worked out well. With the money that she is requesting now, she will do a makeover on her car to leave it in top condition so that she can work and earn a higher income.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Kamsvaag, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Reparación de su auto

loans.name: Barkat Muhammad Siddique Group

texts.en:
Farhat parveen baji wants a loan to buy material (hard paper, gum) for her sweetmeat box making business.  
Ayesha baji wants a loan to buy garments to sell. 
Tayyaba baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell. 

Barkat baji is a wife of M. S. who has lived in Arifwala, Pakistan for the last 15 years. Her husband deals with both ladies & gents garments. He has a good number of customers because of his variety and quality. Barkat baji is a very supportive and kind lady. She helps her members when they need her. She is applying for a loan to buy garments to increase the profit of her husband’s business.


This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. 

Note: “Barkat baji wears a white shawl in this picture”.

loans.use: To buy garments to sell

loans.name: Rukhsana Muhammad Faryad Group

texts.en:
Kosar baji and Asia baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 
Asma baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. 
Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy wheat & corn to sell. 

My name is Rukhsana and I have belonged to a city named Arifwala, Pakistan for the last 10 years. I got married at the age of 20 to M. F.. He is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). He has been in this profession for over three years. I am an uneducated lady because the community was very conservative at that time and not in the right of women's education. I am applying for a loan to repair my husband’s auto-rickshaw because it's creating problems and repairing it has become essential. 


This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. 

Note: “Rukhsana baji is seated in the middle of the other baji’s”.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Lennie

texts.en:
Lennie R. is from the village of Pinig, Dumalinao. She is 28 years old. Lennie is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Lennie works in a family member's business raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale. Lennie has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lennie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lennie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Lennie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lennie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Umeda

texts.ru: Умеда Кодирова 1981 года рождения. Она замужем имеет2 детей. Имеет среднее образование. Закончив школу  родители не смогл устроить в университет. Через год вышла замуж и сидела дома. Муж работал в то время водителем, потом он поменял работу, сейчас он мастерит помещения и проводит ремонт. Она решила заняться бизнесом мелочей.  Она хотела расширить немного свой бизнес и заняла у матери. Так начала со временем торговать обувью. Зимой покупала не большую партию  теплых тапочек и весной и летом  шлепки и сланцы.  Узнав у соседей о кредите она решила расширить свой товарооборот.  Посоветовавшись с мужем ей понравились  условия после получения кредита от КИВА купила летнюю обувь.
texts.en:
Umeda K. was born in 1981. She is married and has 2 children. She has a secondary education. When she finished school, her parents were unable to send her to a university. She got married a year later and stayed home. Umeda’s husband worked as a driver at that time and then switched jobs. Now he does home remodeling and repairs. Umeda decided to start selling small items. She wanted to expand her business a bit and borrowed from her mother. With time, she started selling shoes. She bought a small stock of warm slippers in the winter and a stock of flip flops and slippers in the spring and summer. Having found out about financing from her neighbors, Umeda decided to increase her goods turnover. She talked it over with her husband and liked the lending terms. After receiving the credit from Kiva, she bought summer shoes.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of summer shoes

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.ru:
Гулнора Джураева  1973 года рождения, замужем имеет 1 ребенка. Имеет среднее образование.  Занимается торговлей женской одеждой . Торгует на рынке более 5 лет.  
Раньше торговала на рынке города на улице.  После получения  очередного кредита  арендовала помещение на новом рынке «Сомон».  У нее расширился  оборот и клиентов больше чем на улице. 
От полученной прибыли она увеличила свой капитал. Что позволит ей расширить бизнес.
texts.en:
Born in 1973, Gulnora D. is married and has 1 child. She has a secondary education. Gulnora sells women’s clothing. She has been selling at the market for over 5 years. Previously, she used to sell on the street at the city market. After obtaining a loan, she leased a space at the new Somon market. Her turnover increased, and she now has more clients than she had on the street. She used the resulting profit to increase her capital. This will help her expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of summer goods

loans.name: Rani Manzoor Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Janu baji and Fozia baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

Sardaran baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. 

Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy wheat and corn to sell. 

Rani baji is a wife of M. A.. They have lived in Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 15 years. She is the leader of this group. All of the members respect her a lot because her behavior with them is very nice and caring. She never gets angry at them and always supports them when they have any trouble. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the community. Rani baji is applying for a loan to buy groceries to diversify her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.
 
Note: Rani baji is seated in a black shawl in the photo.

loans.use: To buy groceries

loans.name: Shahnaz Amanat Ali Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread, and clothes) for her decorative embroidery business. 

Sabran baji wants a loan to buy a movie camera for her movie making business. 

Bushra baji wants a loan to buy electric supplies (wires, switches, and switch boards) for her electric supplies business. 

Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

Another Shahnaz baji is the leader of this group. She is a very caring lady. Her members are very happy with her because she supports them in their businesses. Her husband's name is A. A.. They have lived in the city of Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Both of them are very hard working, and they help each other. Her husband deals with seasonal fruit. He buys fruit wholesale and sells it to the fruit shops in various towns. Shahnaz baji helps him by packing the fruit in boxes. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits to expand her husband’s fruit-selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Bushra baji is wearing a white shawl in the photo.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Naziran Muhammad Tufail Group

texts.en:
Ameeran baji wants a loan to buy wheat and corn to sell. 

Another Ameeran baji wants a loan to buy fruit to sell. 

Naziran baji is a wife of M. T.. She has lived in the city of Arifwala, Pakistan for 15 years. Her husband deals with fruit. He buys fruit wholesale and sells it to fruit shops. He also treks to other towns to sell his fruit. Naziran baji is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits to increase her husband's profits. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Naziran baji is seated second from the right.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Badamhand

texts.en:
Badamhand S. is a 55-year-old widow who lives with her 22-year-old daughter in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. She has raised four children and her husband passed away quite some time ago. She currently lives with her youngest daughter who is a student in a local university. 

Badamhand runs a small sewing shop. She makes various customized clothes for women according to her customers' requests. She started her small shop in 1990 with her old sewing machine. Since then, she has been running her sewing shop for 19 years and has retained regularly visiting customers. She says that with her sewing business, she has been able to raise four children who are all highly educated and doing well on their own now. She requests a loan to purchase necessary materials for her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her business

loans.name: Sakina Maqbool Hussain Group

texts.en:
My name is Sakina, and I have lived in Arifwala, Pakistan, for 15 years. I own a two-room brick house in which I live with my family: my husband and my two children. My husband's name is M. H.. He runs a dairy business. Actually, he buys milk from the milk men and sells the milk to the community. This work requires a struggle and the profits are small. Therefore, we decided to buy a buffalo so we could sell our own milk to the milk shops.  

I am the group leader of two other women from my locality. Parveen akhtar baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy fruits for her fruit selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.
 
Note: Sakina baji is seated on the right.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo

loans.name: Suraiya  Liaqat Ali Group

texts.en:
Suraiya baji is a wife of L. A.. They have lived in Arifwala, Pakistan for 15 years. Her husband is an experienced salesman who decided to start his own grocery shop. Presently, he is running his own grocery shop and his good deals bring more customers to his shop. Suraiya baji is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop.

She is the group leader of two other women from her locality. Naziran baji also wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy tea to sell.


This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Suraiya baji is seated in the center of the three women.

loans.use: To buy groceries

loans.name: Khursheed Maqbool Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Khursheed baji is a wife of M. A. who has lived in Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the community. People come to him to buy groceries because of his normal rates on groceries which his customers can easily pay. Khursheed baji is applying for a loan to buy groceries to diversify her husband’s grocery shop. 
 
Khursheed baji is the group leader of three other women from her locality.  Waziran baji and Amina baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their milk-selling businesses. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy vegetables to sell.


This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Khursheed baji is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy groceries

loans.name: Shamshad Muhammad Bota Group

texts.en:
Shamshad baji has been a citizen of a city named Arifwala in Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband's name is M. B. and he runs a food business in the community. People come from different towns to place orders because of his quality food. He sells specifically Punjabi food items such as samosas and Dahi bhala. Shamshad baji prepares these items. Her husband admits that his whole success belongs to his wife, Shamshad. She feels very proud of this compliment. She is applying for a loan to buy materials (flour, spices and cooking oil) to expand the food-selling business.

She is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Rashida baji and Maqboolan baji each want a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy materials (sugar, dry fruits and cooking oil) for her sweetmeat-selling business. Zareena baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. 

Note: Shamshad baji is seated in the middle of the members.

loans.use: To buy materials for food-selling business

loans.name: Mumtaz Saeed Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz baji is a widow who has lived in a city named Arifwala in Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband died of a heart attack. Mumtaz baji is a very strong lady. She never loses courage and fights very bravely despite the circumstances. She is the mother of two sons. She never took her younger son from school. She pays the school fees from her clothes-sewing business. Her elder son runs a fruit-selling business. Mumtaz baji is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits to expand her son’s fruit-selling business.  

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Tahira parveen baji wants a loan to buy tools for her motor-repair workshop. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Amina baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Mumtaz baji is seated on the right side in the photo.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Nasreen Muhammad Ashiq Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is married to M. A. and they both have resided in a city named Chichawatni in Pakistan for the past 10 years. They are a very hardworking couple. Nasreen baji operates a sewing business to share the financial burden with her husband, who runs a food-selling business in the community. He sells specifically Punjabi foods like Dahi bhalas and samosas. He has been doing this business for the past five years. Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) to grow her husband’s food-selling business.

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Najma naheed baji wants a loan to buy vegetables to sell. Bushra baji and Parveen akhtar baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Nasreen baji is working on her sewing machine in this photo.

loans.use: To buy material for food-selling business

loans.name: Vladimir

texts.en:
Vladimir is married with one child. He makes and fixes furniture. Vladimir started this business nine years ago. It was one of his friends who suggested Vladimir try this business. It turned out that there was (and still is!) a high demand for furniture. It helped Vladimir to develop his business fast. Vladimir does his work quickly and with high quality. He is honest with his clients and they repay him with good recommendations and new clients.

Vladimir would like to borrow 6,500 UAH to purchase materials for furniture manufacturing. He hopes to receive additional income and improve his living conditions. His business goal is to offer a larger variety of furniture items.

loans.use: To purchase materials

loans.name: Nasreen Kosar Muhammad Ali Group

texts.en:
Nasreen kosar baji is the wife of M. A. who has lived in Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 11 years. Her husband has a fruit selling business. He buys fruit wholesale from the wholesalers, sells to the fruit shops, and earns income. Nasreen baji is a very responsible lady. She takes care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits to increase her husband’s fruits selling business. 

Nasreen baji is seated with her group members, carrying her grandson. The one next to her is named Shamshad baji and she wants a loan to buy wheat to sell. The third is Rubi baji who wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). The fourth is Asifa Noreen who also wants an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Jambalnyambuu

texts.en: Jambalnyambuu T. lives with her husband and two children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her two children are both university students in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She grows various vegetables on a small piece of land and sells her products at the local market. She mostly grows carrots, potatoes, tomatoes, cabbages, etc. She started her vegetable growing business in 1998 and since then, she has done well. For the last eleven years, her business capital has increased from 100,000 MNT to 1,500,000 MNT. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and create a wholesale market of various vegetables for local people. She requests a loan to increase her working capital for a business expansion.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to increase her business inventory

loans.name: Naseem Akhtar Sadiq Ali Shahid Group

texts.en:
Naseem akhtar baji has been a citizen of Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 15 years. Her husband's name is S. A. S.. He has a wheat & rice selling business. He buys these two things wholesale and sells to the customers. Naseem baji is applying for a loan to buy wheat & rice to sell.  

She is the group leader of two other women from her locality. Another Naseem akhtar baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Safina K. baji wants a loan to buy material (clothes, colored thread and beads) for her decorative embroidery business.
 
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: “Naseem akhtar baji is standing in the middle of the baji’s”.

loans.use: To buy wheat & rice on wholesale

loans.name: Miroslava

texts.en:
Miroslava is a widow; she has two grown daughters. Miroslava sells women's underwear at one of markets in Ivano-Frankovsk. She started this business 10 years ago, after she became unemployed because of a downsizing at the factory she used to work at. During this time she was able to develop her business well. Today Miroslava has got two business locations. A large assortment and low prices help Miroslava to win new and retain old clients. This business is her only source of income.

Miroslava would like to borrow 10,000 UAH to purchase 100 sets of women's underwear to increase her assortment. Miroslava needs to fix her apartment to have decent living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase 100 sets of underwear

loans.name: Khut

texts.en: Khut S., 44, has been producing baskets in Takeo Province at her house since 2000, with an income of US$ 3.3 per day. She lives with her husband and three school-aged children. Her husband raises ducks to sell and earns around US$ 16.6 per day. Seeing an opportunity to generate more income from raising ducks and selling them with a fairly profitable price, S. wants to take a loan of US$1200 to purchase more ducks. By doing this, she is very optimistic that she will be able to make a good standard of living. (S. is pictured with her husband)

loans.use: To buy more ducks

loans.name: Razia Begum Group

texts.en:
Razia B. baji has been a citizen of a city named Chichawatni, Pakistan, for the past ten years. Her husband is a driver and drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor-vehicle).

Razia B. baji is a very hardworking lady. At an early age her mother started teaching her about cooking and domestic chores because she knew that she couldn’t send her to school. Razia B. baji performs her duties in a very effective way. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor-vehicle) for her husband so that he earns the whole income of his struggle. 

Razia B. baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality:

Lubna baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food-selling business.

Hanifan wants a loan to buy cold drinks to sell.

Bushra B. baji wants a loan to buy vehicle repair tools for her motor workshop.

Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading.

Note: Razia B. baji is seated near to the stove in the photo.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her husband

loans.name: Komilhodja

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Комилходжа продаёт обувь на рынке Паншанбе, товар привозит из Истаравшана.Свои кредиты он использует на расширение своего бизнеса.На следующий займ он хочет привезти летний ассортимент мужских шлёпанцев и сланцев.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Komilhodja sells shoes on the Panshabe market, he brings the merchandise from Istaravshan. He uses his loans to expand his business. He wants to use the next loan to bring in summer assortment of mens' flip flops.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes

loans.name: Hamidan Haji Talib Hussain Group

texts.en:
In this photo, Hamidan baji is seated with her group members, holding a child in the right side of the picture. She is a very sincere and gentle lady. She takes care of all her responsibilities in a very effective way. Her husband's name is H. T. H., and he runs a cold-drink corner. He has been doing this work for the past 3 years. She is applying for a loan to buy cold drinks to increase the profit of her drink corner.

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy embroidery material (colored thread, clothes, and beads) for preparing embroidered dresses. Naheed kosar baji wants a loan to buy a welding machine, and Iftikhar kosar wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy cold drinks for drink corner

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia, 51, lives with her carpenter husband in a government housing project for the poor in San Vicente, Brgy. 178, Caloocan City. Their three children are already living independently with their own families.

Cecilia sells vegetables and fish in her own stall along the busy street of her community. She hires one of her neighbors to assist her in tending her business, especially on busy days.

She earns 2,500 PHP per week, which she uses to maintain her business. She saves a large portion of her earnings for the family's other needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for her vegetable stall

loans.name: Si

texts.en: Si P., 32, is a widow. She is a hairdresser and a farmer on her own plot of farmland, with an income of 2 USD per day in Takeo Province. She lives with her three school-aged children and an old mother. Due to the difficulty of being responsible for the expenses of the three children and an old mother, she wants to take out a loan of 500 USD to expand her current hairdressing business. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to generate more income because she is skillful in the business and she has repeat customers who always come to her shop when they need to attend a ceremony or a wedding party. (P. is pictured with ropes used for tying her cows.)

loans.use: Buying equipment for her barbershop

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en:
Emelita D., 30, runs a small eatery in front of her house. She learned the secrets of the trade from her parents when she was still young. In 1991, she started the business on her own. Her business earns 2,000 PHP per week for her family. She dreams of converting her small place into a big restaurant someday.

Emelita lives in the populous barrio of San Vicente, Brgy. 178 Caloocan City. Her husband, Ramly, is a trained electronics technician. Emelita and Ramly have three children, all of whom are in grade school.

Emelita is currently on her fifth loan cycle with CCT. She uses her loans to keep her eatery business going. The profits go to her children's education and to meet their basic daily needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for a food business and for education expenses

loans.name: Phol

texts.en:
Phol M., 36, has been involved in her business of producing pillowcases since 2008 for an income of US$5 per day. She lives with her husband and three school-aged children. Her husband sells her production and bedroom sets for an income of US$13 per day in his village and in other nearby places that he can easily access with his motorbike.

M. wants to take a loan US$750 to expand the inventory of her husband’s business because she thinks that she will be able to generate more income for savings and expenses. M. is shown in the picture with her husband.

loans.use: To buy nets and blankets for her husband's business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita S., 44, manages a small furniture workshop where her 59-year-old husband Oscar (shown with Teresita in the picture above) and youngest son work as craftsmen.  They live in Bagong Silang, one of the biggest barrios in Caloocan City. Teresita and Oscar also have four grown children.

The business, which Teresita started in 1985, supplies wooden beds, cabinets and other household furniture to a number of stores in the city as well as to individual customers who place orders in advance. The business earns Php 2,500.00 profit per week.  Teresita will use her new loan to purchase raw materials like wood, paints, varnish, nails. and other tools of the trade.

Teresita hopes to see her workshop someday employing skilled men around her community. Oscar dreams of purchasing a second-hand delivery truck in the near future.

loans.use: Raw materials (wood, paint, nails and tools)

loans.name: Kishwar Rasheed Ahmad Group
loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

loans.name: Salma Muhammad Saleem Group

texts.en:
Salma Baji helps her husband by operating a sewing business. Her husband, M. S., sells mobile phones. He buys used sets and sells them to customers. He has been in this business for the past three years. Salma Baji is applying for a loan to buy more mobile phones for her husband’s business. She is seated second from the right, sewing clothes on her sewing machine.

This loan is for five people and the other members of the group are: Akhtar Naheed Baji wants a loan to repair her sewing machine for sewing clothes. Samina Kosar Baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics and a hair dryer for her parlor. Kalsoom Akhtar Baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her tailoring center. Hanifan Baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her drug store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy used mobile phones to sell

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren S., 60, lives with his wife and two children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His oldest son is 29 years old and is currently unemployed. His 17-year-old son is a high school student.

Purevsuren is a carpenter. He makes wooden furniture, including sofas, chairs, tables, etc. He has been in the carpentry business since 2000. Compared to the beginning when he started with 300,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT), his business has expanded and business capital has increased to 2,100,000 MNT. He says that, because of his small business, he has been able to raise his five children and help the three oldest ones to have their own lives. His hope is now to make sure that his two youngest children get married and launch their own businesses.

Purevsuren requests a loan to purchase more wood for his carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood as a raw material

loans.name: Rochelle

texts.en:
Rochelle V., 25, lives with her nine-month-old baby and her husband in a small house in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.  Her husband works as a waiter in a nearby restaurant.

A young entrepreneur and mother, Rochelle scours night markets, bargain centers and bazzars to purchase her wares, from RTW (ready to wear dresses) to cosmetic items, which she then sells to her customers at a fairly low price.  She earns a weekly average of Php 1,500.00 on cosmetics alone, aside from other products she sells.

Rochelle dreams of having her own boutique where she can sell her items so she won’t need to leave her child in the care of relatives every time she leaves to tend to her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to increase inventory.

loans.name: Eang

texts.en:
Eang P., 50, has been involved in her business of producing pillowcases and hammocks with an income of US$6.60 per day since 1995. She lives with her husband and four children, two of whom are students, and the rest are employed as garment factory workers. Her husband sells her production and bedroom sets for his customers in his village and other places where he is easily accessible.

P. wants to take a loan of US$1,200 to expand her husband’s current business because she really hopes that her investment of the loan will be able to generate more income. P. is shown in the photo with her husband and the hammock she produced.

loans.use: To buy nets and blankets for her husband's business

loans.name: Asia Muhammad Ramzan Group

texts.en:
Asia Baji is applying for a loan to buy supplies like lentils, cooking oil and spices for a Punjabi food selling business. Her husband, M. R., sells Punjabi foods in the community. People give him orders for family functions such as marriages and birthdays. Asia Baji helps him by preparing the food. They have been citizens of the city of Chichawatni, Pakistan for the past 15 years.

Farzana Baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Zubaida Baji wants a loan to buy tools for a motor workshop. Razia Baji wants a loan to buy fruit to sell. Shabana Baji wants a loan to buy bangles to sell.

Asia Baji is wearing a black shawl in the photo. The other members of this group are seated around her. Shabana Baji is showing her bangles in this photo.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy supplies for a Punjabi food selling business

loans.name: Ben

texts.en: Ben S., 30, is a local farmer and she uses her spare time to produce scarfs at her house. She has a typical income of around $1.60 US per day. She lives with her husband and two school-aged children. Her husband is a local police authority in Takeo Province with an income of $2.50 US per day. She really wants a loan of $1000 US to buy a motorbike for transporting her products to sell at the local markets in her province. S. is photographed with her craft work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to take craftwork to market

loans.name: Cheam

texts.en:
Cheam P., 49, raises livestock and is a local rice cultivator too, with an income of US$2 per day. She lives in Takeo Province with her husband and her two children who are all employed as garment factory workers. Since 1998, her husband has always traveled far to do business in Phnom Penh as a motor-taxi driver with an income of US$7 per day.

P. wants to take a loan of US$1,200 to buy equipment for one of her sons to begin a business of repairing motors in the village. By operating this job for her son, she will have more labor force to help generate more income for the family’s expenses and use.

P. was not available for the photo, so her husband is pictured instead with his motorbike.

loans.use: To buy equipment for a motor-repair shop for her son

loans.name: Farhat Liaqat Ali Group

texts.en:
Farhat baji, wife of L. A., has lived in a city named Chichawatni, Pakistan, for the past fifteen years. Her husband sells sugarcane juice; his business grows in summer because people drink a lot of liquid in this season. Farhat baji operates an clothes-embroidering business and she does this work to pay off the utilities. She is seated in a yellow shawl holding a frame in her hands in the photo.

This loan is based on a total of four persons and the other members of this loan are:

Kosar baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

Rukhsana kosar baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

Muniran baji wants a loan to buy construction supplies to sell.

loans.use: To buy sugarcane for her husband's juice-selling business

loans.name: Chhun's Group

texts.en:
Chhun S., 30, has a business of collecting palm fruits and a kind of insect (large red ants) used for cooking. Her husband usually helps her with this business after his work as a farmer in the rice field and orchard. She lives with her husband and three school-aged children. 

S. has a gross income of $33 US per day. Seeing an opportunity to generate more income for the family, she wants a loan of $1000 US to purchase more palm fruit and red ants to resell. By doing this, she hopes she will be able to have a better standard of living and reserve some savings for her children’s future education.

S. and her husband are in the photo with ants they collected.

loans.use: To buy palm fruits and large red ants

loans.name: Ghzala Yasmeen Javed Iqbal Group

texts.en:
Ghzala Yasmeen baji has lived in Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 15 years. Her husband, J. I., sells clothing. He buys clothes from the city Multan because the clothes are less expensive there, and he resells them in his native city. He also treks to different towns and communities to sell the clothes. Ghzala baji also sews clothes to pay off the utilities. She is applying for a loan to buy additional clothing to advance her husband’s business.

She is the leader of a group including three other women from her locality. The other members and their loan uses are as follows:

Rubina Arshad baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Anayat baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Ruqaiya Bano baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Ghzala baji is showing her sewing machine in this photo.

loans.use: To buy clothing to resell

loans.name: Michael Odhiambo

texts.en:
Michael is a married man and the father of an 8-month-old girl. He has been a tailor for three years after finishing two years of training at a center in the neighborhood of Nyalenda. He is now working in downtown Kisumu. With the proceeds from his loan, he would like to buy an overlock machine which he will use in finishing his various types of garments. He would also like to purchase some more materials including fabric and threads.

Right now, Michael earns a salary as he works alongside about 40 other tailors in the large company called Blackberry. He would like to branch out on his own, and has the confidence that he will be successful. His dream is to get a small place at the lake market. Michael currently specializes in men’s and women’s clothing and children’s school uniforms. He makes shirts, pants, skirts and dresses, and also repairs damaged clothing. Michael is a hard-working man who desires to support his family.

K-MET, the NGO giving the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional MFI. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. For more information about K-MET, please use the following link: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=24

loans.use: To buy a new machine and more materials

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan P., 29, sells palm sugar, a very delicious commonly used sugar in Cambodia, at the local market in Phnom Penh City. He has a gross revenue of $83 US per day. He lives with his wife and three school-aged children. His wife is a garment factory worker with a daily income of around $3.30 US. He is very optimistic that if he invests in his business he will be able to generate a greater income. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of $700 US in order to purchase more palm sugar to expand his inventory.

loans.use: To buy palm sugar.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a tailor who specializes in uniforms, petticoats, and pants - especially for children. She runs her business, Beatrice Fashion, in the Kibuye Market of Kisumu, Kenya. She graduated from her 2-year training course in 1997 and has been working at her trade ever since.

At times, Beatrice experiences cash-flow problems, but knows that she can rely on a steady stream of business from her regular customers. At times, she has so much business that she has to hire a helper to work on her extra sewing machine. With the proceeds from her loan, she would like to differentiate her business by purchasing a variety of fabrics from Uganda and Nairobi.

Beatrice is a married mother of three boys, aged 11, 8, and 5. Paying for their school fees and feeding the family is difficult at times, but her income from the business combined with her husband’s income from mechanic’s work helps them to provide for their boys.

K-MET, the NGO giving the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional MFI. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. For more information about K-MET, please use the following link: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=24

loans.use: Purchasing new fabrics and supplies

loans.name: Zahida Parveen Abdul Hameed Shahzad Group

texts.en:
Zahida parveen baji is a wife of A. H. S. who lives in a city named Chichawatni, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband runs a clothes selling business. He has been in this business for over 3 years. Zahida baji helps him by selling the clothes in the community. She currently needs a loan to advance her husband’s business.

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality and those members are as follows:

Shagufta I. baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

I. baji wants a loan to buy items (table covers, chairs and tables) for her catering business.

Rani baji wants a loan to buy shoes to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Zahida baji is showing her clothes collection in this picture and holding her granddaughter in her lap.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Lem

texts.en:
Lem K., 29, is a Chinese interpreter for a garment factory, Blossom, run by a Chinese guy in Cambodia. He has an income of US$5 per day. He lives with his wife and two school-aged children. His wife stays at home and has been involved in the business of raising pigs since 1979 with an income of around US$1.6.

Seeing the chance that he is able to sell pigs with a fairly profitable price, he wants to take a loan of US$600 to buy more pigs for his wife to raise and sell them back at the right time when the price of the pigs goes up. If he succeeds with his business plan, he really wants to use his savings to build a house made from bricks.

loans.use: To buy pigs

loans.name: Koko

texts.fr: Koko A. est un homme de 42 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants. il est conducteur de taxi moto à Lomé. Koko souhaite avec ce crédit  acheter une nouvelle moto.  ceci lui permettra de limiter les diverses dépenses que lui cause les réparations et de mieux épargner pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Koko A. is a 42-year-old man, married, and the father of three. He is a motorbike taxi driver in Lomé. He wishes to use this loan to buy a new motorbike. This will enable him to limit the various expenses due to repairs and to save more money for meeting the needs of his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new moto

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is a mother of three young children whose ages range from 2 to 7 years. Her dream is to grow her 10-year-old dress-making business to a larger scale by buying a large variety of materials, threads, buttons, and zippers. She currently has 2 machines and has hired one employee to help her with large orders. Joan specializes in ladies’ and children’s traditional clothing, aprons, and bags, and also takes custom orders from clients in her small shop in the Jubilee market of Kisumu.

K-MET, the NGO giving the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional MFI. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. For more information about K-MET, please use the following link: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=24

loans.use: Buying materials, threads, buttons, and zippers

loans.name: Meach

texts.en:
Meach M., 40, sells chickens and palm fruit in Phnom Penh City with gross revenue of $50 per day. She lives with her husband and four school-aged children. Her husband always helps her with her current business at the market.

M. has to work hard to generate income for her children’s education-related and family expanses, so she has made up her mind to take a loan of $600 to expand her business. M. was not available, so her husband is pictured with his palm fruit instead.

loans.use: To buy chickens and palm fruit

loans.name: Kosar Parveen Niaz Ali Group

texts.en:
Kosar parveen baji is a wife of N. A. and has resided in a city named Borewala, Pakistan for the past 18 years. They both have a business making & selling plastic bottles. Kosar baji stays at home and prepares the bottles while N. A. goes to different shops and clinics to sell them. They started this business 4 years ago; they are special in this work because they do it well. Kosar baji currently needs a loan to advance their business. She is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy milk to sell. Salamat baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to sell. Amna kosar baji wants a loan to buy calling cards to sell. Suraiya nasreen baji wants a loan to buy vegetables to sell. This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: “Kosar baji is seated in the middle of the baji’s and is showing her plastic bottles”.

loans.use: To buy plastic for making plastic bottles to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a freezer

loans.name: Nasreen Akhtar Muhammad Ayub Group

texts.en:
"My name is Nasreen akhtar and I am a citizen of a city named Borewala, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. My husband's name is M. A. and he is involved in animal husbandry. He feeds buffalos and sells them. He has been in this business for over 6 years. I also help him by taking care of his animals. I am applying for a loan to advance his business."


She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Tahmina baji wants a loan to buy fruits for her fruit selling business. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy bicycles for her rented bicycles business. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: “Nasreen baji is standing with her granddaughter in this picture”.

loans.use: To buy buffalo to sell

loans.name: Mukhtaran Abdul Rasheed Group

texts.en:
Mukhtaran baji is a wife of A. R. and has resided in a city named Borewala, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Her husband has a business selling vegetables. He has been doing this work for over 3 years. Mukhtaran baji wants to set a good example for her grandchildren and for her family. In spite of her age, she keeps working at sewing clothes for her own well being and that of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to advance her husband’s business. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Hamidan baji and Sumera baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Jamila baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.
